THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Raymond G. Gelinas,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Department of Public Safety,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 20040UP-498
Submitted September 19, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  October 5, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Daniel D. Dâ€™Agostino, of York, for Appellant. 
Frank L. Valenta, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The Department of Public Safety suspended Raymond G. Gelinasâ€™ 
  driverâ€™s license after he refused to take an alcohol breath test.Â  The circuit 
  court affirmed the Departmentâ€™s administrative hearing officerâ€™s decision sustaining 
  the suspension.Â  Gelinas appeals and we affirm. 
  [1] Â  
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Officer Gilstrap arrested 
  Gelinas for DUI during a traffic stop after he smelled the odor of alcohol on 
  him and Gelinas failed a sobriety test.Â  At the law enforcement center, Officer 
  Gilstrap advised Gelinas of his implied consent rights and requested he take 
  the Datamaster test. Â The officer began setting up the Datamaster when 
  Gelinas told the officer he was not going to take the test.Â  The test was never 
  administered. [2]  Â Because of Gelinasâ€™ refusal and pursuant 
  to applicable law, Officer Gilstrap issued a Notice of Suspension suspending 
  Gelinasâ€™ driving privileges.Â  
On appeal to the circuit court, 
  Gelinas argued the implied consent law permits only a qualified Datamaster operator 
  to offer an alcohol breath test. Â He claimed that because Officer Gilstrap 
  was the arresting officer, he could not be qualified as the Datamaster operator 
  until after he videotaped Gelinasâ€™ conduct pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann. 
  sections 56-5-2950(a) and 56-5-2953(A)(2)(d) (Supp. 2003).Â  All parties agreed 
  no videotaping occurred. Â Gelinas therefore contended the officer could 
  not offer him a valid test to refuse, thus invalidating his suspension.Â  
The circuit court disagreed and 
  upheld Gelinasâ€™ suspension finding â€œthe arresting officer, if certified, is 
  qualified to administer all pre-test processes and procedures including accepting 
  a refusal, right from the start.â€ Â Moreover, the court concluded the question 
  of whether Gelinas was offered a valid test was irrelevant because the precautionary 
  rules governing test procedures are inapplicable if the test is refused.Â  To 
  support its conclusion, the court relied on State v. Jansen, 305 S.C. 
  320, 408 S.E.2d 235 (1991), wherein our supreme court held the validity of test 
  methods will not be considered when no test is administered and no test results 
  are offered into evidence. Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appeal from a decision of 
  the department of public safety is governed by the Administrative Procedures 
  Act.Â  Byerly Hosp. v. South Carolina State Health & Human Servs. Fin. 
  Commâ€™n, 319 S.C. 225, 229, 460 S.E.2d 383, 385 (1995).Â  Therefore, when 
  reviewing a final decision of the department, the circuit court, sitting as 
  an appellate court, may not substitute its judgment for that of the department 
  as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  The departmentâ€™s decision will be affirmed unless it is controlled 
  by an error of law or is without evidentiary support.Â  Mictronics, Inc. v. 
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 345 S.C. 506, 510, 548 S.E.2d 223, 225 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
DISCUSSION
Gelinas contends the circuit 
  court erred in determining he was offered a valid test because the Datamaster 
  operator, who was also the arresting officer, did not observe or videotape him 
  during a twenty-minute pre-test waiting period before offering the test.Â  He 
  therefore claims his refusal was void for lack of a valid test offer requiring 
  the circuit court to reverse his suspension and reinstate his driving privileges.Â  
  We disagree.
South Carolina Code Ann. section 
  56-5-2950(a) (Supp. 2003) states â€œ[t]he arresting officer may administer 
  the tests if the [arrested] personâ€™s conduct during the twenty-minute pre-test 
  waiting period is videotaped pursuant to Section 56-2-2953(A)(2)(d).â€Â  (Emphasis 
  added.)Â  Section 56-2-2953(A)(2)(d) also states â€œif the arresting officer 
  administers the breath test, the personâ€™s conduct during the twenty-minute 
  pre-test waiting period must be videotaped.â€Â  (Emphasis added.)Â  
The statutes require an arresting 
  officer to videotape a personâ€™s conduct if he administers the Datamaster test, 
  not offers it.Â  Therefore, Officer Gilstrap did not have to videotape Gelinas 
  or observe the twenty-minute waiting period prior to offering the test and accepting 
  the refusal.Â  Moreover, the purpose of the videotaping is â€œto insure that the 
  results of the breathalyzer test if given are accurate and reliable as evidence 
  at trial.â€Â  State v. Jansen, 305 S.C. 320, 322, 408 S.E.2d 235, 237 (1991).Â  
  Because Gelinasâ€™ suspension did not depend on the reliability of the test results, 
  he may not challenge Officer Gilstrapâ€™s pre-test qualifications or methods.Â  
  See Jansen, 305 S.C. at 322-23, 408 S.E.2d at 237 (holding testing 
  precautions â€œdo not apply to the offer and refusal of a breathalyzer testâ€ and 
  a defendant may not question the validity of test methods when â€œno test was 
  given, and there were no results offered as evidence by the Stateâ€); see 
  also Ex parte Horne, 303 S.C. 30, 32, 397 S.E.2d 788, 789 (Ct. 
  App. 1990) (â€œThe question of the validity of test methods employed by a breath 
  test operator does not arise until a test is given and its results are offered 
  as evidence.â€). Â 
AFFIRMED.
 STILWELL, BEATTY, 
  and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  At the hearing before the circuit court, Gelinasâ€™ counsel 
    stated Officer Gilstrap entered the time, date â€œand everything elseâ€ into 
    the Datamaster before Gelinas refused to take the test.Â  Counsel therefore 
    argued testing had already begun and was terminated on Gelinasâ€™ refusal.Â  
    However, we find Officer Gilstrap was merely preparing the Datamaster for 
    an anticipated breath test that never occurred.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Tyrese R. Chisolm,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-499
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  October 5, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan 
  McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney 
  General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, 
  Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tyrese R. Chisolm appeals his 
  second-degree burglary conviction, arguing the trial court erred in refusing 
  to allow rehabilitative evidence of his alibi witnessâ€™ truthful character.Â  
  We reverse and remand for a new trial. 
  [1]   
FACTS
Doug Sweeney and his friend, Jackson Goss, stopped 
  by Sweeneyâ€™s apartment building and were almost to the front door when a man 
  they did not recognize came out of the doorway with a green bicycle.Â  The men 
  exchanged hellos and Sweeney and Goss went inside.Â  When Sweeney thought to 
  himself that the man did not look like someone who would be visiting his downstairs 
  neighbors, he asked his roommate whether the neighbors had a green bicycle.Â  
  She said they did and told him one of her own bicycles had been stolen only 
  two hours earlier.Â  Sweeney called 911 and with Gossâ€™ help, provided a description 
  of the man.Â  
Sarah Samuel, Sweeneyâ€™s neighbor, testified 
  her green bicycle was taken from the apartment building.Â  She had left the bicycle 
  under a stairwell inside the building.Â  When she returned, the police were there 
  and she learned of the theft. Â 
An officer patrolling the area where 
  the burglary occurred noticed Chisolm, who matched the burglarâ€™s description 
  and was on a green bicycle.Â  Chisolm attempted to escape when the officer asked 
  him to stop, eventually leaving the bicycle and fleeing on foot.Â  However, the 
  officer caught up with him. Â Chisolm was taken into custody at approximately 
  4:15, about an hour to an hour and fifteen minutes after Sweeney and Goss first 
  saw the burglar.Â  
Chisolm presented an alibi defense.Â  
  He testified he was at the Steinberg Law Firm at the time of the crime, waiting 
  to see Steven Goldberg regarding a workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  He claimed 
  that after he left the office, he purchased the bicycle and a cell phone from 
  a man fitting the burglarâ€™s description.Â  
Critical to Chisolmâ€™s defense was the 
  testimony of Walter Bilbro, an attorney who had associated members of the Steinberg 
  firm on Chisolmâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  Bilbro testified he had reminded 
  Chisolm of his 1:00 p.m. appointment with Goldberg and that at approximately 
  3:50 p.m. Chisolm called him from the firm to tell him he had been waiting for 
  Goldberg but Goldberg failed to meet him.Â  Bilbro testified Chisolm put a receptionist 
  on the phone at Bilbroâ€™s request and she confirmed that Chisolm had been waiting 
  and that Goldberg was not in the office.Â  Other witnesses placed Chisolm 
  at the firm that afternoon, and testified he waited a considerable time for 
  Goldberg, but they were not able to confirm precisely when Chisolm was there.Â  

During Bilbroâ€™s direct testimony, he 
  admitted the Supreme Court had publicly reprimanded him.Â  During the Stateâ€™s 
  cross-examination, Bilbro revealed he was reprimanded for violating the rule 
  requiring attorneys to refrain from conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, 
  or misrepresentation and for violating the rule that prohibits an attorney from 
  engaging in conduct tending to bring the legal profession into disrepute.Â  In 
  response, the defense asked to submit the testimony of another attorney in the 
  community who would speak positively regarding Bilbroâ€™s reputation for honesty.Â  
  The court refused to admit the testimony, citing the possibility of several 
  witnesses for each side on the issue.Â  The court reasoned the dueling testimony 
  could distract everyone from the â€œtrue purposeâ€ of the trialâ€”Chisolmâ€™s â€œguilt 
  or innocence.â€Â  The prosecution and defense stipulated that if allowed, 
  the defense would have called attorney Stephen Booker, who would have testified 
  he had dealt with Bilbro on many cases, working both with him and against him; 
  that he knew his reputation for truthfulness in the community; and that his 
  reputation in the legal community is that he is truthful.Â  
DISCUSSION
The admission of evidence is within the 
  trial courtâ€™s sound discretion and will not be reversed on appeal absent an 
  abuse of that discretion.Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling is based on an error of law.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 
  325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000).Â  Evidence of a witnessâ€™ truthful character 
  is only admissible after the witnessâ€™ character for truthfulness â€œhas been attacked 
  by opinion or reputation evidence or otherwise.â€Â  Rule 608(a)(2), SCRE.Â  â€œImpeachment 
  is not a dispassionate study of the witnessâ€™s capacities and character, but 
  rather is regarded in our tradition as an attack upon his credibility.Â  
  Under our adversary system of trials, the witnessâ€™s proponent must be given 
  an opportunity to meet this attack by evidence rehabilitating the witness.â€Â  
  1 McCormick on Evidence Â§ 47 (5th ed. 1999).
Here, the State attacked Bilbroâ€™s character for 
  truthfulness by inquiring about the details of his public reprimand.Â  The Stateâ€™s 
  examination revealed Bilbro had been reprimanded for violating Rule 407, which 
  prohibits attorneys from engaging in â€œdishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation.â€Â  
  The prosecutor had Bilbro read the rule into the record.Â  The Stateâ€™s cross-examination 
  clearly was intended to damage Bilbroâ€™s credibility as a truthful witness.Â  
  Evidence of his truthful character, such as Bookerâ€™s testimony, was thereby 
  rendered admissible under Rule 608(a)(2).Â  The trial courtâ€™s refusal to admit 
  the proffered evidence was thus governed by an error of law.Â  Further, because 
  Bilbroâ€™s testimony was central to Chisolmâ€™s defense, the exclusion of evidence 
  of his truthful reputation cannot be considered harmless.Â  See State 
  v. Bell, 302 S.C. 18, 27, 393 S.E.2d 364, 369 (1990) (holding exclusion 
  of evidence is reversible only where error and prejudice are shown); State 
  v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (holding whether 
  an error is harmless depends on the circumstances of the case, but it is harmless 
  where it could not reasonably have changed the outcome of the trial).
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  This appeal was originally submitted pursuant to Anders 
    v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).Â  The court denied counselâ€™s petition 
    to be relieved and ordered re-briefing on this issue.Â  We decide this case 
    without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Sylvia Dunbar, as Guardian ad Litem for Akeya Johnson, a minor under 
        the age of eighteen (18) years,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Willette L. Johnson,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Allendale County
Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-500
Submitted September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  October 5, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Lewis C. Lanier, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
Mark B. Tinsley, of Allendale and Robert N. Hill, of Newberry, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Sylvia Dunbar brought this 
  action as Guardian ad Litem for Akeya Johnson, a minor under the age of eighteen, 
  to recover damages as a result of an automobile accident in which Akeya Johnson 
  was a passenger in a vehicle driven by Willette L. Johnson.Â  The jury returned 
  a verdict in favor of Akeya in the amount of $62,000 and a judgment was entered 
  in this amount.Â  Willette Johnson appeals, claiming the trial court erred in 
  denying her motion for a new trial because the verdict was excessive and the 
  trial court failed to issue a jury charge on sudden emergency.Â  She also argues 
  a new trial should have been granted because the circuit court improperly admitted 
  some testimony from the investigating officer while improperly excluding other 
  testimony. We affirm.
ANALYSIS
Because Appellant failed to address 
  the trial courtâ€™s initial ground for denying her post-trial motion, we need 
  not address the issues raised on appeal.Â  We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s denial 
  based solely on the fact that Appellantâ€™s motion for a new trial was untimely 
  filed.
Rule 59(b), SCRCP, states â€œ[t]he motion 
  for a new trial shall be made promptly after the jury is discharged, or in the 
  discretion of the court not later than 10 days thereafter.â€Â  Following discharge 
  of the jury, the trial court granted Appellant the maximum ten days to file 
  her post-trial motions.Â  Documents received by this court from the Allendale 
  County courthouse reveal that Appellantâ€™s motion was filed beyond the ten-day 
  period.
Initially, the trial court found Appellant 
  improperly made her motion pursuant to a repealed statute.Â  The court expanded 
  on this ground for denial as follows:

This fact alone provides a sufficient basis for the denial 
  of Defendantâ€™s motion.Â  Nonetheless, the motion also would be denied if it had 
  been made pursuant to Rule 59(a), SCRCP. [the current rule for post-trial motions]

In a footnote to the above quotation, the court 
  continued:

The Court notes that the time limit for filing a Rule 59(a) 
  motion has expired, but because its ruling would be the same if the proper motion 
  had been timely filed, it discusses the validity of the request for a new trial.

The trial court went on to discuss the merits of 
  Appellantâ€™s motion for a new trial based on the issues now raised on appeal.Â  
  The motion was ultimately denied.
Appellant 
  argues several errors in the trial courtâ€™s order, but does not raise an exception 
  to the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion on the basis of timeliness.Â  Accordingly, 
  we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision based solely on the untimeliness of Appellantâ€™s 
  motion for a new trial.Â Â Â  See Dwyer v. Jenkins, 289 S.C. 118, 
  120-121, 344 S.E.2d 886, 888 (Ct. App. 1986) (affirming the circuit court when 
  unchallenged alternative findings support the judgment); 5 Am. Jur. 2d Appellate 
  Review Â§ 829 at 489 (1995) (â€œwhere a separate and independent ground from 
  the one appealed supports the judgment made below, and is not challenged on 
  appeal, the appellate court must affirm.â€).Â  We need not address the merits 
  of the other issues raised on appeal.Â  See Rule 220 (c), SCACR; Futch 
  v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 
  591, 598 (1999) (holding appellate courts need not address remaining issues 
  when the disposition of a prior issue is dispositive).  
The circuit courtâ€™s decision to deny Appellantâ€™s 
  motion for a new trial is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS,
JJ., 
  concur.

Bi-Lo, Inc.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Union County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-504
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  8, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Nancy Browning, of Union, Pro Se.
Samuel W. Outten and Laurel R.S. Blair, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This is a slip and fall case.Â  
  Nancy Browning appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment 
  to Bi-Lo, Inc.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
On August 21, 1998, Browning slipped and fell on 
  a substance in a Bi-Lo grocery store.Â  As a result of the fall, Browning sustained 
  an injury to her right shoulder.Â  She subsequently filed suit against Bi-Lo.Â  
  Bi-Lo answered, denying liability and averring that Browning was comparatively 
  negligent.Â  Bi-Lo then moved for summary judgment, which the circuit judge granted.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of summary judgment, 
  the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant 
  to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 
  (2002).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue of material 
  fact such that the moving party must prevail as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), 
  SCRCP; Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 487 S.E.2d 187 (1997).
LAW
I.
Browning argues the 
  circuit judge erred in granting Bi-Loâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We disagree.
To recover damages for 
  injuries caused by a dangerous or defective condition on a storekeeperâ€™s premises, 
  the plaintiff must show either (1) that the injury was caused by a specific 
  act of the defendant which created the dangerous condition; or (2) that the 
  defendant had actual or constructive knowledge of the dangerous condition and 
  failed to remedy it.Â  Wintersteen v. Food Lion, Inc., 344 S.C. 32, 542 
  S.E.2d 728 (2001).Â  In the case of a foreign substance, the plaintiff must demonstrate 
  either that the substance was placed there by the defendant or its agents, or 
  that the defendant had actual or constructive notice the substance was on the 
  floor at the time of the slip and fall.Â  Id. at 35, 542 S.E.2d at 729-30.Â  
  The mere fact the substance was on the floor is insufficient standing alone 
  to charge the storekeeper with negligence.Â  Calvert v. House Beautiful Paint 
  & Decorating Ctr., Inc., 313 S.C. 494, 443 S.E.2d 398 (1994).
Here, the record reveals no evidence 
  that Bi-Lo either placed the foreign substance on the floor or had actual or 
  constructive notice that the substance was on the floor before Browningâ€™s fall.Â  
  In her deposition, Browning testified that she did not see the alleged foreign 
  substance before she fell because she was not looking at the floor and she had 
  no idea who placed the substance on the floor.Â  When asked what evidence she 
  had that Bi-Lo was on notice of the substance on the floor prior to her fall, 
  Browning stated there was a video camera operating â€œ[r]ight aboveâ€ the place 
  where she fell.Â  Browning asserts Bi-Lo had constructive notice by virtue of 
  a camera directed at the location where the fall occurred and the presence of 
  a monitor fed by the camera in an area allegedly observable by Bi-Lo employees 
  at the time of the fall.Â  There is no evidence the mere presence of a camera 
  constituted constructive notice to Bi-Lo.Â  Additionally, the presence or absence 
  of an incident report completed after Browningâ€™s fall has no bearing on Bi-Loâ€™s 
  notice of the foreign substance before the fall.
Because Browning failed to meet 
  her burden as to the two Wintersteen elements, we find the trial court 
  did not err in granting summary judgment to Bi-Lo.Â  It is clear that Browning 
  has failed to present any evidence establishing a genuine issue of fact for 
  trial.
II.
Browning contends that 
  her attorney â€œdid not represent same in as much as he did not disagree with 
  counsel for Bi-Lo.â€Â  She further maintains that Bi-Loâ€™s attorney â€œ[m]ade inaccurate 
  statements toâ€ the judge when the attorney â€œstated that there was no incident 
  report filed.â€
These issues on appeal 
  were abandoned due to their conclusory nature and lack of supporting authority.Â  
  See Glasscock, Inc. v. United States Fidelity & Guar. Co., 
  348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œSouth Carolina law clearly 
  states that short, conclusory statements made without supporting authority are 
  deemed abandoned on appeal and therefore not presented for review.â€).Â  Moreover, 
  because these issues were not raised to and ruled upon by the circuit judge, 
  they are not preserved for our review.Â  See Widman v. Widman, 
  348 S.C. 97, 557 S.E.2d 693 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding issue cannot be raised 
  for first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by trial 
  judge to be preserved for appellate review).
III.
Browningâ€™s â€œStatement of Issues 
  on Appealâ€ includes the bare assertion that â€œMs. Jennifer Eubanks fell on a 
  green substance in the store approximately thirty minutes before Plaintiffâ€™s 
  accident.â€Â  This conclusory statement is insufficient to preserve this issue 
  for appellate review.Â  See Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 
  S.C. 102, 439 S.E.2d 283 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding an issue is deemed abandoned 
  and thus not presented for appellate review if argued in a short, conclusory 
  statement).
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, 
  based on the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit judge is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Edna L. Calhoun,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Marlboro County School District,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-505
Heard September 16, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  8, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
W. Allen Nickles, III, Carl L. Solomon and Dona L. Guffey, 
  all of Columbia, for Appellant.
Shirley M. Fawley, Vernie L. Williams and Kenneth L. Childs, 
  all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 
PER CURIAM:Â  Dr. Edna L. Calhoun appeals 
  the order of the circuit court affirming the decision of the Marlboro County 
  School District Board (Board) not to renew her teaching contract.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Calhoun taught in various Marlboro County schools 
  for nearly fifty years.Â  Her most recent tenure was as a social studies teacher 
  at Marlboro County High School (MCHS), which was located in the Marlboro County 
  School District (District).
Rocky E. Peterkin became principal of 
  MCHS in 1999.Â  During the course of the 1999-2000 school year, he observed the 
  teaching performance of the MCHS faculty members.Â  While observing Calhounâ€™s 
  teaching performance in the Fall of 1999, Peterkin developed â€œsignificant concernsâ€ 
  about the quality of Calhounâ€™s teaching performance, including â€œthe method by 
  which [her] lesson plans were planned and implemented â€¦ how objectives did not 
  always mesh with the lessons being taught, and â€¦ about the lack of a verified 
  teacherâ€™s strategies (sic) to meet the needs of all students.â€ 
Consequently, he met with Calhoun in December 1999 
  to advise her of his concerns and make her aware that in the spring 2000 semester 
  he intended to â€œput her on a professional development plan with [the] full intent 
  that the plan support and strengthen her abilities to teach.â€Â  Peterkin wrote 
  Calhoun in January 2000 to reiterate that a â€œprofessional development planâ€ 
  would be devised for her â€œimplementation during the second semester of the 1999-2000 
  school yearâ€ and that â€œthe purpose of this plan is to provide additional administrative 
  support for [her] classroom instruction.â€Â  
The three-page development plan provided focus 
  on the dual goals of improving Calhounâ€™s â€œInstruction Presentationâ€ and â€œFacilitating 
  Instructionâ€ skills.Â  Within each goal, the plan included specific objectives 
  and activities designed to achieve the objectives.Â  Descriptions of appropriate 
  evidence that Calhoun had completed the activities were provided, as well as 
  descriptions of relevant resources available to help Calhoun complete the activities, 
  and â€œcompletion datesâ€ for each activity.Â  Additionally, Calhoun was assigned 
  to participate in â€œCooperative Learning Sessionsâ€ to help improve her teaching 
  skills. 
Throughout the spring 2000 semester, a team of 
  District and MCHS administrators observed Calhounâ€™s teaching performance and 
  efforts to comply with the development plan.Â  Based on those observations, Peterkin 
  determined Calhoun had not satisfactorily improved her teaching performance, 
  and notified District superintendent Dr. Ray Brayboy of his concerns.Â Â  
In an April 3, 2000 letter, Brayboy informed Calhoun 
  that Peterkin and she were to meet and develop an improvement plan for Calhoun 
  to pursue in the 2000-2001 school year.Â  Brayboy further informed Calhoun that 
  Peterkin would â€œalso be monitoring and evaluating [her] performance to see that 
  the necessary improvements are made.â€Â  He added, â€œYour failure to address these 
  concerns could place your continued employment with this District in jeopardy.â€ 

Peterkin met with Calhoun on April 6, 2000, after which 
  he summarized their meeting in a written letter to Calhoun.Â  In the letter, 
  Peterkin wrote:

This letter is a follow-up to our conference on April 6, 
  2000, in which I shared with you my serious concerns with your overall teaching 
  performance.Â  In particular, we discussed my continued reservations regarding 
  your long- and short-range planning, delivery of instruction in accordance with 
  District expectations, treatment of and communications with students, classroom 
  environment, and classroom management skills.

Peterkin added that, based on observations of Calhounâ€™s 
  teaching performance, he saw a â€œcontinued need for improvement,â€ and that she 
  â€œwould be provided with an Improvement Plan to assistâ€ her.Â  He added that â€œ[s]hould 
  [she] fail in the upcoming year to complete successfully the S.T.E.P. process 
  [1]  or to demonstrate significant improvement in [her] teaching performance, 
  [her] continued employment with this District may be in jeopardy.â€ 
Peterkin later provided Calhoun with a detailed 
  improvement plan for the 2000-2001 school year, which was designed to strengthen 
  identified teaching deficiencies.Â  In a May 25, 2000 letter from Peterkin to 
  Calhoun, he noted that she was given the plan because of â€œconcerns about [her] 
  overall teaching performance in the areas of accommodating the needs of special 
  education students enrolled in [her] classes, delivery of instruction, time 
  on task by [her] students, and classroom management.â€Â  Peterkin sought to meet 
  with Calhoun to discuss the plan and â€œany revisionsâ€ she wanted to make to the 
  plan.Â  He reiterated his earlier warning that â€œif significant improvement in 
  your job performance is not noted, your continued employment with this District 
  will be in jeopardy.â€
During the 2000-2001 school year, Calhounâ€™s teaching 
  performance was evaluated under the S.T.E.P. plan by Peterkin and Assistant 
  Principal Sequal Black.Â  Among other things, they observed that Calhoun was 
  not following lesson plans, students were allowed to copy answers from their 
  textbooks during tests, and that students were permitted to chose whether to 
  even take social studies tests.Â  Of particular concern to Black were observations 
  that the needs of special education students were not being met as required 
  by federal law.Â  Calhounâ€™s preliminary S.T.E.P. evaluation results for the 2000-2001 
  school year were â€œunsatisfactoryâ€ with nine subsections rated â€œprofessionalâ€ 
  and six rated as â€œneeds improvement.â€Â  Peterkin provided a formal, written remediation 
  plan to address Calhounâ€™s teaching areas deemed unsatisfactory.Â  The plan included 
  suggested professional readings, staff development training, and other specific 
  ideas for improvement.
In spite of Calhounâ€™s â€œunsatisfactoryâ€ results 
  on the S.T.E.P. evaluations, Peterkin recommended to Superintendent Brayboy 
  that for the 2001-2002 school year Calhoun receive a third opportunity to improve 
  her â€œoverall teaching performance.â€Â  Peterkin recommended continued assistance 
  and a second formal S.T.E.P. evaluation for the 2001-2002 school year.Â  
Brayboy accepted Peterkinâ€™s recommendations.Â  He 
  advised Calhoun by letter dated April 5, 2001 that the District would renew 
  her contract for the 2001-2002 school year, but that ongoing, serious concerns 
  about her teaching performance motivated the District to continue formal evaluation 
  of her teaching performance during the year.Â  He again noted that the District 
  expected â€œsignificant and consistent progress in improving [her] overall teaching 
  performance,â€ and that failure to do so satisfactorily would put her â€œcontinued 
  employment with the District in jeopardy.â€
For the 2001-2002 school year, Calhounâ€™s S.T.E.P. 
  evaluation team consisted of District administrators Mildred Baker and Herbert 
  Gould, a former MCHS principal.Â  Throughout the year, Calhoun was observed and 
  provided written and oral assistance.Â  However, in the December 2001 initial 
  review of her S.T.E.P. evaluation, she again received an unsatisfactory evaluation 
  of her performance including â€œprofessionalâ€ ratings on ten S.T.E.P. subsections 
  and â€œneeds improvementâ€ ratings on five subsections.Â  
Consequently, Baker, Gould, and Peterkin met with 
  Calhoun for approximately three hours in December 2001 to review her results 
  and provide Calhoun a written remediation plan with specific objectives, strategies, 
  and deadlines.Â  The District gave Calhoun a â€œresource notebookâ€ with materials 
  â€œprepared to help her with her classroom teaching.â€Â  However, Calhoun returned 
  the binder to Bakerâ€™s office, stating she was not going to read the â€œstuffâ€ 
  in the binder.Â  In a written letter from Baker to Calhoun on February 4, 2002, 
  Baker expressed her disappointment in Calhounâ€™s disregard of the resource notebook, 
  and detailed examples of Calhounâ€™s noncompliance with several requirements of 
  the remediation plan.Â  Ultimately, Calhoun failed to complete the majority of 
  the remediation plan recommendations. 
On March 8, 2002, Gould and Baker again 
  met with Calhoun to review their final 2001-2002 S.T.E.P. evaluation results.Â  
  Calhoun received an overall rating of â€œunsatisfactoryâ€ with six subsections 
  rated â€œprofessionalâ€ and nine subsections rated â€œneeds improvement.â€Â  During 
  the conference, Gould reviewed each category of evaluation.Â  They asked Calhoun 
  if there was anything she wanted Baker or him to address, and whether they could 
  do anything further to assist her.Â  She responded that she thought she was doing 
  what was expected of her.
Based on Calhounâ€™s two final â€œunsatisfactoryâ€ 
  S.T.E.P. evaluations andÂ  his personal evaluation of Calhoun, Peterkin recommended 
  to Superintendent Brayboy that Calhoun not be given a teaching employment contract 
  for the 2002-2003 school year.Â  Brayboy agreed, and notified Calhoun in an April 
  1, 2000 letter that he had recommended to the Board that her contract not be 
  renewed.
In response to Brayboyâ€™s recommendation, 
  the Board conducted a review and held a hearing to review whether Calhounâ€™s 
  contract should be renewed.Â  At the hearing, all parties were represented by 
  counsel.
Peterkin, Gould, Baker, and Black each detailed 
  numerous examples of how over a two-and-a-half year period Calhoun received 
  repeated written notices concerning alleged deficiencies about her teaching 
  performance.Â  This testimony further indicated the following: (1) Calhoun was 
  given remedial programs that she largely ignored or failed to complete; and 
  (2) Calhoun was subject to comprehensive informal and formal evaluations that 
  consistently indicated her teaching performance was generally unsatisfactory 
  with little signs of improving.Â  
During the hearing, Calhoun testified 
  that prior to Peterkinâ€™s initial expression of concern about her teaching performance 
  in the fall of 1999, at least one other principal had expressed â€œmajor concernsâ€ 
  about her teaching.Â  When asked if she had communication problems with Peterkin, 
  she only replied, â€œWell, heâ€™s a friendly person, but he seems to be busy.â€Â  
  When asked, â€œisnâ€™t it true that over the past two-and-a-half years Mr. Peterkin 
  and others have provided you with either remediation plans or improvement plans 
  designed to help you improve your teaching,â€ Calhoun responded â€œYes. But the 
  suggestions that they were making that I should attend to, I felt I was doing 
  that thoroughly.â€Â  The thrust of the evidence offered by Calhoun was that she 
  was properly responding to the remediation efforts.
The Board decided not to renew Calhounâ€™s 
  teaching contract for the 2002-2003 school year, thereby adopting the superintendentâ€™s 
  recommendation.Â  She appealed the decision of the Board to the circuit court, 
  which affirmed.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe scope of review that applies to cases brought 
  under the Teacher Employment and Dismissal Act is limited to whether the grounds 
  given for termination of employment are supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  
  Hendrickson v. Spartanburg County Sch. Dist., 307 S.C. 108, 110, 413 
  S.E.2d 871, 872-73 (Ct. App. 1992).Â Â Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla 
  of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is 
  evidence which, considering the record as a whole would allow reasonable minds 
  to reach the conclusion the administrative agency must have reached in order 
  to justify its action.â€Â  Â Id., 307 S.C. at 110-11, 413 S.E.2d at 873.
DISCUSSION
I.
Calhoun first argues that the Board failed to enforce 
  her legal right to receive written notice of perceived deficiencies and an opportunity 
  to improve.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Teacher Employment and Dismissal Act 
  (the Act) governs the employment and dismissal of all continuing contract teachers 
  in the South Carolina public school system.Â  Among other things, it empowers 
  school boards to employ teachers and to discharge them â€œwhen good and sufficient 
  reasons for doing so present themselves.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-19-90(2) (1976).Â  
  Here, Calhoun was terminated pursuant to two portions of the Act.Â  The first 
  provides:

[a]ny teacher may be dismissed at any time who shall 
  fail, or who may be incompetent, to give instruction in accordance with the 
  directions of the superintendent, or who shall otherwise manifest an evident 
  unfitness for teaching; provided, however, that notice and an opportunity 
  shall be afforded for a hearing prior to any dismissal. Evident unfitness for 
  teaching is manifested by conduct such as, but not limited to, the following: 
  persistent neglect of duty, willful violation of rules and regulations of district 
  board of trustees â€¦.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-25-430 (1976) (emphasis removed).Â  
  The second part of the Act upon which the Board based its termination provides:

[w]henever a superior, principal,Â  or supervisor charged with 
  the supervision of a teacher finds it necessary to admonish a teacher for a 
  reason that he believes may lead to, or be cited as a reason for, dismissal 
  or cause the teacher not to be reemployed he shall: (1) bring the matter in 
  writing to the attention of the teacher involved and make a reasonable effort 
  to assist the teacher to correct whatever appears to be the cause of potential 
  dismissal or failure to be reemployed and, (2) except as provided in 
  Â§ 59-25-450 [2] , allow reasonable 
  time for improvement.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-25-440 (1976) (emphasis added).
In the present case, Calhoun received numerous written 
  and oral warnings over nearly a three-year period, beginning in the fall of 
  1999.Â  By her own admission, Peterkin provided Calhoun a written notice of his 
  concerns about her teaching performance and parent complaints as early as January 
  2000. Â Furthermore, Calhoun does not dispute that for a two-and-one-half 
  year period preceding the Boardâ€™s decision not to renew her contract, Peterkin 
  and others provided her â€œwith either remediation plans or improvement plans 
  designed to help â€¦ improve [her] teaching.â€ Rather, she expressed a belief that 
  she was â€œthoroughlyâ€ addressing their suggestions.Â  In essence, she offers no 
  indication that, given more time to improve, she would alter her performance 
  in any way.Â  We find that sufficient evidence exists to establish that Calhoun 
  received sufficient written notice of alleged deficiencies with her performance, 
  more than reasonable assistance by MCHS to help her correct the alleged deficiencies, 
  and a reasonable amount of time to demonstrate improvement in the areas of alleged 
  deficiencies. 
II.
Calhoun next argues that the Act gives rise to a fiduciary 
  duty that the Board breached by allowing her to be evaluated by an allegedly 
  â€œflawed process.â€Â  We acknowledge â€“ as does the District â€“ that a school board 
  owes a general duty of good faith and fair dealing consistent with the procedures 
  and mandates of the Act.Â  We, however, need not reach the question of whether 
  the Act creates a separate and independent fiduciary duty, for Calhoun has failed 
  in any event to establish a breach of any such duty. 
  [3] 
One alleged flaw in the evaluation process, according 
  to Calhoun, is that past comments allegedly made by S.T.E.P. evaluator Baker 
  suggested her â€œbiasâ€ against Calhoun.Â  However, Calhoun offers no evidence of 
  actual bias on Bakerâ€™s part.Â  We thus find no merit to this argument.Â  See 
  Green v. Clarendon County School Dist. Three, 923 F.Supp. 829, 846 (D.S.C. 
  1996)(stating that the â€œnebulous concept of a â€˜probabilityâ€™ of unfairness[] 
  is not sufficient proof of actual biasâ€). 
The second alleged flaw stems from evaluator Blackâ€™s 
  testimony that she had â€œsecretâ€ concerns about Calhounâ€™s performance that were 
  not reflected on Calhounâ€™s 2000-2001 evaluation.Â  Calhoun contends this violated 
  the Actâ€™s requirement that she receive written notice and remediation.Â  We have, 
  however, determined, as noted above, that Calhoun otherwise received sufficient 
  notice, remediation guidance, and time to demonstrate improvement over a two-and-one-half 
  year period prior to the decision of the Board not to renew her contract.Â  A 
  review of the record demonstrates that the ultimate decision of the Board was 
  based on the cumulative effect of all facts and circumstances surrounding Calhounâ€™s 
  persistent pattern of noncompliance with the remediation plans.Â  There was no 
  substantial reliance on the so-called â€œsecretâ€ concerns of Black.Â  We find no 
  â€œbreachâ€ of the Act or purported fiduciary duty.Â  
III.
Calhoun contends the District 
  failed to prove its case before the Board because the District relied, in part, 
  on hearsay evidence of parent and student complaints regarding her teaching 
  performance.Â  In doing so, Calhoun argues the Board, in allowing such testimony, 
  violated her Constitutional rights.Â  We disagree.
It is well established 
  that school board hearings under the Act are â€œquasi-judicialâ€ administrative 
  hearings.Â  See e.g., Laws v. Richland County School Dist. No. 
  1, 270 S.C. 492, 243 S.E.2d 192 (1978).Â  The rules of evidence do not strictly 
  apply to teacher dismissal hearings.Â  Richards v. City of Columbia, 227 
  S.C. 538, 552, 88 S.E.2d 683, 689 (1955) (â€œ[E]ven without the aid of statute 
  it is held that an administrative or quasi-judicial body is not governed by 
  the ordinary legal rules of evidenceâ€);Â  Jacoby v. S.C. State Bd. Of Naturopathic 
  Examiners, 219 S.C. 66, 90, 64 S.E.2d 138, 149 (1951) (â€œAn administrative 
  or quasi judicial body is allowed a wide latitude of procedure and not restricted 
  to the strict rule of evidence adhered to in a judicial court.â€).Â  Thus, we 
  find no error in the admission of hearsay evidence regarding parent and teacher 
  complaints. [4] Â  
IV.
Finally, Calhoun argues that the Board failed to 
  objectively determine if â€œgood and just causeâ€ had been proven to support the 
  Boardâ€™s decision not to renew her employment contract.Â  Calhoun maintains that 
  the Board refused â€œto view the record in its entiretyâ€ and disregarded testimony 
  favorable to Calhoun provided by one of Calhounâ€™s fellow faculty members, two 
  of Calhounâ€™s former students, and Calhounâ€™s sister.Â  Calhoun essentially urges 
  us to discredit the evidence relied upon by the Board. 
The ultimate inquiry is whether substantial evidence 
  supports the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  We find substantial evidence in the record to 
  support the Boardâ€™s decision to terminate Calhoun.Â  We emphasize that our limited 
  standard of review precludes fact-finding on our part.Â  Having concluded that 
  the Boardâ€™s decision is supported by substantial evidence, we are constrained 
  to affirm.Â Â  In so holding, we in no way diminish Dr. Calhounâ€™s lengthy and 
  laudable career in public education.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]    S.T.E.P. was a formal teacher evaluation process used 
    by District at the time.Â  

 
   
    [2]    Section 59-25-450 provides for the â€œimmediate suspensionâ€ 
    of teachers in limited circumstances.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-25-450 (1976).

 
   [3]   
  Calhoun cites Armstrong v. Sch. Dist. Five of Lexington County Richland 
    Counties, 26 F.Supp.2d. 789 (D.S.C. 1998) for the proposition that â€œschool 
    districts serve in a fiduciary capacity in matters related to teacher rights 
    and benefits.â€Â  We find Armstrong inapposite, for the imposition of 
    a fiduciary duty there concerned only the administration by the school district 
    of accrued employee benefits.Â  

 
   
    [4]     Even assuming that the admission of hearsay evidence was erroneous, 
    we find the error not prejudicial to Calhoun in light of the non-hearsay evidence

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Bill P. Passaloukas and Susie H.
Passaloukas, Individually and as Shareholders 
        derivatively on behalf of Zorba's Inc.,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Cynthia Bensch, Gary Bensch and Zorba's Inc.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Special Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-506
Submitted September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  October 11, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Frank F. Pape, Jr., of Atlanta, for Appellants.
James Arthur Brown, Jr., of Beaufort, for Respondents.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  In early 1999, Bill 
  and Susie Passaloukas (â€œAppellantsâ€) approached Gary and Cynthia Bensch (â€œRespondentsâ€) 
  and initiated discussion concerning the possible leasing of commercial real 
  estate owned by Respondents for the purpose of opening a restaurant.Â  Following 
  these discussions, the parties incorporated Zorbaâ€™s Inc., a statutory close 
  corporation, to operate the restaurant.Â  Appellants and Respondents were each 
  fifty-percent owners of this corporation, which was funded by contributions 
  in various forms from both parties.Â  Zorbaâ€™s Inc. then entered into a commercial 
  lease agreement with Respondents to rent retail space for the restaurant.Â  This 
  agreement essentially placed Respondents in the dual role of sole landlord and 
  half owner of the leasing entity.Â  
Zorbaâ€™s lease with Respondents provided 
  for default in the event rent was not paid, and clearly stated eviction could 
  occur if default was not cured within ten days of notice.Â  Just months into 
  the restaurantâ€™s operation, Zorbaâ€™s had yet to turn a profit and various disagreements 
  arose between Appellants and Respondents.Â  In November 1999, Appellants withheld 
  the rent money due to a disagreement over Respondentsâ€™ alleged responsibility 
  to correct some problems with the property.Â  The rent was put in an attorneyâ€™s 
  escrow account and eventually paid to Respondents.Â  In December, however, the 
  rent was again withheld due to disagreements between the parties and financial 
  woes. 
In response to the non-payment of rent, 
  Respondents evicted Zorbaâ€™s, Inc. from the premises by changing the locks on 
  the restaurant and threatening Appellants with criminal prosecution if they 
  attempted entry.Â  After a short and ill-fated attempt by Respondents to operate 
  their own restaurant on the premises, the restaurant, its good-will, and all 
  its equipment was sold to another restaurant for $75,000.Â  The purchasing restaurant 
  also entered into a five-year lease with Respondents for the retail space.
Appellants brought an action individually and as 
  a derivative suit on behalf of Zorbas, Inc. against Respondents and Zorbaâ€™s.Â  
  Appellants set forth several causes of action relating to actions of Respondents, 
  including breach of fiduciary duty, unfair trade practices, and misappropriation 
  of corporate assets.Â  Additionally, they brought individual and derivative claims 
  for damages resulting from the alleged conversion of corporate and personal 
  property which was in the restaurant on the date of eviction.Â  Respondents counterclaimed 
  for damages.Â  After hearing exhaustive and often conflicting testimony from 
  the parties, the circuit court ordered any remaining assets of Zorbas be used 
  to pay creditors and then split evenly between Appellants and Respondents. He 
  denied all other claims of both parties.Â  
ANALYSIS
Despite the daunting amount of testimony and evidence 
  presented in the record on appeal, we conclude a strict accounting is necessary 
  to properly answer the questions before this court.Â  While the trial court attempted 
  to allow as much into the record as possible in an effort to preclude remanding 
  the action, there is scant evidence from either party as to the identity and 
  value of the property owned by Zorbaâ€™s, the specific amounts of debt owed, or 
  how the proceeds from the sale of Zorbaâ€™s, its corporate assets, or Appellantsâ€™ 
  personal property were applied to this alleged debt.Â  Although both parties 
  introduced several vague and unspecific valuations, the recordâ€™s lack of particularity 
  leaves this court without the means to determine whether the circuit erred in 
  simply splitting Zorbaâ€™s meager remaining corporate assets.
We deem an accounting necessary to properly 
  determine whether Respondents converted corporate assets to their personal use 
  and whether there is any indication of oppressive or unfairly prejudicial behavior 
  on the part of Respondents.Â  The accounting should detail the contributions 
  by the parties; the identity and value of equipment, furnishings, and other 
  items in Zorbaâ€™s at the time of eviction; the disposal of any property belonging 
  to Zorbaâ€™s; any revenues from the disposal of Zorbaâ€™s property; and Zorbaâ€™s 
  debts, both paid and currently outstanding.Â  As all remaining issues raised 
  on appeal are to some degree intertwined with the factual conclusions to be 
  determined by the strict accounting, we do not address them at this time.Â  Instead, 
  we remand for a strict accounting followed by a full de novo review 
  of all legal and equitable issues.
REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
US Food Services, Employer, and Mac Risk Management,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-510
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  13, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephen Benjamin Samuels, of Lexington, for Appellant.
Ellen H. Goodwin, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Mervin Wilber Hall appeals a 
  circuit court order that affirms the denial of workersâ€™ compensation benefits 
  by his employer US Food Services.Â  We affirm. [1]  
Hall contends he suffered a back injury while on 
  the job.Â  Food Services disputes that.Â  The single commissioner denied Hallâ€™s 
  claim, pointing to his lack of credibility, his failure to carry the burden 
  of proof, and the believability of Food Servicesâ€™ witnesses. Â An appellate 
  panel affirmed the single commissioner. Â The circuit court, in turn, 
  affirmed the appellate panel.
Hall claims he injured his back when he 
  adjusted his seat while driving a company truck. Â An investigation conducted 
  by Food Services, however, showed the seat could not be moved either forward 
  or backward because of a broken handle used to adjust the seat.Â  
 At the hearing before the single commissioner, 
  Hall acknowledged he had sustained a prior back injury when he adjusted a seat 
  on a company bus while employed elsewhere.Â  Hall admitted to having suffered 
  other prior back injuries as well, but only after Food Services confronted him 
  at the hearing before the single commissioner with medical records. Â Hall 
  failed to report these injuries to the doctors who treated him for the alleged 
  injury that led to the present claim because he â€œdidnâ€™t think [the information] 
  was relevant.â€ 
I.
Hall first argues the circuit court erred in affirming 
  the order of the workersâ€™ compensation commission because the commission failed 
  to make specific and detailed findings of fact.
Findings of fact in a final decision of an administrative 
  body, such as the workersâ€™ compensation commission, must contain â€œa concise 
  and explicit statement of the underlying facts supporting the findings.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-350 (2002).Â  The commission satisfied this requirement here.Â Â  
  See Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 159-160, 519 S.E.2d 
  102, 105 (1999) (holding the findings of the workersâ€™ compensation commission 
  that a claimant did not suffer a work-related injury were sufficient where the 
  commission based its decision on the lack of credibility of the claimant and 
  on the credibility of the employerâ€™s witnesses)
The commission found as a fact that Hall did not 
  sustain any injury by accident arising out of and in the course of his employment.Â  
  Â The â€œconcise and explicit statementâ€ of the underlying facts that support 
  this finding are the following: (1) Hall â€œwas not credible due to inconsistencies, 
  vague answers, and misstatements,â€ and failed â€œto disclose material information 
  until confronted with documentationâ€; (2) Hall gave â€œinconsistent answers in 
  regards to prior injuries,â€ concealed the existence â€œof prior injuries until 
  confronted with . . . medical documentationâ€ reflecting those injuries; and 
  (3) the commission viewed the employerâ€™s witnesses as being â€œcredibleâ€ when 
  they testified Hall said he was going to sue the company â€œif he did not get 
  a new seat in his truck.â€ 
II.
Hall next questions the commissionâ€™s finding that 
  Hall â€œfailed to prove his case.â€Â  He says there is â€œone reasonâ€ for this finding: 
  the commission found Hall â€œwas not a credible witness.â€Â  This statement is not 
  quite correct.Â  The commission also found the employerâ€™s witnesses were credible. 
  As we noted above, these findings are sufficient to support the commissionâ€™s 
  decision.Â  Sharpe, 336 S.C. at 159-160, 519 S.E.2d at 105.Â  Determinations 
  regarding the credibility of witnesses in a workersâ€™ compensation case are singularly 
  for the commission.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 
  438, 442 (2000). 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.

 
   [1]  This case is decided without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Carolyn M. Taylor, a/k/a Carolyn 
  Younns Murphy Taylor, appeals the trial courtâ€™s order denying her motion to 
  set aside a default judgment in favor of BB&T, f/k/a Southern National Bank, 
  asserting the judgment is void for lack of sufficient service of process.Â  We 
  affirm.1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
BB&T filed this action for collection 
  of a consumer debt on May 29, 1998.Â  A process server purported to serve Taylor 
  on June 17, 1998, stating in his affidavit of service that the â€œ[d]ocuments 
  [were] posted on front door after person(s) inside refused to answer door.â€Â  
  On July 17, 1998, BB&T filed an affidavit of default.Â  The Honorable L. 
  Henry McKellar granted BB&T a default judgment on the liquidated debt, costs, 
  and attorneyâ€™s fees totaling $8,926.10 by order filed August 3, 1998.Â  
On July 16, 2004, Taylor filed a motion 
  to vacate the judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP, claiming the court 
  lacked personal jurisdiction in this matter due to insufficiency of service 
  of the summons and complaint.Â  The Honorable Alison R. Lee denied the motion.2 
  This appeal followed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Questions of fact arising on a motion 
  to quash service of process for lack of jurisdiction over the defendant are 
  to be determined by the circuit court.Â  Brown v. Carolina Emergency Physicians, 
  P.A., 348 S.C. 569, 583, 560 S.E.2d 624, 631 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œThe findings 
  of the circuit court on such issues are binding on the appellate court unless 
  wholly unsupported by the evidence or manifestly influenced or controlled by 
  error of law.â€Â  Id.
DISCUSSION
Taylor argues the circuit court erred 
  in finding she was properly served with the summons and complaint.Â  We disagree.
Rule 4(d)(1), SCRCP, provides service may be made 
  as follows:

Upon an individual other than a minor under the age of 14 
  years or an incompetent person, by delivering a copy of the summons and complaint 
  to him personally or by leaving copies thereof at his dwelling house or usual 
  place of abode with some person of suitable age and discretion then residing 
  therein, or by delivering a copy to an agent authorized by appointment or by 
  law to receive service of process. 

Rule 4, SCRCP, serves the dual purposes 
  of conferring personal jurisdiction on the court and assuring the defendant 
  of reasonable notice of the action.Â  Roche v. Young Bros., Inc., 318 
  S.C. 207, 209, 456 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1995).Â  Exacting compliance with the rules 
  is not required to effect service of process.Â  Id. at 209-10, 456 S.E.2d 
  at 899.Â  Rather, inquiry must be made as to whether the plaintiff has sufficiently 
  complied with the rules such that the court has personal jurisdiction of the 
  defendant and the defendant has notice of the proceedings.Â  Id. at 210, 
  456 S.E.2d at 899.Â  The plaintiff has the burden of establishing that the court 
  has personal jurisdiction over the defendant.Â  Moore v. Simpson, 322 
  S.C. 518, 523, 473 S.E.2d 64, 66 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  However, service of process 
  â€œshould not become a game of wiles and tricks and a defendant should not be 
  able to defeat service simply by refusing to accept the papers or by instructing 
  others to reject service.â€ 62B Am.Jur. 2d Process Â§ 204 (1990).
The Georgia Court of Appeals found service 
  was effective when, after the defendantâ€™s wife ordered the process server to 
  leave and closed the door, the process server declared in a voice sufficiently 
  loud enough to be heard that he was leaving the papers at the front door and 
  left after doing so.Â  Jacobson v. Garland, 487 S.E.2d 640 (Ga. Ct. App. 
  1997).Â  The court explained:Â  â€œIt is the duty of a defendant to accept and submit 
  to the service of process when he is aware of the process serverâ€™s purpose.â€Â  
  Id. at 642.Â  
Similarly, the New York Court of Appeals held â€œif 
  the person to be served interposes a door between himself and the process server, 
  the latter may leave the summons outside the door, provided the person to be 
  served is made aware he is doing so.â€Â  Bossuk v. Steinberg, 447 N.E.2d 
  56, 58 (N.Y. 1983).Â  It extended this holding to leaving a copy of the summons 
  outside the door of the person to be served upon the refusal of â€œa person of 
  suitable age and discretionâ€ to open the door to accept it, provided the process 
  server informs the person to whom delivery is being made that this is being 
  done.Â  Id.Â  The court in Bossuk noted that no question had been 
  raised concerning the fact that the children who received service, one 14 and 
  the other 15, were of â€œsuitable age and discretion.â€Â  Id.Â  See also 
  Wood v. Weenig, 736 P.2d 1053, 1055 (Utah Ct. App. 1987) (finding service 
  valid where process server left the summons and complaint on the defendantâ€™s 
  doorstep after a fruitless conversation with a faceless individual inside the 
  residence who had identified herself as the defendantâ€™s daughter and as being 
  of suitable age even though both of the defendantâ€™s daughters denied having 
  spoken to the process server); CRB v. Wyoming, 974 P.2d 931, 935 (Wyo. 
  1999) (finding service of process was proper where after the defendant refused 
  to open his apartment door to accept service, the process server called him 
  while still outside of the apartment and informed him that he had papers to 
  serve on him, and then told him that the process server would leave the papers 
  in the defendantâ€™s mailbox).
In the present case, BB&Tâ€™s process server 
  stated in an affidavit that he made nine visits to Taylorâ€™s residence in his 
  attempt to serve her.Â  On several occasions, he confirmed someone was in the 
  residence, but no one would answer the door.Â  He checked the public records 
  to confirm Taylorâ€™s address and discover what type of vehicle she owned and 
  the vehicleâ€™s license tag number.Â  He returned to Taylorâ€™s residence on June 
  17, 1998 at approximately 4:30 p.m.Â  He noted that Taylorâ€™s vehicle and another 
  vehicle were in the driveway.Â  Once again, although someone was definitely present 
  in the residence, the occupant refused to come to the door.Â  The process server 
  called out his intent to leave the papers and secured the papers to the front 
  door.Â  He averred, â€œI left copies [of the papers] at [Taylorâ€™s] dwelling house 
  and usual place of abode with some person, I believe the Defendant, of suitable 
  age and discretion occupying the premises at that time.â€Â  
BB&Tâ€™s attorney stated in an affidavit 
  that he wrote to Taylor at both addresses for her residence confirming the service 
  and asking her to contact him after the process server left the papers at Taylorâ€™s 
  residence.Â  After the judgment was served on Taylor, he wrote her again at both 
  addresses.Â  He subsequently sought and received an execution against her property.Â  
  The attorney averred that none of the correspondence he sent Taylor was ever 
  returned as improperly addressed or undeliverable.Â  
In her affidavit, Taylor acknowledged that she 
  resided at the residence where the process server left the papers and that the 
  addresses BB&Tâ€™s attorney used were valid addresses for her property.Â  However, 
  she asserted she never received the summons and complaint the process server 
  left at her house on June 17, 1998.Â  She also claimed she never received any 
  of the correspondence from BB&Tâ€™s attorney.Â  Taylor averred the first time 
  she knew of the existence of BB&Tâ€™s action was when she discovered the judgment 
  against her while checking the records in the clerk of courtâ€™s office.Â  
The circuit court held, â€œ[u]nder the circumstances, 
  it cannot be argued that one may avoid service merely by refusing to answer 
  the door, and such avoidance should not be allowed.â€Â  The process server stated 
  he left the summons and complaint at Taylorâ€™s residence with a person of suitable 
  age and discretion, whom he believed to be Taylor.Â  Although Taylor denied receiving 
  the documents, there is evidence in the record to support the trial courtâ€™s 
  conclusion that Taylor was properly served.Â  Accordingly, under our limited 
  standard of review, we hold the trial court did not err in denying Taylorâ€™s 
  motion to set aside the default judgment.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., and CURETON, 
  A.J. concur.Â  

 
  1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
  2 Judge McKellar retired July 31, 2002.
