Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  October 14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
Mac Babb, of Calabash, North Carolina, pro se.
Nina Lee Thompson, of Acton, North Carolina, pro se.
    
  

PER CURIAM: Mac Babb brought this action against Helen W. 
  Thompson and Waterway Mobile Home Park to collect on a default judgment entered 
  against Thompson in 1998.Â  The circuit judge issued an order disposing of Waterwayâ€™s 
  previously impounded funds and allowing Waterwayâ€™s previous attorney to withdraw, 
  as earned fees, money he held in escrow for Waterway.Â  The judge denied Babbâ€™s 
  request for a writ of assistance to assign to him the stock of Waterway and 
  denied Babbâ€™s motions for contempt, sanctions, and punitive damages.Â  The order 
  also affirmed the probate courtâ€™s dismissal of Babbâ€™s petition to open an estate 
  for Thompson.Â  Babb appeals from this order.Â  We affirm. [1] Â  
FACTS
This case arises from a lengthy and complex procedural 
  history.  [2] Â  Babb filed a breach of contract action against 
  Thompson regarding their business relationship.Â  A default judgment was entered 
  against Thompson in the amount of $63,000, plus prejudgment interest.Â  Babb 
  filed this action seeking to collect his judgment.Â  The action was designated 
  a complex case over which Judge J. Michael Baxley presided.Â  During the course 
  of this litigation, Thompson assumed sole ownership of Waterway.Â  Subsequently, 
  and also during the course of litigation, Thompson died in the state of California.Â  
  Thompson and Waterway have insufficient assets to satisfy Babbâ€™s judgment.Â  

Babb filed a 
  petition, as a judgment creditor, to open an estate for Thompson in South Carolina 
  and to be appointed personal representative.Â  The probate court issued an order 
  dismissing Babbâ€™s case due to inactivity and removed the file from the active 
  docket with leave to restore upon good cause shown. Â A letter attached to the 
  order of the probate court stated the reason the file was being closed was because 
  it â€œappears to be defunct in fact and not susceptible to ending by Letters Dismissory.â€Â  

 By a prior order of the circuit judge, Waterwayâ€™s corporate income 
  and accounts, excluding its operating account, were impounded.Â  Additionally, 
  another prior order of the circuit judge released $10,000 from the impounded 
  funds into Waterwayâ€™s operating account.Â  At the time of the final hearing, 
  the impounded funds totaled $71,975.38.Â  Waterwayâ€™s previous attorney, Michael 
  Henthorne, held a sum of money, presumably paid from Waterwayâ€™s operating account, 
  [3]  in his escrow account.Â  
At the final hearing in this action, Babb sought partial satisfaction 
  of his judgment through payment of the impounded funds.Â  Babb also sought a 
  writ of assistance assigning to him all of the stock of Waterway.Â  Further, 
  Babb requested the trial court hold Thompson and Waterway in contempt and asked 
  for sanctions arising from alleged violations 
  [4]  of the courtâ€™s previous orders. Â Babb also requested punitive 
  damages. Â Finally, Babb appealed to the circuit court the probate courtâ€™s 
  dismissal of his petition to open an estate for Thompson.Â  
The circuit judge 
  ordered $2,377 of impounded funds be paid to accountant Harold R. Cooper, for 
  his services as ordered by the court and necessitated by the litigation.Â  As 
  for the remainder of the impounded funds, the judge ordered they be paid to 
  Babb in partial satisfaction of his judgment.Â  The judge also authorized Henthorne 
  to withdraw $4,488 of his outstanding and past due legal fees from his escrow 
  account, finding Henthorneâ€™s work greatly beneficial to the court and to Babb.Â  
  The order denied Babbâ€™s request for a writ of assistance, finding it would not 
  be beneficial and would only generate further litigation.Â  The judge denied 
  Babbâ€™s motion for contempt, stating that he found Thomson and Waterway had substantially 
  complied with the previous orders. The judge also denied Babbâ€™s request for 
  punitive damages.Â  Finally, the judge declined to reverse the probate courtâ€™s 
  order dismissing Babbâ€™s petition to open an estate for Thompson, ultimately 
  concurring with the probate courtâ€™s decision to dismiss the initial filing as 
  inadequate, but noting that Babb had failed to request a rehearing or move to 
  restore the case to the probate court.Â  This appeal followed.
ISSUES

  1.                 
  Whether the trial court erred in providing for payment of Henthorneâ€™s fees;
  2.                 
  Whether the trial court erred in providing for payment of accountant Cooper 
  from the impounded funds;
  3.                 
  Whether the trial court erred in denying Babbâ€™s motion for writ of assistance;
  4.                 
  Whether the trial court had jurisdiction to deny Babbâ€™s motion for punitive 
  damages; and
  5.                 
  Whether the trial court erred in failing to remand to the probate court the 
  issue of the dismissal of Babbâ€™s petition to open an estate for Thompson.

LAW/ANALYSIS
As an initial matter, we note that Babb has provided us with an incomplete 
  record on appeal.Â  For a case with a substantial procedural history, the record 
  in this case is sparse.Â  Significantly, Babb has failed to include in his record 
  a copy of his complaint in this matter.Â  Without this, we can only speculate 
  as to the causes of action under which Babb requested payment of the impounded 
  funds.Â  See Harkins v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 606, 616, 533 
  S.E.2d 886, 891 (2000) (stating the appellant has the burden of presenting a 
  sufficient record to allow review).Â  â€œExcept as provided by Rule 212 and Rule 
  208(b)(1)(C) and (2), the appellate court will not consider any fact which does 
  not appear in the Record on Appeal.â€Â  Rule 210(h), SCACR.Â  Only matters the 
  parties deem not to be relevant to the appeal are properly excluded from the 
  record.Â  See Former v. Butler, 319 S.C. 275, 277 n.1, 460 S.E.2d 
  425, 427 n.1 (Ct. App. 1995). â€œ[T]he South Carolina Appellate Court Rules are 
  not mere technicalities but provide the parties and this Court with an orderly 
  mechanism through which to guide appeals in this State.Â  It is incumbent upon 
  counsel to provide material that complies with the Rules and facilitates appellate 
  review.â€Â  Henning v. Kaye, 307 S.C. 436, 437, 415 S.E.2d 794, 794 (1992).Â  
  See also State v. Burton, 356 S.C. 259, 265, n.5, 589 S.E.2d 
  6, 9 n.5 (2003) (â€œA pro se litigant who knowingly elects to represent 
  himself assumes full responsibility for complying with substantive and procedural 
  requirements of the law.â€);Â  State v. Hollman, 232 S.C. 489, 498, 102 
  S.E.2d 873, 877 (1958) (stating that established rules of procedure are not 
  to be discarded on appeal merely because a party appeared pro se), 
  overruled on other grounds by Stevenson v. State, 335 S.C. 193, 
  516 S.E.2d 434 (1999).Â  In this case, without knowing the causes of action Babb 
  proceeded under to collect the impounded funds, we are unable to determine and 
  apply the proper standard of review.Â Â Â Â Â 
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Payment of attorney's fees
Babb claims the judge erred in providing for payment of attorney 
  Henthorneâ€™s legal fees.Â  Babb asserts Henthorne waived his right to request 
  fees because he failed to appear at the final hearing.Â Â  This issue is not preserved 
  for our review because Babb did not raise it to the circuit judge at the final 
  hearing.Â  Rather, Babb raised this issue for the first time in a Rule 59(e) 
  motion. â€œA party cannot use Rule 59(e) to present to the court an issue the 
  party could have raised prior to judgment but did not.â€Â  Hickman v. Hickman,Â  
  301 S.C. 455, 456, 392 S.E.2d 481, 482 (Ct. App. 1990) (citations omitted). 

To the extent that Babb argues the judge erred in allowing Henthorneâ€™s 
  fees to be paid out of â€œmonies used in the winding up of Waterwayâ€™s affairs,â€ 
  we find this issue not properly before us.Â  Henthorneâ€™s affidavit stated that 
  he accrued his fees in complying with the courtâ€™s order for an accounting and 
  in winding up Waterwayâ€™s corporate affairs.Â  In an unappealed order, the circuit 
  judge found Henthorneâ€™s firm to be a claimant and â€œaccorded [the firm] claimant 
  status to the extent of its unpaid legal and professional fees,â€ amounting to 
  $11,170.68.Â  The order specifically stated that â€œthis court shall consider at 
  a subsequent dispositional hearing whether all or a portion of the [firmâ€™s] 
  fees should be paid from the remaining assets of the corporation over which 
  this court has jurisdiction.â€Â  By another unappealed order of the circuit judge, 
  $10,000 of impounded funds were released to Waterwayâ€™s operating account, which 
  was not impounded, to be used as â€œnecessary for the winding up of Defendant 
  Waterwayâ€™s corporate affairs.â€Â  Babb did not appeal the prior order treating 
  the firm as a claimant or the prior order allowing the operating account to 
  be used for the winding up of Waterwayâ€™s affairs.Â  Thus, these orders became 
  the law of the case.Â  See Brading v. County of Georgetown, 327 
  S.C. 107, 113, 490 S.E.2d 4, 7 (1997).Â  Furthermore, Babb does not contest the 
  fact that Henthorne accrued the fees in winding up Waterwayâ€™s affairs. Therefore, 
  the actions of the circuit judge in allowing Henthorne to treat fees accrued 
  in the winding up of Waterwayâ€™s affairs as earned and permitting Henthorne to 
  withdraw the balance of the escrow account ($4,480.00) are not subject to our 
  review.Â  
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Payment of accountant Cooperâ€™s fees
Babb argues the circuit judge erred in awarding accountant Cooper 
  fees from the impounded funds.Â  Babb does not cite to any authority in support 
  of his proposition.Â  As a result, we deem this issue abandoned on appeal.Â  See 
  First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994).Â  
  However, even if we were to address the merits and apply the broad standard 
  of review for actions in equity, we find Babbâ€™s argument to be without merit.Â  


In an appeal from an action in equity, this Court has jurisdiction 
  to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  However, this broad scope of review does not require an appellate court to disregard 
  the findings below or ignore the fact that the trial judge is in the better 
  position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Moreover, the appellant 
  is not relieved of his burden of convincing the appellate court the trial judge 
  committed error in his findings.Â  

Pinckney v. Warren, 344 S.C. 382, 387-88, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001) 
  (citations omitted). 
We are satisfied and the record demonstrates 
  that Cooperâ€™s work was court ordered and necessitated by this litigation.Â  The 
  following dialogue took place between Babb and the circuit judge:

  
  
    
      The Court:Â 
       All right, is it within you â€“ itâ€™s your position that no other 
  claimant then should receive any [impounded] funds other than you?
    
    
      Mr.
        Babb: 
       Should not be senior, yes, sir.Â  I would think probably based on 
  one of your Orders that Mr. Cooper should be paid.Â  I believe his bill is $3000.00.
    
    
      The Court:Â 
       All right, sir, than other than Mr. Cooper you donâ€™t believe itâ€™s 
  your position that no other claimant should be paid in part and certainly not 
  in whole?Â  In other words, nobody [sic] but the remaining funds go to you other 
  than Accountant Cooper?
    
    
      Mr.
        Babb:
       Thatâ€™s correct . . . .
    
  
  

Babb asserts that he consented to Cooper being paid, but contends 
  that payment should have been made out of the monies in the operating account. [5] Â  The record does not demonstrate 
  that any funds in the operating account were available to pay Cooper.Â  The record 
  does not show the balance of the operating account, nor does the record itemize 
  how the operating account was used in winding up Waterway's affairs.Â  Thus, 
  the equities favor providing payment for Cooperâ€™s services by means of the impounded 
  funds.
3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Writ of assistance
Babb argues the circuit judge erred in denying 
  his motion for a writ of assistance which would assign to him all of the stock 
  of Waterway.Â  Babb does not cite to any authority in support of his proposition.Â  
  As a result, we deem this issue abandoned on appeal.Â  See First Sav. 
  Bank, 314 S.C. at 363, 444 S.E.2d at 514.Â Â  Nonetheless, we also disagree 
  with Babb on the merits of this argument.Â  
 The issuance of a writ of assistance rests 
  in the sound discretion of the trial court.Â Â  See Griggs v. Griggs, 
  205 S.C. 272, Â­Â­Â­274, 31 S.E.2d 505, 505 (1944).Â  The object of a writ of assistance 
  is to take â€œpossession [of property] from a party whose rights have been determined 
  by the suit in which the sale [of property] was ordered.â€Â  Id. at 275, 
  31 S.E.2d at 506 (citation omitted).Â  A writ of assistance is â€œâ€˜issued only 
  when the right is clear and free from doubt â€“ when there is no equity or appearance 
  of equity in defendant, and when the decree, and the sale and proceedings thereunder, 
  are beyond suspicion . . . .â€™â€Â  Id. at 274-75, 31 S.E.2d at 505-06 (quoting 
  5 C.J., Â§4 at 1317).Â  
In this case, the court found that Waterway 
  operated a mobile home park on real property that it did not own.Â  The order 
  stated that Waterway ceased operations and noted that the court had already 
  seized its bank accounts.Â  The order referred to Waterway as an insolvent non-entity.Â  
  In fact, Waterway was dissolved prior to the final hearing on the merits.Â  Because 
  we find support in the record for the circuit judgeâ€™s findings, we hold the 
  circuit judge did not abuse his discretion in declining to issue Babb a writ 
  of assistance.Â  
4.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Punitive damages
Babb argues the circuit judge erred in denying him punitive damages 
  because the judge did not have subject matter jurisdiction over that issue.Â  
  Babb asserts that a prior order of the court, through an agreement of the parties, 
  provided for the issue of punitive damages to be heard by a master-in-equity.Â  
  Babbâ€™s argument to this effect is conclusory and not supported by any authority.Â  
  As a result, this issue is abandoned on appeal.Â  See First Sav. Bank, 
  314 S.C. at 363, 444 S.E.2d at 514.Â  
Moreover, as previously noted, the record in this case is sparse. 
  The record contains the reference of the issue of punitive damages to a master-in-equity, 
  dated March 25, 1998.Â  Despite this order of reference, the issue of punitive 
  damages was raised to the circuit judge at the final hearing.Â  Nothing in the 
  record indicates why this issue was raised at that time.Â  The issue of punitive 
  damages was addressed at the hearing as follows:

  
  
    
      Mr.
        Babb: 
       All right, the last thing is the punitive damages that [sic] Judge 
  Lockemyâ€™s Order of March of 1998 and Iâ€™m not prepared for that today.
    
    
      The
        Court: 
      Well my recollection is is [sic] that issue â€“ well, let me ask 
  you to publish for the record what is the status of that issue.
    
    
      Mr.
        Babb:
       Itâ€™s never been heard.Â  He ruled â€“ it seemed like to me, Iâ€™m going 
  from memory now that you asked that straight question, that itâ€™s to be heard 
  by Judge Cross but youâ€™ve taken jurisdiction.
    
    
      The Court:Â 
       All right, sir, then Iâ€™m going to take that under advisement, too, 
  and weâ€™ll look back in the Orders and again, just as it is somewhat confusing 
  for you, there has been a lot of litigation in this action just while Iâ€™ve been 
  in charge of the complex case and Iâ€™ll have to look back and see just exactly 
  how that issueâ€™s framed and weâ€™ll make a ruling.
    
  
  

 Because this case has an abundant procedural history with which the 
  circuit judge was very familiar, we are reluctant to find a lack of subject 
  matter jurisdiction based on the record before us.Â  As stated above, the record 
  is incomplete, and thus, we are unable to determine why the issue of punitive 
  damages was raised to the circuit judge at the final hearing.Â  Further, we are 
  unable to determine on what grounds the circuit judge would have â€œtaken jurisdiction.â€Â  
  The circuit judge had all the prior orders in the case available to review and 
  determine how the issue of punitive damages was framed.Â  We are not afforded 
  the same luxury and are left only to speculate whether the court had subject 
  matter jurisdiction.Â  The appellant has the burden of presenting a sufficient 
  record to allow review.Â  SeeÂ  Harkins, 340 S.C. at 616, 533 S.E.2d 
  at 891.Â  Because we find Babb has not met this burden, we decline to address 
  this issue on appeal.
5.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Appeal from probate court
Finally, Babb argues that because the 
  circuit court applied inadequate grounds to affirm the dismissal of his probate 
  petition, his appeal should have been remanded to probate court for further 
  determinations. [6]  â€œâ€˜If the proceeding in the probate court is in the nature of 
  an action at law, the [appellate] court may not disturb the probate courtâ€™s 
  findings of fact unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence 
  to support them.â€™â€Â  Macaulay v. Wachovia Bank of South Carolina, N.A., 
  351 S.C. 287, 293, 569 S.E.2d 371, 375, (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Howard v. 
  Mutz, 315 S.C. 356, 361, 434 S.E.2d 254, 257 (1993)). Rule 4 of the South 
  Carolina Rules of Probate Court allow the court to strike a case from the active 
  file with leave to restore upon good cause shown when it appears that the file 
  is â€œdefunct in fact and not susceptible to ending by letters dismissory . . 
  . .â€Â  
In this case, the order states that the 
  reason for dismissal was inactivity in the file, but a letter accompanying the 
  dismissal states the reason based on Rule 4.Â  The circuit court affirmed on 
  the grounds of Rule 4, finding Babbâ€™s initial filing inadequate.Â  The record 
  reveals that Babbâ€™s petition to open an estate for Thompson contained several 
  omissions.Â  Thus, we decline to overturn the circuit judgeâ€™s decision to affirm 
  the probate courtâ€™s dismissal of his petition.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR 
  (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) 
  appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).Â  Further, because we affirm the dismissal 
  of Babbâ€™s petition, there is no reason to remand the issue.Â  However, nothing 
  in this opinion affects Babbâ€™s right to move to restore the petition to the 
  active docket for good cause shown, as provided for in Rule 4 of the South Carolina 
  Rules of Probate Court.Â  
CONCLUSION 
We find Babbâ€™s argument that the circuit judge erred in awarding Henthorne legal 
  fees not preserved for our review and, therefore, decline to address the issue 
  on appeal.Â  We deem Babbâ€™s issues concerning the payment of accountant Cooperâ€™s 
  fees and concerning the writ of assistance abandoned on appeal.Â  Nonetheless, 
  these issues also fail on the merits.Â  Furthermore, Babb has failed to provide 
  to us a sufficient record on appeal to address whether the trial court had subject 
  matter jurisdiction to decide the issue of punitive damages, and thus we decline 
  to address the issue.Â  Finally, we do not find the circuit judge abused his 
  discretion in affirming the decision to dismiss Babbâ€™s petition to open an estate 
  for Thompson in probate court.Â  Therefore, the order of the circuit judge is
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. 

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  Our court has twice before examined this case.Â  
    A more detailed procedural history can be found in the two previous unpublished 
    opinions.Â  Babb v. Thompson, Op. No. 2002-UP-026 (Ct. App. filed Jan. 
    16, 2002) (affirming the default judgment against Thompson, but reversing 
    the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Babb), and 95-UP-195 (Ct. App. filed June 
    28, 1995) (reversing the trial judgeâ€™s denial of Babbâ€™s motions for new trial 
    nisi additur and new trial absolute, finding the juryâ€™s award 
    of $5.00 for his breach of contract claims not supported by the evidence).

 
   [3]  Although not explicitly set forth in the record, 
    this is a logical presumption because the judge ordered this account be used 
    to wind up Waterwayâ€™s corporate affairs and Henthorneâ€™s services were utilized 
    for the purpose of winding up Waterwayâ€™s affairs.Â Â  

 
   [4]  Neither Babbâ€™s complaint nor his motion to hold 
    Thomson and Waterway in contempt appear in the record on appeal. 

 
   [5]  Arguably, this issue is not preserved for our 
    review.Â  Babb did not make this specific argument at the final hearing.Â  The 
    argument is made for the first time in his Rule 59(e) motion.Â  See 
    Hickman, 301 S.C. at 456, 392 S.E.2d at 482 (â€œA party cannot use Rule 
    59(e) to present to the court an issue the party could have raised prior to 
    judgment but did not.â€).Â  However, in light of the confusing manner in which 
    this issue was addressed at the final hearing, Babbâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion may 
    have presented him with the first opportunity to raise this argument.Â  We, 
    therefore, address the equities presented by this issue.Â Â  

 
   [6]  The order dismissing Babbâ€™s petition to open an 
    estate for Thompson provided for â€œleave to restore [the petition] for good 
    cause being shown why the case should be continued as a pending case.â€Â  Instead 
    of moving to restore the case for good cause shown, Babb directly appealed 
    the probate courtâ€™s order to the circuit court.Â  Therefore, his appeal to 
    circuit court was, at best, premature.Â  However, because the judge decided 
    this issue on the merits, we also address the merits of Babbâ€™s argument.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Charlotte Davis and Roy Davis, Jr.,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Barbara Jean Dacus and Unisun Insurance, Defendants
Of whom Barbara Jean Dacus  is the       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Jr., Special Circuit 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-521
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  October 14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James H. Moss, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
E. Mitchell Griffith, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this declaratory 
  judgment action, Charlotte and Roy Davis appeal from the trial courtâ€™s grant 
  of summary judgment in favor of Barbara Jean Dacus.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
Both parties stipulate to the following 
  facts of this case.Â  On November 23, 1998, Dacus was driving the Davises to 
  an appointment in Savannah, Georgia when they were involved in an automobile 
  accident. Dacus, an employee of the South Carolina Department of Social Services, 
  was driving a DSS vehicle and was acting within the course and scope of her 
  employment at the time of the accident.Â  
After the accident, the Davises filed suit 
  against Dacus and DSS, seeking recovery for injuries they sustained.Â  Dacus 
  moved to dismiss the case, arguing the complaint failed to state a cause of 
  action against her because she had immunity under the South Carolina Tort Claims 
  Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-10 to -200 (Supp. 2003).Â  The trial court agreed, 
  stating: â€œThe Defendant Dacus cannot be joined in this action.Â  If there is 
  some possibility of insurance coverage it must be established other than in 
  this law suit [sic].â€ 
Subsequent to that order, the Davises brought 
  this declaratory judgment action, asking the court to declare that Dacusâ€™s liability 
  and underinsured motorist coverage, provided by Unisun, is â€œvalid and binding 
  upon the insurance company and the insured, and requiring the insurance company 
  to pay amounts under the liability provision of the policy or the underinsured 
  motorist provisions of the policy.â€Â  Dacus and Unisun filed a motion for summary 
  judgment, arguing that because Dacus is immune from liability pursuant to the 
  Tort Claims Act, there could be no direct suit against her insurance company.Â  
  The trial court granted the motion.Â  The Davises filed a motion to reconsider, 
  which the trial court denied. This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary 
  judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs 
  the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. 
  Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-115, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  Pursuant to Rule 
  56, SCRCP, summary judgment is proper when â€œthere is no genuine issue as to 
  any material fact and . . . the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a 
  matter of law.â€Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the 
  evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Strother 
  v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 
  121 (1998) (citation omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
 The Davises argue the trial 
  court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Dacus and her insurance 
  company.Â  Specifically, the Davises claim that the Tort Claims Act does not 
  prevent them from recovering under Dacusâ€™s automobile policy because the insurance 
  coverage is based in contract, and contractual liability is expressly excluded 
  from the Act.Â  We disagree.Â  
While section 
  15-78-20(d) of the Tort Claims Act does expressly exclude contractual liability 
  from immunity, there is no contractual relationship between the Davises and 
  Dacus or Unisun.Â  Rather, Dacusâ€™s liability to the Davises, if such liability 
  exists, would sound in tort.Â  However, we agree with the trial court that pursuant 
  to the Tort Claims Act, Dacus cannot be held personally liable for the Davisesâ€™ 
  injuries.Â  
The Tort 
  Claims Act bars civil suits against any employee of the State who is acting 
  within the scope of his or her employment at the time the tort occurs, unless 
  the employeeâ€™s actions constitute actual fraud, actual malice, intent to harm, 
  or a crime involving moral turpitude.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-70(a)-(b).Â  Here, 
  there is no question that Dacus was acting within the scope of her employment 
  when the accident occurred, and there is no assertion that her actions constituted 
  actual fraud, malice, or intent to harm.Â  Thus, Dacus cannot be held personally 
  liable for the injuries the Davises suffered.Â  
Furthermore, as is 
  typical with personal automobile policies, Dacusâ€™s policy with Unisun only covers 
  injuries and property damage for which Dacus is legally responsible. Â Because 
  Dacus cannot be held either personally liable to the Davises or legally responsible 
  for the Davisesâ€™ injuries or property damage, Unisun likewise has no responsibility 
  to the Davises.Â  We therefore find the trial court did not err in granting summary 
  judgment in favor of Dacus and Unisun. 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.Â  

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David B. Crockett,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Carolina First Bank, Defendant and Third Party Plaintiff, David W. Bowers 
        and Kenneth F. Crockett, Third Party Defendants,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-522
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed October 14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Samuel M. Price, Jr., of Newberry, for Appellant.
Edward M. Woodward, Jr., of Columbia and Wallace K. Lightsey 
  and William P. Crawford, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: David B. Crockett brought suit 
  against Carolina First Bank seeking a finding that his signature on stock certificates 
  was a forgery and directing the bank to redeem his shares of stock.Â  The trial 
  court dismissed the case pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, finding the complaint 
  failed to allege facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
In his complaint, Crockett alleged he 
  was the owner of 1,000 shares of stock in Midlands National Bank, which merged 
  in 1995 with Carolina First.Â  He maintained his brother â€œabsconded with [his] 
  legal papers including, but not limited to, the aforementioned shares.â€Â  In 
  July of 1999, Crockett discovered his shares had been redeemed by the bank.Â  
  Crockett claims his brother forged his signature to endorse the shares.Â  Crockettâ€™s 
  complaint states the forged signature was guaranteed by David Bowers, the former 
  President and CEO of Midlands National Bank.Â  The complaint further indicates 
  that Crockett is currently in possession of the original shares and has asked 
  Carolina First to redeem them, but that Carolina First refused. Accordingly, 
  Crockett asks the court to declare that his signature was forged and to require 
  Carolina First â€œto honor the original certificates of stock and redeem the original 
  certificates of stock and pay to [Crockett] the amount wrongfully paid to [Crockettâ€™s 
  brother], his successors or assigns.â€Â  
After answering and filing a third-party 
  complaint, Carolina First moved to dismiss the appeal based on Rule 12(b)(6), 
  SCRCP.Â  Carolina First asserted the complaint failed to set forth a viable claim 
  against the bank because it was not involved in any of the alleged wrongdoing, 
  the claim was barred by the statute of limitations, and Crockett lacked standing 
  to assert liability based on the guaranty pursuant to section 36-8-306 of the 
  South Carolina Code (2003).Â  
The trial court granted the motion to dismiss, 
  finding:Â  (1) the allegations in the complaint did not set forth a legally viable 
  claim; (2) Carolina First was not liable to Crockett under the guaranty; (3) 
  Crockett failed to follow the statutory procedure for dealing with lost or stolen 
  stock certificates under section 36-8-405 of the South Carolina Code (2002); 
  and (4) Crockett was prohibited from bringing a claim against the bank under 
  section 36-8-406 of the South Carolina Code (2002).Â  This appeal followed.Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The trial court may dismiss a claim when 
  the defendant demonstrates the plaintiffâ€™s â€œfailure to state facts sufficient 
  to constitute a cause of actionâ€ in the pleadings filed with the court.Â  Rule 
  12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  â€œThe trial court must dispose of a motion for failure to state 
  a cause of action based solely upon the allegations set forth on the face of 
  the complaint.â€Â  Brown v. Leverette, 291 S.C. 364, 366, 353 S.E.2d 697, 
  698 (1987).Â  â€œThe motion cannot be sustained if facts alleged in the complaint 
  and inferences reasonably deducible therefrom would entitle plaintiff to any 
  relief on any theory of the case.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œAll properly pleaded factual 
  allegations are deemed admittedâ€ for the purpose of considering a motion for 
  judgment on the pleadings.Â  Russell v. Columbia, 305 S.C. 86, 89, 406 
  S.E.2d 338, 339 (1991).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Crockett contends the trial court erred 
  in dismissing his case.Â  We disagree.
Arguably, Crockettâ€™s assertion of liability 
  in his complaint could be characterized as the following three possible causes 
  of action: negligence, conversion, or liability based on David Bowersâ€™ signature 
  guaranty.Â  However, Crockettâ€™s complaint fails to state facts sufficient to 
  constitute any of these causes of action.
To make a claim for negligence, Crockett 
  would need to allege in the complaint that (1) Carolina First owed a duty of 
  care to him, (2) Carolina First breached the duty by a negligent act or omission, 
  (3) Carolina Firstâ€™s breach was the actual and proximate cause of Crockettâ€™s 
  injury, and (4) Crockett suffered an injury or damages.Â  Steinke v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 387, 520 
  S.E.2d 142, 149 (1999).Â  As the trial court found, Crockettâ€™s complaint fails 
  to allege a duty of care Carolina First breached when it redeemed the shares 
  based on an endorsement that was allegedly forged. [2] Â  Accordingly, the complaint does 
  not set forth a claim of negligence.
The complaint also fails to 
  establish a viable claim of conversion against the bank.Â  â€œConversion is the 
  unauthorized assumption and exercise of the right of ownership over goods or 
  personal chattels belonging to another.â€Â  Jones v. Equicredit Corp. of S.C., 
  347 S.C. 535, 544-545, 556 S.E.2d 713, 718 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Crane 
  v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs., Inc., 313 S.C. 70, 73, 437 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1993)).Â  
  While Crockett may have a claim of conversion against his brother, he has failed 
  to allege how Carolina First has exercised the right of ownership over his certificates.Â  
  Therefore, Crockett has failed to state a viable claim of conversion.
Finally, the complaint seems to allege 
  Carolina First is liable on the signature guaranty of David Bowers.Â  However, 
  as the trial court noted, section 36-8-306(h) states:Â  

The warranties under this section are made to a person 
  taking or dealing with the security in reliance on the guaranty, and the 
  guarantor is liable to the person for loss resulting from their breach. An indorser 
  or originator of an instruction whose signature, indorsement, or instruction 
  has been guaranteed is liable to a guarantor for any loss suffered by the guarantor 
  as a result of breach of the warranties of the guarantor.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-8-306(h) (2003) (emphasis added).Â  
  Crockett cannot state a claim under this section against Carolina First because 
  the benefit of the guaranty does not run to him.Â Â  
As we cannot deduce a viable 
  legal claim stated in the complaint, we find the trial court properly dismissed 
  the action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP. 
  [3] Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s dismissal is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  In his brief, Crockett contends that the trial court found no duty 
    of care solely because Midlands National Bank had merged into Carolina First.Â  
    He therefore argues that Carolina First assumed all of Midlands National Bankâ€™s 
    liabilities.Â  However, Crockettâ€™s complaint fails to allege any legal duty 
    running between him and either Carolina First or Midlands National 
    Bank.Â  Thus, despite the merger, Crockettâ€™s complaint fails to allege a viable 
    cause of action.

 
   
    [3]  As we affirm based on the failure of the complaint to state a claim 
    under Rule 12(b)(6), we need not address the remaining grounds for dismissal 
    offered by the trial court in the order of dismissal.Â  See Futch 
    v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 
    591, 598 (1999) (ruling that an appellate court need not review remaining 
    issues when disposition of prior issues is dispositive).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lynn Marie Boland,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John Michael Boland,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Berry L. Mobley, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-526
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  October 18, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John R. Ferguson, of Laurens, for Appellant.
John J. Sherrill, of Surfside Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Wife appeals the family courtâ€™s 
  order of equitable distribution, arguing the court erred in the identification, 
  valuation, and division of marital property and in failing to award her attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
The parties married in 1969.Â  After separating 
  in 1987, they divided their assets by agreement.Â  Under the agreement, Wife 
  received the partiesâ€™ home in Florida and Husband received a farm they owned 
  in Kentucky.Â  
The parties reconciled several years later.Â  After resuming 
  their relationship, Husband created a trust for the purpose of avoiding probate.Â  
  The trust named Husband and Wife as the beneficiaries and designated Husband 
  the trustee with extensive powers over the trust assets.Â  The parties placed 
  vehicles, savings accounts, and other property in the trust.Â  The parties also 
  signed a deed placing the Kentucky farm Husband received in the separation agreement 
  into the trust.Â  However, as to the Florida home Wife received in the separation 
  agreement, Husband twice prevented Wife from placing proceeds traceable from 
  the sale of that property into the trust.Â  
The parties separated again in 2001.Â  Wife filed 
  for separate maintenance and support and Husband counterclaimed for the same.Â  
  Neither party filed for a divorce.Â  At the hearing, the main issues were the 
  Kentucky farm, the incomes of the parties, and whether Husband should continue 
  health insurance coverage for Wife.Â  At the end of the hearing, the family court 
  granted each party two weeks to submit proposed orders.Â  Husband sent his order 
  to the court without sending a copy to Wife, and the court signed the order 
  before the end of the two weeks and before receiving Wifeâ€™s proposed order.Â  

Among other things, the court found the Kentucky 
  farm was not marital property and divided the marital property equally, though 
  it used Husbandâ€™s date of hearing valuations for some of his assets rather than 
  his date of separation valuations.Â  The court also denied Wifeâ€™s request for 
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Wife moved for reconsideration, which the court denied.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find 
  facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. 
  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  
  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family 
  courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 
  616, 617 (1981).Â  Nor does it require us to ignore the fact that the trial judge, 
  who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their 
  credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Miles v. Miles, 
  355 S.C. 511, 516, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied 
  (June 14, 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Issuance of Final Order
 Wife contends the final order should be 
  vacated because the trial court signed Husbandâ€™s proposed order prior to receiving 
  and reviewing Wifeâ€™s proposed order and because its submission constituted an 
  ex parte communication.Â  We disagree.
Wife cites several cases for the proposition 
  that a ruling cannot be issued without a party being given the opportunity to 
  be heard by the court in a meaningful way.Â  See, eg., Universal Benefits, 
  Inc. v. McKinney, 349 S.C. 179, 561 S.E.2d 659 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Even though 
  the court ruled without reviewing her proposed order, Wife nevertheless had 
  a meaningful opportunity to be heard.Â  She had a full hearing to address her 
  claims and offer any evidence she wished to have considered.Â  
Wife also asserts the ex parte nature 
  of Husbandâ€™s proposed order violated Rule 3.5 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, 
  Rule 407, SCACR.Â  Rule 3.5 states:Â  â€œA lawyer shall not . . . [c]ommunicate 
  ex parte with [a judge] except as permitted by law.â€Â  Rule 3.5 was established 
  to prevent any improper influence of judges, jurors or other officials.Â  Although 
  we do not condone ex parte communication, the transmittal letter and the requested 
  proposed order certainly did not improperly influence the court.Â  
Moreover, Wife raised these and other arguments 
  in her motion to reconsider, which the court denied after review.Â  For the reasons 
  discussed, we find no basis for vacating the family courtâ€™s final order.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Kentucky Property
Wife contends the trial court erred in 
  failing to include the Kentucky property in the marital estate.Â  We disagree.
The South Carolina Code defines marital property, 
  which is subject to equitable distribution, as â€œall real and personal property 
  which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned 
  as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2003).Â  The statute also provides certain exceptions, 
  including â€œproperty excluded by written contract of the parties.â€Â  Â§ 20-7-473(4).Â  

Nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital 
  property if it (1) becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable, 
  (2) is jointly titled, or (3) is utilized by the parties in support of the marriage 
  or in some other manner so as to evidence the partiesâ€™ intent to make it marital 
  property.Â  Pool v. Pool, 321 S.C. 84, 88, 467 S.E.2d 753, 756 (Ct. App. 
  1996), affâ€™d as modified, 329 S.C. 324, 494 S.E.2d 820 (1998).Â  â€œTransmutation 
  is a matter of intent to be gleaned from the facts of each case.â€Â  Id.Â  
  The spouse claiming transmutation must produce objective evidence showing that 
  during the marriage the parties themselves regarded the property as the common 
  property of the marriage.Â  Id.
Husband became the sole owner of the Kentucky 
  property by way of the 1987 separation agreement.Â  Wife does not dispute this, 
  but contends their subsequent reconciliation abrogated the agreement or that 
  the property was transmuted when it was placed into the family trust.
The partiesâ€™ reconciliation did not abrogate 
  the property settlement the parties reached in their 1987 separation.Â  An inherently 
  executory provision of a separation agreement, such as one for future support, 
  is abrogated by a reconciliation.Â  Bourne v. Bourne, 336 S.C. 642, 645-46, 
  521 S.E.2d 519, 521 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  However, any executed property settlement 
  provisions are unaffected by a subsequent reconciliation, except to the extent 
  the property has increased in value because of the partiesâ€™ joint efforts.Â  
  Id.Â  Because the parties executed the property division provided for 
  in the 1987 separation agreement, the property settlement was not affected by 
  their reconciliation.
Additionally, the evidence does not support Wifeâ€™s 
  claim of transmutation.Â  Although the Kentucky property was placed in the trust 
  with marital property, it never became untraceable.Â  Furthermore, the property 
  never generated any real income used to support the family or to pay debts of 
  the parties.Â  Although the trust gave Wife the authority to control the property, 
  she admitted Husband controlled the trustâ€™s assets.Â  Both parties testified 
  it was Husbandâ€™s idea to create the trust, and he testified the main purpose 
  was to avoid probate in the event of his death.Â  Finally, even though Husband 
  had Wife sign a deed to transfer the Kentucky property to the trust, that deed 
  was ineffective because Wife had executed a quitclaim deed as a result of the 
  1987 separation agreement.Â  See Graniteville Co. v. Williams, 
  209 S.C. 112, 120, 39 S.E.2d 202, 206 (1946) (finding deed signed by party without 
  claim to title of property was ineffective). Â Because we find Wife failed to 
  produce objective evidence the parties treated the farm as their common property, 
  we find the family court properly excluded it from the marital estate.
III.Â Â Â  Inclusion or Exclusion of Other Property
Wife contends the family court improperly 
  included her income, clothing, and jewelry without also including the full amount 
  of Husbandâ€™s income, clothing, and jewelry.Â  Wife also contends Husband improperly 
  sold bonds despite being enjoined from disposing of assets.Â  We disagree.
Husband testified the value he listed 
  for his furnishings also included his clothing and jewelry.Â  Although he was 
  only awarded $1,000 in furnishings, and Wifeâ€™s valuation of Husbandâ€™s clothing 
  and jewelry totaled $1,500, we cannot say the court abused its discretion, nor 
  did the failure to specifically delineate the clothes and jewelry lead to an 
  unfair award.Â  
Wife contends the trial court erred in 
  failing to properly include income earned by Husband or in including her income 
  at a gross value and his at its net value.Â  Additionally, she asserts his gambling 
  winnings should be added to the equitable distribution.Â  We disagree.
The partiesâ€™ incomes post-filing should 
  not have been included for purposes of equitable distribution.Â  See S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2003) (providing â€œterm â€˜marital propertyâ€™ as used 
  in this article means all real and personal property which has been acquired 
  by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing 
  or commencement of marital litigationâ€).Â  Although Wife is correct that her 
  income was improperly included in the marital estate, Husbandâ€™s income from 
  the date of filing until the date of the order was also improperly included.Â  
  As Wifeâ€™s income was included at approximately $11,000 and Husbandâ€™s was included 
  at approximately $65,000, any error benefited Wife and she is thus entitled 
  to no relief. Â 
The evidence in the record is inconclusive as to 
  when the gambling winnings occurred.Â  However, there is no evidence in the record 
  that any sum existed at the time of filing.Â  If the winnings occurred after 
  filing, they constitute earnings and are not subject to equitable distribution.Â  
  For either reason, the trial court properly excluded gambling proceeds from 
  equitable distribution.
As for the bonds, they were redeemed by the issuer 
  and Husband had no way to prevent their redemption.Â  Additionally, Wife did 
  not establish that either the bonds or their proceeds were marital property 
  subject to division.Â  
IV.Â Â Â  Valuation of Marital Estate
Wife asserts the family court improperly valued 
  the property in the marital estate.Â  She maintains Husbandâ€™s IRA and investment 
  accounts were valued at the time of the hearing and not at the time of separation 
  as required.Â  She asserts it was error for the trial court to value his property 
  at the time of the hearing and her property at the time of separation.Â  We affirm 
  the value assigned by the family court.
As stated above, â€œmarital propertyâ€ includes â€œall 
  real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the 
  marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital 
  litigation.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473.Â  Thus, for purposes of equitable distribution, 
  the value of marital property is the value of the property at the time of the 
  commencement of the marital litigation.Â  See Mallett v. Mallett, 
  323 S.C. 141, 151, 473 S.E.2d 804, 810 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œMarital property is 
  valued as of the date of the filing of the complaint.â€).Â  However, where necessary 
  to avoid an unfair apportionment caused by significant changes in the valuation 
  of marital property during marital litigation, the court may â€œconsider the post-filing 
  appreciation or depreciation when valuing and apportioning the marital estate.â€Â  
  Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C. 222, 228, 512 S.E.2d 539, 542 (Ct. App. 1999).
Here, Husband provided the court with 
  updated values of his investment accounts due to the recent market decline.Â  
  The reduction in value was not caused by an intentional depletion of assets 
  or any fault of Husband.Â  The accounts declined along with the market, and Husband 
  should not be penalized for the measurable decline.Â  Accordingly, the court 
  did not err in using the updated values of Husbandâ€™s accounts.Â  Because Wife 
  failed to provide updated values of her accounts, it is impossible to determine 
  whether any change in her accounts occurred.Â  
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Apportionment of Marital Estate
Wife also challenges the courtâ€™s division 
  of the marital estate.Â  She asserts the equitable distribution should be adjusted 
  because Husband retained the Kentucky farm as non-marital property.Â  She also 
  asserts Husband improperly elected to receive higher pension payments during 
  his life rather than lower lifetime payments that would continue after his death.Â  
  We find the courtâ€™s apportionment fair and proper.
The apportionment of marital property 
  is within the family courtâ€™s sound discretion.Â  Morris v. Morris, 295 
  S.C. 37, 39, 367 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988).Â  Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina 
  Code enumerates fifteen factors applicable to a determination of equitable distribution.Â  
  The statute vests the family court with discretion to decide what weight should 
  be assigned to the various factors.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2003).Â  
  On review, this court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment, and 
  if the end result is equitable, the fact this court might have weighed specific 
  factors differently than the family court is irrelevant.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 
  296 S.C. 289, 300-01, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  This court will 
  affirm the family courtâ€™s apportionment of marital property where the court 
  addressed the factors with enough sufficiency for us to conclude the family 
  court was cognizant of the statutory factors.Â  Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 
  502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 859 (Ct. App. 1996).
 Both parties sought an equal division 
  of the marital property.Â  Wife knew the status of the Kentucky property was 
  an issue before the court and still argued for an equal division of the marital 
  assets.Â  The court stated that after â€œreflecting upon all the factors set forth 
  within Section 20-7-472 . . . that the intention, and thus agreement, of both 
  parties to divide all marital property on a 50/50 basis should be accepted.â€Â  
  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly considered the factors and the 
  testimony of the parties.Â  We find the equal division of the marital assets 
  a fair result and thus not an abuse of discretion.Â  Nor do we find Husbandâ€™s 
  pension electionâ€”a joint decision made by the parties while they were married 
  and before commencement of this actionâ€”a basis for adjusting the overall award.Â  

VI.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife asserts the family court erred in failing 
  to award her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We do not agree.
The decision whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees is 
  a matter within the family courtâ€™s sound discretion.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).Â  In determining whether to award 
  attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their 
  own fees, the beneficial results obtained by the attorney, the partiesâ€™ respective 
  financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of 
  living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 
  (1992).
The family court properly considered the appropriate 
  factors and concluded neither party was entitled to recover attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
  Although the family court may have improperly imputed the ability to continue 
  to earn income to the Wife, it is undisputed her income will be similar to Husbandâ€™s, 
  as they will divide his pension equally.Â  Additionally, the results obtained 
  were not more beneficial to one party than the other, and both parties received 
  the same amount of marital assets from which to pay their fees.Â  Finally, the 
  award of attorneyâ€™s fees will impact each partyâ€™s standard of living in roughly 
  the same manner.Â  Accordingly, we hold the trial court did not abuse its discretion 
  in denying attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  
    Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Miriam B. Vallentine,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jack B. Vallentine, III,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County"
Anne Gue Jones, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-529Â Â Â 
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 20, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Cynthia Bailey Berry, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
John G. Felder and Bates N. Felder, both of St. Matthews, 
  for Respondent.
Sean Paul Thornton, of Walterboro, for Guardian ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The family court granted Miriam 
  Vallentine a divorce from Jack Vallentine on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous 
  separation and equitably apportioned the partiesâ€™ marital assets.Â  As part of 
  the apportionment, the court granted Mr. Vallentine sole ownership and possession 
  of the home the parties resided in and three surrounding acres, as well as a 
  fifteen-acre tract and a twenty-two-acre tract, but ordered him to pay Mrs. 
  Vallentine $58,330.00 for her interest in these assets.Â  Mr. Vallentine appeals, 
  arguing the court erred in finding the home and three acres, which he had inherited, 
  had been transmuted into marital property that was subject to equitable apportionment.Â  
  We affirm.  [1] 
FACTS
The Vallentines were married on August 2, 1971.Â  
  Both parties are in good health.Â  Mr. Vallentine has a reliable job that has 
  contributed to the accumulation of marital assets.Â  His income is more than 
  four times that of Mrs. Vallentine.Â Â Â  
Mrs. Vallentine performed most of the household 
  duties and childcare throughout the marriage.Â  The partiesâ€™ youngest child, 
  Jeffery, was born with Downâ€™s syndrome on July 10, 1985.Â  Mrs. Vallentine spent 
  the majority of her time at home caring for their special-needs child since 
  his birth.Â  The court noted this was a marital decision by the parties.Â Â Â  
For the majority of their marriage, the 
  Vallentines lived in a home owned by Mr. Vallentineâ€™s grandmother and for which 
  they paid her rent when she moved to a nursing home.Â  The Vallentines raised 
  their three children there.Â  Mr. Vallentine inherited the house and the three 
  surrounding acres when his grandmother died.Â  
While living at the home, in addition to providing 
  continuous care to their special-needs child, Mrs. Vallentine worked to improve 
  the appearance of the property.Â  She planted a variety of flowers in the yard 
  and was primarily responsible for the general care and maintenance of the property.Â  
  Mr. Vallentine also worked to improve the house by painting the interior and 
  doing work on the exterior of the home.Â  
The family court found the home where 
  the parties resided and the three surrounding acres had been transmuted into 
  marital property that was subject to equitable apportionment.Â  The court awarded 
  this property to Mr. Vallentine, but ordered him to pay Mrs. Vallentine $58,330.00 
  for her interest in these assets and two other tracts. [2] Â  Mr. Vallentine retained all 
  other real estate held in his name.Â  On appeal, Mr. Vallentine argues the family 
  court erred in finding that the home and three acres was marital property subject 
  to equitable apportionment.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The family court has wide discretion 
  in equitably apportioning marital property, and its decision will not be disturbed 
  on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Murphy v. Murphy, 319 S.C. 
  324, 461 S.E.2d 39 (1995).
â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs 
  when the judge is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based 
  upon findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 
  351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002); see also Stewart v. 
  Floyd, 274 S.C. 437, 265 S.E.2d 254 (1980).
In appeals involving equity actions, including 
  those tried in the family court, an appellate court has authority to find facts 
  in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford 
  v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992).Â  Nevertheless, this 
  broad scope of review does not require an appellate court to disregard the findings 
  of the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position 
  to evaluate their credibility.Â  Strout v. Strout, 284 S.C. 429, 327 S.E.2d 
  74 (1985).
Although inherited property 
  is generally considered a nonmarital asset, it can be transmuted into marital 
  property under certain conditions:

[W]hile property acquired by either 
  party by inheritance from a party other than the spouse is generally considered 
  nonmarital property, nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital property 
  if:Â  (1) it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable; 
  (2) it is jointly titled; or (3) it is utilized by the parties in support of 
  the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties 
  to make it marital property.

Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 
  97, 117, 557 S.E.2d 693, 703 (Ct. App. 2001);Â  see also Hussey v. 
  Hussey, 280 S.C. 418, 312 S.E.2d 267 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Transmutation is 
  a matter of intent, which must be gleaned from the facts of each case.Â  Widman, 
  348 S.C. at 117, 557 S.E.2d at 703-04. 
In this case, the evidence suggests 
  the parties utilized the property in support of the marriage and intended to 
  make the house and three acres marital property.Â  The parties lived in the house 
  during most of their marriage, raised their children in the home, and worked 
  together to maintain and improve the property. 
The parties originally 
  rented a house; however, when Mr. Vallentine inherited the property in question, 
  he proposed that the parties make the inherited property their home.Â  According 
  to Mrs. Vallentine, ever since they were engaged, Mr. Vallentine told her that 
  one day they would live in the house and raise their children there.Â  
Further, Mr. Vallentine testified 
  that Mrs. Vallentine often complained that she did not feel like the inherited 
  property was her own house.Â  He testified, however, that he reassured her that 
  it was her home.Â  
Considering all of the evidence, 
  we find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision to treat the home 
  the parties resided in and the three surrounding acres as marital property and 
  to require Mr. Vallentine to pay his wife a sum for her interest.Â  Accordingly, 
  the order of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOSLBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  This case is decided without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  As noted above, we construe the family courtâ€™s order as requiring 
    the sum to be paid to Mrs. Vallentine for her interest in not only the home 
    and three acres, but for two other tracts of fifteen acres and twenty-two 
    acres.

THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Auto Pro of Goose Creek,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Thomas Barnes,       
Thomas Barnes,
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-532
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  20, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas J. Barnes, of Goose Creek, pro se Appellant.
Walter Bilbro, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Thomas J. Barnes appeals from 
  the circuit courtâ€™s order that affirmed the magistrateâ€™s sale of Barnesâ€™s vehicle 
  to satisfy a mechanicâ€™s lien held by Auto Pro of Goose Creek.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
Barnes experienced mechanical problems with his 
  1995 Cadillac and took it to Auto Pro.Â  Auto Proâ€™s invoice dated January 8, 
  2001 lists various items needing repair at a total cost of $3,747.65.Â  The invoice 
  states a fee of $15 per day would be charged if the vehicle was not picked up 
  within five days of notice of completion.Â  Barnesâ€™s signature appears underneath 
  a preprinted statement on the form indicating that he authorized the repairs.Â  

After Barnes did not pay the repair bill, Auto 
  Pro sent Barnes a Notice of Unclaimed Vehicle [2]  advising him that it would apply for a magistrateâ€™s 
  sale if he did not pay the amount of repair and storage costs due within thirty 
  days.Â  The notice also advised Barnes of his right to seek a hearing within 
  thirty days if he wished to contest the matter.Â  
When Barnes made no request for a hearing, Auto 
  Pro applied to the magistrate for a public sale of the vehicle to satisfy its 
  lien for repair and storage costs pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-15-10 (1991). 
  [3] Â  
The magistrate ordered the vehicle to be sold at 
  a public auction to satisfy the lien.Â  The public sale took place on June 26, 
  2001, but no one appeared on behalf of Barnes.Â  The magistrate ordered the sale 
  of the vehicle to Auto Pro for a stated sales price of $25 in satisfaction of 
  the lien.Â  
Barnes appealed to the circuit 
  court, enumerating eleven issues in his notice of appeal.Â  At the hearing on 
  the appeal, Barnesâ€™s attorney argued two issues:Â  (1) whether the magistrateâ€™s 
  return was defective, and (2) whether Barnes was entitled to a remand to the 
  magistrate because his alleged prior attorney did not receive notice of the 
  proceedings in the magistrateâ€™s court and failed to appear.Â  At the end of the 
  hearing, the circuit court concluded the return was sufficient and Barnes had 
  proper notice of the magistrateâ€™s court proceedings.Â  The circuit court subsequently 
  filed a form order affirming the appeal.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Barnes has filed a pro se 
  brief listing twenty-three alleged errors in his Statement of Issues for this 
  Courtâ€™s consideration.Â  The argument on these issues has been grouped under 
  several headings in the body of his brief.
Initially, we note that, as a reviewing 
  court sitting in an appellate capacity, we may properly consider only those 
  issues that were raised to and ruled upon by the circuit court.Â  See, e.g., 
  Harris v. Bennett, 332 S.C. 238, 245, 503 S.E.2d 782, 786 (Ct. App. 1998) 
  (â€œAs a general rule, an issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal, 
  but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the court below to be preserved 
  for appellate review.â€).Â  
I.
Barnesâ€™s first argument to the circuit 
  court was that the magistrateâ€™s return was defective.Â  Although Barnes does 
  not separately articulate this issue in his brief, we construe his arguments 
  broadly because he is pro se and Auto Pro specifically addresses 
  the issue in its Respondentâ€™s Brief.Â  Cf. Greer v. McFadden, 295 
  S.C. 14, 366 S.E.2d 263 (Ct. App. 1988) (stating a point raised by a pro 
  se appellant would be considered, even though it was not a properly framed 
  exception, where it was reasonably clear to the court and the issue was addressed 
  by the adverse party).
During the circuit court hearing, Barnes 
  contended the magistrateâ€™s return was defective because the magistrate did not 
  specify all of the evidence that was considered and he did not know what the 
  magistrate had reviewed in reaching a decision.Â  
The circuit court ruled the return was adequate 
  in conjunction with the other documentation provided by the magistrate as contained 
  in the magistrateâ€™s file that was before it on appeal.Â Â Â  
Section 18-7-60 of the South Carolina Code provides 
  a magistrate â€œshall . . . make a return to the appellate court of the testimony, 
  proceedings and judgment and file it in the appellate court.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 18-7-60 (1985).Â  If the circuit court believes the return is defective, it 
  can direct the magistrate to file an amended return.Â  Id. Â§ 18-7-80.Â  
  When the magistrate has submitted a return, it is left to the circuit courtâ€™s 
  discretion whether or not to order an amended return.Â  Lynch v. Heyward, 
  56 S.C. 562, 35 S.E. 220 (1900) (citing predecessor statutes to section 18-7-80). 

In this case, the magistrateâ€™s return 
  stated in pertinent part:

Auto Pro of Goose Creek filed a Public Sale on June 11, 2001 
  for storage and repair for the amount of 6382.65.Â  All appropriate steps in 
  the documentation submitted to [the] court on behalf of Auto Pro was correct, 
  and all procedures were followed legally in obtaining the Magistrateâ€™s Bill 
  of Sale.
The public sale took place on June 26, 2001, and no one appeared 
  for or on the behalf of Thomas Barnes.Â  This court received no letter of representation 
  from any attorneys representing the defendant, nor was any attached to Auto 
  Pro of Goose Creekâ€™s paperwork.
Therefore, considering that all of the procedures were followed 
  correctly and by the statute, this court issued a Bill of Sale on 07-03-2001 
  giving title of the 1995 Cadillac, serial number 1G6KF52Y9SU264548, to Auto 
  Pro of Goose Creek[.]
This court handled everything in the utmost judicial manner.Â  


We agree with the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that the 
  magistrateâ€™s return was sufficient when considered with all of the documents 
  submitted by the magistrate as part of that courtâ€™s file.Â  Among the documents 
  constituting the magistrateâ€™s file was a copy of Auto Proâ€™s invoice, a Notice 
  of Unclaimed Vehicle, a certified return receipt, the magistrateâ€™s notice of 
  sale, and the magistrateâ€™s order of sale.Â  We note this was not a full-blown 
  trial in the magistrateâ€™s court; rather, it was a summary proceeding on a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien under section 29-15-10.Â  Under these circumstances, we find the return 
  was adequate.
II.
The second issue Barnes raised on appeal to the 
  circuit court was his contention that he was entitled to a remand to the magistrate 
  for a new proceeding with an attorney present.Â  Barnesâ€™s appellate counsel advised 
  the circuit court, â€œ[W]eâ€™d ask this Court to remand this back so that Mr. Barnes 
  can be represented by counsel . . . on the grounds that, you know, he did think 
  he had an attorney present but who didnâ€™t show up.Â  Thatâ€™s being taken care 
  of, I believe, in another forum by Mr. Barnes.â€Â  
Counsel for Auto Pro advised the circuit court 
  that, after Auto Pro sent a certified letter to Barnes requesting payment and 
  informing him that storage charges would be incurred, Auto Proâ€™s owner received 
  a telephone call in mid-March 2001 from Kevin Kearse, an attorney, who said 
  he was calling just as a friend of Barnes to see what could be done to resolve 
  the matter.Â  Auto Proâ€™s owner told Kearse that Barnes could just come down and 
  pay the amount due.Â  After Barnes made no payment, Auto Pro sent Barnes a Notice 
  of Unclaimed Vehicle on April 13, 2001, informing him that if payment was not 
  made, it would request that the vehicle be sold in a magistrateâ€™s sale, but 
  that he had thirty days to request a hearing on the matter.Â  Counsel for Auto 
  Pro noted a certified receipt signed by Barnes on April 17, 2001 indicated Barnes 
  had received this notice.Â  Auto Pro thereafter served notice on Barnes of this 
  litigation.Â  Auto Proâ€™s counsel stated he â€œnever received any notice of representation 
  from Mr. Kearse.â€Â  Further, no request for a hearing was ever made by Barnes 
  or any attorney on behalf of Barnes.Â  
In response, Barnesâ€™s appellate counsel argued, 
  â€œWhether he said he was just calling as a friend or not, Mr. Barnes, I think, 
  was justified in relying on -- itâ€™s evident that he had an attorney to speak 
  on his behalf.Â  That attorney failed to show up, and thatâ€™s one of the reasons 
  we ask that this be remanded.â€Â  
After considering the foregoing, the circuit court 
  ruled as follows:Â  â€œI understand the problem and the fact that you [Barnes] 
  werenâ€™t present.Â  However, there is nothing to suggest that notice wasnâ€™t properly 
  given of it, and that you had an opportunity to be present but for whatever 
  reason were not.â€Â  
We find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s ruling 
  in this regard.Â  The magistrate stated in his return that the â€œcourt [had] received 
  no letter of representation from any attorneys representing [Barnes], nor was 
  any attached to Auto Pro of Goose Creekâ€™s paperwork.â€Â  Further, Kearse apparently 
  never represented himself to be Barnesâ€™s attorney and did not put in an appearance 
  on his behalf, and Barnes presented no documentation to the circuit court that 
  Kearse was, in fact, ever his attorney of record.Â  Accordingly, we conclude 
  Auto Pro was not required to serve Kearse with notice and Barnes is not entitled 
  to a remand for new proceedings.Â  See generally Culbertson v. Clemens, 
  322 S.C. 20, 471 S.E.2d 163 (1996) (noting it is important to the parties and 
  the court that the correct attorneys are listed as the attorneys of record and 
  stating any changes should be noticed to the court under Rule 11(b), SCRCP).Â  
  Moreover, the fact that Barnes believed an attorney would be present does not 
  invalidate any notice that was sent to him.Â Â Â  
To the extent Barnes further argues to this Court 
  that he personally was never given notice of the magistrateâ€™s court proceedings, 
  we find this issue is not preserved as he did not argue this point to the circuit 
  court.Â  Barnes did not dispute at the circuit court hearing that he had received 
  notice; rather, he only argued that he was not present at the magistrateâ€™s court 
  proceedings because he thought he had an attorney who would be present to represent 
  him.Â  See Harris, 322 S.C. at 245, 503 S.E.2d at 786 (stating 
  an issue must be raised to and ruled on by the court below to be preserved for 
  further review).Â  
III.
Lastly, Barnes raises several arguments concerning 
  the circuit courtâ€™s conduct in holding a hearing to determine which documents 
  it considered in making its ruling.Â Â  
During the docketing of the appeal with this Court, 
  a dispute arose between the parties regarding which documents could be designated 
  for inclusion in the record on appeal.Â  We ordered a remand to the circuit court 
  for it to identify which documents it considered because only documents that 
  were presented to the circuit court could properly be included in the record 
  on appeal under the South Carolina Appellate Court Rules.Â  See Rule 210(c), 
  SCACR.
The circuit court thereafter held a hearing to 
  reconstruct which documents were submitted to it for the appeal, during which 
  it relied on a transcript of the proceedings, as well as input from the parties.Â  

Although Barnes now contends the circuit court 
  erred in conducting a hearing, we find no error in this regard.Â  The court merely 
  reconstructed the record since it did not have the original magistrateâ€™s court 
  file.Â  The court explained that the original magistrateâ€™s court file could not 
  be located, but it had the clerkâ€™s file containing copies of the documents that 
  were presented at the appeal.Â  The court stated the magistrateâ€™s court apparently 
  had retained the original file and sent the circuit court a copy of its file 
  for the appeal.Â  
While Barnes stated at the hearing that he objected 
  â€œto all of the records that are being spoke about today,â€ he participated in 
  the document review without contemporaneously objecting to the manner of the 
  proceedings.Â  Further, most of his arguments to the circuit court concerned 
  the allegation that his attorney had been ineffective in failing to object to 
  the documents at the original hearing before the circuit court.Â  To the extent 
  Barnes additionally contends the documents were inappropriately considered by 
  the circuit court because they were submitted by counsel for Auto Pro, we find 
  the transcript refutes this assertion as the circuit court indicated the documents 
  it possessed did not come from the parties, but instead were previously supplied 
  by the magistrateâ€™s court.Â  Â Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.Â  We note the case caption has been amended to name Auto Pro of Goose 
    Creek as the first party since it instituted the original action as plaintiff 
    against the defendant Barnes.Â  This also corresponds to the caption on the 
    notice of appeal to the circuit court.Â  It appears the caption was inadvertently 
    reversed during the appeal to the circuit court.

 
   
    [2] Â  The typewritten date at the top of the Notice is May 4, 2001, but 
    during a hearing in this matter counsel for Auto Pro stated, without contradiction, 
    that the Notice was sent on April 13, 2001 and a certified return receipt 
    showed Barnes received it on April 17, 2001.Â  There is a certified return 
    receipt in the record with a date of either April 11 or April 17 (part of 
    the number overlaps a preprinted portion of the form).Â  

 
   
    [3] Â  Section 29-15-10 was amended after this case arose in 2001.Â  See 
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-15-10 (Supp. 2003).Â  The amendment does not affect this 
    appeal.
