THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Sylvia Harrington, Claimant,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Hopewell Health Care Center, Employer and
RSKCo., Carrier,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-533
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  20, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Stephen B. Samuels, of Sumter, for Appellant.
Ellen H. Goodwin, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation 
  case, Sylvia Harrington appeals the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s 
  denial of her Form 15 request for a hearing to determine whether she was entitled 
  to further temporary compensation payments.Â  We reverse and remand. 
  [1] 
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Harrington worked as a nursing assistant 
  to the Hopewell Health Care Center.Â  On November 11, 2001, she sustained a compensable 
  injury to her left hand while turning a patient.Â  Although Hopewell accepted 
  her claim and paid medical benefits, Harrington missed no time from work as 
  a result of this injury.
Harrington re-injured her left hand on 
  April 4, 2002, when a patient sat on her hand while she was placing the patient 
  into a wheelchair.Â  In addition to medical treatment for this injury, 
  Hopewell paid Harrington temporary total disability compensation.Â  It 
  appears undisputed that (1) Harrington began receiving temporary total disability 
  compensation on April 11, 2002; (2) Harrington was released by her treating 
  physician on September 9, 2002, to return to work in a regular and full duty 
  capacity; and (3) Hopewell paid no temporary total disability compensation 
  after September 25, 2002.
On January 9, 2003, Harrington, 
  through her attorney, filed a Form 15 with the Commission contesting the termination 
  of her total disability compensation and requesting a hearing to determine whether 
  she was entitled to have these benefits continue.Â  On January 14, 2003, 
  the Commission advised Harringtonâ€™s attorney in writing that Harrington was 
  not entitled to a hearing.Â  The Commission stated it was denying the request 
  because the date Hopewell terminated benefits was â€œoutside the 150 day rule.â€Â  

On February 13, 2003, Harrington appealed 
  the denial of her hearing request to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court heard 
  arguments in the matter on March 11, 2003.Â  On July 14, 2003, the circuit 
  court filed an order dismissing Harringtonâ€™s appeal.Â  In support of the dismissal, 
  the circuit court determined (1) the Commissionâ€™s letter of January 14, 2003, 
  denying Harringtonâ€™s request for a hearing was not a final decision; (2) the 
  Commissionâ€™s refusal to schedule a Form 15 hearing did not amount to a deprivation 
  of Harringtonâ€™s due process rights; and (3) Harrington failed to exhaust her 
  administrative remedies.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Harrington first contends 
  the circuit court erred in finding she failed to exhaust her administrative 
  remedies.Â  In support of this position, she argues that her use of Form 15 to 
  contest the termination of her benefits was proper and therefore an exhaustion 
  of her administrative remedies.Â  We agree.
Under administrative regulation 
  67-207, a claimant may request a hearing by filing â€œa Form 15, Form 50, or 
  Form 52 with the Commissionâ€™s Judicial Department.â€ 
  [2] Â  Here, Harrington had filed a Form 15 with the Commission and indicated, 
  through the signature of her attorney in the appropriate space on the form, 
  that she did not agree with the termination of temporary compensation and was 
  requesting a hearing on the matter.Â  Even though, as the circuit court noted, 
  there may have been other means, such as a motion or petition or another form, 
  to request a hearing, the applicable administrative regulation requires that 
  she avail herself of only one of several enumerated methods.Â  It does not require 
  that she resort to the other methods if the first method does not yield the 
  desired result. [3] 
2.Â  We further agree with 
  Harrington that the Commissionâ€™s denial of her Form 15 request violated the 
  procedural provisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  
South Carolina Code section 
  42-9-260 governs the procedure for suspending or terminating temporary disability 
  payments. [4] Â  Under paragraph (A) of this statute, an employer 
  may continue temporary disability payments â€œfor up to one hundred fifty days 
  from the date the injury . . . is reported without waiver of any grounds for 
  good faith denial.â€ [5] Â  Within this one-hundred-fifty-day period, 
  the payments may be terminated or suspended immediately under certain conditions. [6] 
Pursuant to paragraph (F) 
  of section 42-9-260, [7]  the Commission has adopted administrative regulation 
  67-505, which governs the procedure for terminating or suspending temporary 
  disability payments after the one-hundred-fifty-day period has expired.Â  If 
  an employer wants to suspend or terminate temporary total disability after one 
  hundred fifty days without the claimantâ€™s consent, it must file a Form 21 to 
  request a hearing on the matter. [8] 
Under section 42-9-260(C), 
  a claimant whose disability payments have been terminated may request a hearing 
  within sixty days for reinstatement of these benefits. 
  [9] Â Â  This remedy is available whenever the â€œdisability payments have been 
  terminated or suspended pursuant to this section.â€ [10] Â  It does not matter whether the employer ceased making payments 
  within the first one hundred fifty days after the injury or after that period 
  of time has elapsed.Â  
It appears that the Commission, 
  in denying Harringtonâ€™s hearing request, placed undue emphasis on section II 
  of Form 15.Â  This section is used solely by the employer to unilaterally terminate 
  temporary disability compensation within the first one hundred fifty days after 
  receiving notice of the injury.Â  Consistent with section 42-9-260, the time 
  limit plainly refers only to the use of section II. 
  [11] Â  
Harrington, however, used 
  section III of Form 15 and, as expressly stated in this part of the form, the 
  signature of her attorney in this section indicated that she did not agree with 
  the termination of temporary compensation and was requesting a hearing to determinate 
  whether she was entitled to further temporary compensation payments.Â  Nowhere 
  on Form 15 is there any prohibition against using section III after one hundred 
  fifty days following notice to the employer of a work-related injury. 
  [12] Â  
CONCLUSION
The letter from the Commission 
  denying Harringtonâ€™s request for a hearing was a final order and subject to 
  judicial review.Â  We further hold the Commissionâ€™s denial of Harringtonâ€™s Form 
  15 request for a hearing on her entitlement to continuation of her temporary 
  disability compensation violated the procedures mandated by section 42-9-260. 
  [13] Â  We therefore reverse the circuit court and remand this case to the 
  Commission for a Form 15 hearing.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and 
  WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-207 (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).

 
   
    [3]  See 73 C.J.S. Public Administrative Law and Procedure 
    Â§ 39 n.80, at 459 (1983) (â€œExhaustion of remedies does not refer to reapplication 
    to the same council or board for an alternative form of relief from an already 
    promulgated adverse and final decision, especially when such suggested action 
    would be futile or useless.â€).Â  We further disagree with Respondentsâ€™ argument 
    that the letter Harrington received from the Commission denying her request 
    for a hearing â€œdoes not constitute a final order of that body.â€Â  See 
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-350 (1986) (stating the requirements for a â€œfinal decision 
    or order adverse to a party in a contested caseâ€); id. Â§ 1-23-360 (recognizing 
    that â€œmembers or employees of an agencyâ€ may be â€œassigned to render a decision 
    or to make findings of fact and conclusions of law in a contested caseâ€); 
    73A C.J.S. Public Adminstrative Law and Procedure Â§ 147, at 120 (1983) 
    (acknowledging that â€œan administrative order need not be in any particular 
    formâ€ as long as it complies with statutory requirements).

 
   
    [4] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-260 (Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [5] Â  Id. Â§ 42-9-260(A).

 
   
    [6] Â  Id. Â§ 42-9-260(B).

 
   
    [7] Â  Id. Â§ 42-9-260(F).

 
   
    [8] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-505 (Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [9] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-260(C) (Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [10]  Id. (emphasis added).

 
   
    [11]  See id. Â§ 42-9-260(B) (stating the conditions under 
    which an employer may terminate or suspend temporary disability payments within 
    one hundred fifty days after such payments have begun).

 
   
    [12]  We reject Respondentsâ€™ argument that Harringtonâ€™s delay of more 
    than sixty days after the termination of her temporary total benefits renders 
    her argument moot.Â  The date of the hearing request controls, not the date 
    the benefits are stopped.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-260(C) (Supp. 
    2003) (â€œAn employee whose disability payments have been terminated or suspended 
    pursuant to this section may request a hearing to have the payments reinstituted.Â  
    The hearing must be held within sixty days of the date of the employeeâ€™s 
    request for a hearing.â€) (emphasis added).

 
   
    [13]  We do not address the issue of whether the Commissionâ€™s denial of 
    a hearing amounted to a deprivation of Harringtonâ€™s constitutional right to 
    due process.

Appellant.

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster;Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Phillip Jackson was indicted 
  for murder.Â  He was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.Â  Jackson 
  appeals.Â  
Pursuant to Anders v. California, 
  386 U.S. 738 (1967), counsel for Jackson attached to the final brief a petition 
  to be relieved as counsel, stating he had reviewed the record and concluded 
  Jacksonâ€™s appeal is without legal merit sufficient to warrant a new trial.Â  
  Jackson filed a separate pro se response.Â  
 After a thorough review of the record 
  and the pro se response pursuant to Anders and State 
  v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal 
  and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.Â  
 APPEAL DISMISSED. [1] 
 STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services/Helen
Fleisig, Plaintiffs,
of whom Helen Fleisig is Respondent,
v.
Richard Fleisig, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-535
Submitted February 11, 2004 â€“ Filed October 21, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
James H. Moss, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
Ralph E. Tupper, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  Richard Fleisig (Husband) 
  appeals a ruling of the family court ordering him to pay $57,600 in unpaid alimony 
  to Helen Fleisig (Wife).Â  We reverse. 
  [1] 
BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife married in New Jersey in 1963 and were granted a divorce in 
  South Carolina in 1990.Â  The family court granted Wife child support and $400 
  per month rehabilitative alimony for a period of sixty months.Â  Wife appealed, 
  and this court modified the alimony to permanent periodic payments of $600 per 
  month.Â  Fleisig v. Fleisig, 93-UP-0061 (S.C. Ct. App. Mar. 8, 1993).Â  

According to Wifeâ€™s testimony, Husband moved around a lot after the divorce, 
  never paid the ordered alimony, and later quit paying the child support. Â Husband 
  claims no notice or knowledge of this courtâ€™s opinion modifying his alimony 
  obligation, but asserts he timely paid all of the rehabilitative alimony ordered 
  by the family court. Â 
Shortly after this courtâ€™s opinion, Wife moved to her family home in Mississippi. 
  Â She was diagnosed with cancer in 1997 and spent a large portion of the 
  next three years hospitalized and in a physically and financially disadvantaged 
  condition.Â  Nevertheless, Wife claimed that before, during, and after this ordeal, 
  efforts were made to secure payment of the alimony and child support.Â  She contacted 
  several attorneys, one of whom agreed to take her case only to later refuse 
  it. [2] Â  She contacted legal aid and 
  the police several times in both South Carolina and Mississippi. Â When 
  Wife learned Husband was residing in Atlanta, she contacted the courthouse there 
  only to learn he had moved to New Jersey. Â By this point, her illness 
  and financial situation began to hinder her efforts. Â At no time was 
  Husband contacted or any claim filed in relation to the non-payment of alimony.Â  

In 1999, the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS), acting on 
  behalf of Wife, sought a rule to show cause resulting in the issuance of a bench 
  warrant for Husbandâ€™s arrest for a support arrearage of $19,364. Â However, 
  pursuant to a 1995 order, SCDSS asserted and the court held the child was emancipated 
  and Husband was $7,107 in arrears on child support at the time of emancipation.Â  
  In October 2001, Husband paid this amount in full to the New Jersey family court. 
  Â The money eventually went to SCDSS and some payments were made to Wife.Â  
  Neither the New Jersey court nor Wife ever communicated to the issuing South 
  Carolina court that the amount had been satisfied. Â In June 2002, Wife 
  learned Husband was in Beaufort visiting their son.Â  She contacted the police 
  and Husband was arrested on the bench warrant issued for the child support arrearage.Â  
  He was incarcerated for nine days before being granted a hearing on the matter.Â  

At the hearing, Husband submitted evidence he had paid his child support arrearage, 
  obviously believing child support was the subject of the action.Â  The court 
  quickly acknowledged the child support had been paid and was no longer at issue. 
  Â Wife, however, wanted to proceed on a claim for unpaid alimony, expressing 
  her fear that Husband would never again appear in South Carolina.Â  She claimed 
  the contempt order (entered to support the original bench warrant) contained 
  language broad enough to cover the alimony as well as child support. [3] Â  Husband contended the case should 
  be dismissed and he should be served a separate summons and complaint on the 
  issue of alimony. Â Attempting to balance the due process concerns of 
  Husband and the significant travel burdens on Wife, the court allowed Wife to 
  testify on the non-payment of the alimony at this hearing.Â  The court then gave 
  Husband official personal notice of the suit and granted him ten days to respond 
  in person or by affidavit. Â Husband submitted an affidavit. 
In its final order, the court found Husbandâ€™s claim that he did not receive 
  notice of this courtâ€™s unpublished opinion lacking in credibility and awarded 
  Wife $57,600 in unpaid alimony (the total accrued less the $24,000 Husband claimed 
  to have paid). Â Husband appeals on the ground that this procedure violated 
  certain constitutional rights. 
DISCUSSION 
Husband claims the procedure followed by the family court 
  constitutes a violation of his constitutional right to procedural due process.Â  
  We agree.
The Due Process Clause requires â€œnotice reasonably calculated 
  under all the circumstances, to apprise interested parties of the pendency of 
  the action and afford them an opportunity to present their objections.â€Â  Mullane v. 
  Central Hanover Bank & Trust Co., 339 U.S. 306, 314 (1950); Murdock 
  v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 334, 526 S.E.2d 241, 248 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Although 
  procedural due process is a flexible doctrine, it mandates that a litigant be 
  placed on notice of the issues the court is to consider.Â  Murdock, 338 
  S.C. at 333, 526 S.E.2d at 248.Â  The fundamental purpose of pleadings is to 
  fulfill this requirement.Â  See South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank v. Joyner, 
  289 S.C. 382, 387, 346 S.E.2d 329, 332 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œIt is elementary that 
  the principal purpose of pleadings is to inform the pleaderâ€™s adversary of legal 
  and factual positions which he will be required to meet on trial.â€). 
Here, Husband was arrested on a bench warrant issued pursuant 
  to a civil contempt order.Â  The order was issued following a rule to show cause 
  brought on Wifeâ€™s behalf by SCDSS.Â  Both the order and the bench warrant list 
  SCDSS as a plaintiff.Â  SCDSS, though granted authority to pursue unpaid child 
  support by way of a limited power of attorney, has no authority to pursue unpaid 
  alimony.Â  These pleadings were wholly insufficient to give Husband notice he 
  would be required to address the issue of unpaid alimony at the hearing.Â  The 
  court even acknowledged Husband â€œhad reason to believe what he was here today 
  to defend on was on child support.â€Â  
Wife argued the language â€œfailure to pay as orderedâ€ contained 
  in the civil contempt order broadly covered any support amount Husband might 
  have owed.Â  We disagree.Â  The family court is limited by the scope of due process, 
  and the rule that its pleadings are to be liberally construed may not be stretched 
  so as to permit the court to award relief not contemplated by the pleadings.Â  
  Henry v. Henry, 296 S.C. 285, 287, 372 S.E.2d 104, 106 (Ct. App. 1988); 
  see also Murdock, 338 S.C. at 334, 526 S.E.2d at 248.Â  The inclusion 
  of SCDSS as a party clearly indicated the action concerned only unpaid child 
  support.Â  Wife could have easily prepared a summons, complaint, and rule to 
  show cause for unpaid alimony and served Husband while he was in the Beaufort 
  County jail.
We also disagree with the contention that the courtâ€™s grant 
  of ten days to Husband to respond via affidavit or appearance cured this due 
  process violation.Â  A fundamental requirement of due process is the opportunity 
  to be heard at a meaningful time and in a meaningful manner.Â  Blanton v. 
  Stathos, 351 S.C. 534, 542, 570 S.E.2d 565, 569 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Allowing 
  Wife to proceed with her testimony as to unpaid alimony at the child support 
  hearing deprived Husband the opportunity to participate in discovery, prepare 
  adequate cross-examination, file relevant financial declarations, and call his 
  own witnesses.Â  We fail to see how an extension of time to respond cured these 
  flaws and made Husbandâ€™s deficient opportunity to be heard any more meaningful 
  in time or manner.Â  To quote the family court judge, you â€œcannot let convenience 
  get in the way of due process.â€Â  Unfortunately, that is exactly what happened 
  in this case. 
Absent due notice, a court lacks jurisdiction to adjudicate 
  the partyâ€™s personal rights.Â  Blanton, 351 S.C. at 542, 570 S.E.2d at 
  569.Â  A judgment by a court without jurisdiction over both the parties and the 
  subject matter is a nullity and must be so treated by the courts.Â  Id.Â  

For the foregoing reasons, the order of the family court 
  is
REVERSED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to the 
    partiesâ€™ request and Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  After her appeal, she chose to dismiss trial and appellate 
    counsel because of issues surrounding the handling of her initial case and 
    general mistrust. 

 
   
    [3]  The order stated Husband owed a â€œsupport arrearageâ€ of $19,364 
    â€œfor failure to pay as ordered.â€Â

title: State v. Williams
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON 
  AS
PRECEDENT IN NAY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Rufus Junior Williams, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.
2004-UP-536  
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 21, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Edward Delane Rosemond, of Seneca, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Williams was convicted of 
  first-degree burglary and simple assault and battery.Â  He argues on appeal that 
  the trial judge abused his discretion by (1) not allowing him access to the 
  attorney of his choice and (2) admitting portions of a 9-1-1 tape into evidence.Â  
  We affirm. 
FACTS  
On August 25, 2002, Rufus Junior Williams made threatening phone calls to his 
  ex-girlfriendâ€”Smith.Â  Later the same night, Smith heard a noise in the bathroom 
  of her apartment.Â  After discovering that the screen in her bathroom window 
  had been cut open, she called 9-1-1.Â  While on the phone with the 9-1-1 operator, 
  Smith heard another noise in the bathroom and observed Williams walking down 
  the hallway towards her.Â  Smith dropped the phone and ran outside.Â  Williams 
  followed her out of the apartment and hit her on the back of her head, causing 
  her to fall to the ground.Â  Once on the ground, Williams repeatedly hit and 
  kicked Smith until a crowd drew near.Â  Williams then fled the scene and 
  was later arrested. 
Williams was charged with first-degree burglary and assault and battery. A 
  public defender was appointed to represent him at trial.Â  After Williams refused 
  to cooperate with the public defender, she filed a motion to be relieved.Â  The 
  trial court denied the motion, requiring Williams to proceed with the public 
  defender. 
During trial, the State offered the 9-1-1 tape into evidence.Â  Williams objected 
  to the tape on grounds that it was hearsay, cumulative, and prejudicial.Â  The 
  trial court overruled the objection and allowed portions of the 9-1-1 tape to 
  be admitted into evidence. 
The jury found Williams guilty of first-degree 
  burglary and assault and battery.Â  Williams was sentenced to twenty years on 
  the burglary charge and thirty days on the assault and battery charge. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Â I. Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of defense counselâ€™s 
  motion to be relieved.Â  â€œA motion to relieve counsel is addressed to the discretion 
  of the trial judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  
  State v. Graddick, 345 S.C. 383, 385, 548 S.E.2d 210, 211 (2001) (citation 
  omitted). 
The Sixth Amendment guarantees criminal defendants a right to counsel.Â  U.S. 
  Const. Amend. VI; Stevenson v. State, 337 S.C. 23, 26, 522 S.E.2d 343, 
  344 (1999).Â  Defendants also have the right to secure counsel of their own choice.Â  
  Powell v. Alabama, 287 U.S. 45, 53 (1932).Â  However, the right to counsel 
  may be waived.Â  In State v. Jacobs, 271 S.C. 126, 245 S.E.2d 606 (1978), 
  our supreme court held that a defendant could waive the right to counsel through 
  his conduct.Â  The court noted that:Â 

[W]here a defendant able 
  to retain counsel has been advised by the court that he must retain counsel 
  by a certain reasonable time, and where there is no showing why he has not retained 
  counsel within that time, the court may treat his failure to provide for his 
  own defense as a waiver of his right to counsel and require such defendant to 
  proceed to trial without an attorney. 

Id. at 128, 245 S.E.2d 
  at 607-608 (quoting United States v. Arlen, 252 F.2d 491 (2d Cir. 1958)).Â  
  In State v. Jacobs, the Appellant never expressly waived his right to 
  counsel.Â  However, the trial court found that the Appellant was on several occasions 
  urged to retain counsel, a phone was made available to him, and additional time 
  had been given him to make arrangements.Â  Id. at 128, 245 S.E.2d at 608.Â  
  On the day of trial, counsel was not present and Appellant did not name an attorney 
  or indicate when counsel would be available.Â  Id.Â  Therefore, the court 
  held that Appellant had waived his right to counsel by his conduct. Id. 
 

In this case, also through his conduct, Williams waived the right to counsel 
  of his choice.Â  A public defender was appointed on August 29, 2002 to represent 
  him at trial; however, Williams was uncooperative with the public defender. 
  He failed to show up for office appointments and refused to discuss his case 
  or offer any defense.Â  One month before trial was to begin, Judge Kittredge 
  warned Williams that his case would soon be called for trial and that if he 
  wanted to hire a private attorney, he should do so quickly.Â  On the day of trial, 
  Williams alleged he had followed this advice and hired a private attorney.Â  
  However, Williams first talked to the attorney earlier that same morning and 
  failed to inform the attorney his case was on the trial docket for that day. 

Because Williams refused to cooperate with the public defender and failed to 
  hire a private attorney after the court urged him to do so, he waived the right 
  to have the counsel of his choice. Therefore, the trial court did not abuse 
  its discretion by requiring Williams to proceed to trial with the public defender. 

II.Â Â Â Â Â  The trial court did not err in allowing a portion of the Smithâ€™s 
  9-1-1 tape to be admitted into evidence.Â  â€œThe admissibility of evidence is 
  within the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  State v. Mansfield, 
  343 S.C. 66, 77, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing State v. Patterson, 
  337 S.C. 215, 522 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  â€œAccordingly, evidentiary rulings 
  of the trial court will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion 
  or the commission of legal error which results in prejudice to the defendant.â€Â  
  Id.  
The 9-1-1 tape contained Smithâ€™s conversation with 9-1-1 dispatchers as the 
  incident was occurring.Â  Williams argues the tape was highly prejudicial and 
  should not have been admitted into evidence.Â  The trial court found that the 
  tapeâ€™s probative value outweighed any danger of unfair prejudice.Â  It noted 
  that the tape had significant probative value for two reasons.Â  First, the tape 
  provided a real-time account of the entering and was relevant to the issue of 
  whether or not Williams had the intent to commit a crime at the time of entering.Â  
  Secondly, the trial court noted that the State was trying to prove assault and 
  battery. An important element of assault is that the victim is placed in fear 
  by the attacker. Thus, screaming on the tape was relevant to show the victimâ€™s 
  fear.Â  Therefore, the trial court found the tape had significant probative value. 

Because we feel the trial court clearly set forth the probative value of the 
  tape and made a conscious effort to minimize any prejudicial effect of the tape 
  might have, we find that the trial court did not abuse its discretion by admitting 
  the tape into evidence. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing reasons, Williamsâ€™ convictions 
  and sentences are
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.
Â

title: Reliford v. Mitsubishi Motors Credit of America, Inc.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ephrain Reliford, Jr., Appellant,
v.
Mitsubishi Motors Credit of America, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-537
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ephrain Reliford, Jr. of Kershaw, pro se.
Andrew F. Lindemann, of Columbia; and David Austin Brown, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Ephrain Reliford, Jr. appeals a circuit court order granting 
  summary judgment to Mitsubishi Motors Credit of America, Inc.Â  On appeal, Reliford 
  argues the circuit court erred in denying his Constitutional right to a jury 
  trial by granting summary judgment to Mitsubishi and erred in ruling that his 
  claims were barred by the statute of limitations.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In May 1993, Reliford purchased an automobile financed by Mitsubishi.Â  He was 
  arrested for murder on January 7, 1994 and the Aiken County Sheriffâ€™s Department 
  seized the car as evidence a few days later.
Reliford failed to make loan payments to Mitsubishi.Â  Consequently, Mitsubishi 
  instituted a claim and delivery action against Reliford.Â  On May 13, 1994, Mitsubishi 
  served him with the summons and complaint.Â  Reliford was incarcerated at that 
  time.Â  He did not respond to the claim and delivery action.Â  The Sheriffâ€™s Department 
  released the car to Mitsubishi on May 25, 1994.Â  Mitsubishi and the Sheriffâ€™s 
  Department entered a written stipulation through which they agreed to dismiss 
  the claim and delivery action against Reliford without prejudice.
In November 2002, Reliford brought the present action alleging 
  â€œstatute of negligence, bailment, wrongful taking, nuisance, and trover and 
  conversionâ€ against Mitsubishi.Â  Mitsubishi answered, asserting defenses including 
  the statute of limitations.
Reliford made a motion for summary judgment in 
  January 2003.Â  A hearing was held on the motion, during which the circuit court 
  denied Relifordâ€™s motion but sua sponte granted summary judgment to Mitsubishi.Â  

Reliford made a â€œMotion to Alter or Amendâ€ pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP. Before 
  the circuit court ruled on his order, Reliford filed a notice of appeal.Â  In 
  June 2003, the circuit court subsequently issued an order partially granting 
  and denying Relifordâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion.Â  This court later found that the circuit 
  court order was entered â€œwithout jurisdiction.â€
LAW/ANALYSIS  
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Statute of Limitations
The gravamen of Relifordâ€™s appeal is his contention that the circuit court 
  erred in finding that his action was barred by the statute of limitations.Â  
  We disagree.
Reliford concedes that the underlying cause of action in the present case is 
  subject to a three-year statute of limitations.Â  At the time this cause of action 
  arose, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-40 (1976) tolled the three-year statute of limitations 
  for â€œpersons under disability.â€Â  Subsection (3) of this statute provided that 
  such â€œpersons under disabilityâ€ included those â€œ[i]mprisoned on a criminal or 
  civil charge or in execution under the sentence of a sentence of a criminal 
  court for a less term than his natural life â€¦.â€ 
  [1] Â  Id.Â  However, â€œ[t]he time of such disability is not part of 
  the time limited for the commencement of the action, except the period within 
  which the action must be brought cannot be extended by: (1) [m]ore than five 
  years by any such disability, except infancy; nor (2) [i]n any case longer than 
  one year after the disability ceases.â€Â  Id.
Here, Relifordâ€™s causes of action undisputedly arose 
  in May of 1994 when he was served with Mitsubishiâ€™s claim and delivery action. 
  [2] Â  However, Reliford maintains pursuant to the â€œdiscovery ruleâ€ that 
  the statute of limitations did not begin running until well after May 1994, 
  such that this action would be timely.Â  We find this argument unavailing.Â  Reliford 
  was clearly on notice not later than May of 1994 when he admittedly received 
  the summons and complaint in the claim and delivery action in which Mitsubishi 
  sought â€œimmediate seizure and permanent possession ofâ€ Relifordâ€™s car.Â  This 
  knowledge clearly provided reasonable notice to Reliford that possession of 
  his car, and possibly its contents, would be transferred to Mitsubishi.Â  From 
  an objective standpoint, if Mitsubishiâ€™s possession of the car were wrongful, 
  a reasonable person would have been on notice of a potential claim in May of 
  1994.Â  Thus, we find that, at the latest, Relifordâ€™s statute of limitations 
  began running in May of 1994.Â  See Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of 
  Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 719, 511 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1999) (Finding that 
  under the discovery rule, whether the particular plaintiff actually knew he 
  had a claim is not the test; rather, courts must objectively determine whether 
  the circumstances of the case would put a person of common knowledge and experience 
  on notice that some right of his has been invaded, or that some claim against 
  another party might exist).Â  Even allowing the maximum five-year period of tolling 
  allowed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-40 (1976), followed by the three-year statute 
  of limitations, we find that the time Reliford had to bring the present action 
  expired on May 13, 2002.Â  Because he did not bring the present action until 
  November 2002, we find as a matter of law that the applicable statute of limitations 
  barred his action.
II.      Constitutional Violation
Reliford next argues that the circuit court erred in denying his Constitutional 
  right to a jury trial by sua sponte granting summary judgment to Mitsubishi.Â  
  However, the issue of Relifordâ€™s Constitutional rights was not raised to the 
  circuit court in the summary judgment hearing nor was it later raised in Relifordâ€™s 
  â€œMotion to Alter or Amendâ€ made pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP. 
  [3] Â  Thus, the issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See 
  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 380, 580 S.E.2d 785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (â€œArguments not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved 
  for appellate reviewâ€);Â  State v. Varvil, 338 S.C. 335, 339, 526 S.E.2d 
  248, 250 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œConstitutional arguments are no exception to the 
  rule, and if not raised to the trial court are deemed waived on appealâ€).Â  
III.Â Â Â  Denial of Motion for Summary Judgment
Last, Reliford argues that the circuit court erred in denying his motion for 
  summary judgment.Â  However, it is well settled law in South Carolina that â€œthe 
  denial of a motion for summary judgment is not appealable, even after final 
  judgment.â€Â  Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 168, 
  580 S.E.2d 440, 444 (2003).Â  Accordingly, we find the issue of the circuit courtâ€™s 
  alleged error in denying Relifordâ€™s summary judgment motion is not appealable.Â  
  In any event, Mitsubishiâ€™s entitlement to summary judgment renders moot the 
  challenge to the denial of Relifordâ€™s motion for summary judgment.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  A 1996 amendment 
    removed subsection (3) from S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-40, among other changes. 
  

 
   [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The car was seized 
    by the Sheriffâ€™s Department in January 1994, shortly after Relifordâ€™s arrest.

 
   [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Significantly, 
    the precise issue of the circuit court granting relief to a party that did 
    not request such relief is not before us.

THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Larry M. Hathcock, Appellant,
v.
Betty M. Hathcock, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-538
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas F. McDow, of Rock Hill; James R. Honeycutt, of Fort 
  Mill; and James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Lohman D. Reiter, II, and G. Murrell Smith, Jr., both of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic action brought 
  by Larry Hathcock (Husband) against ex-wife Betty Hathcock (Wife), Husband argues 
  the family court erred by declining to terminate alimony and refusing to award 
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm. [1] 
Facts  
In September 1996, a York County family court awarded Betty Hathcock a divorce 
  from her husband of twenty-eight years, Larry Hathcock, on the ground of adultery.Â  
  The divorce decree required Husband to pay Wife $400.00 per month in alimony.Â Â  
  In 1998, approximately two years after the divorce, Wife began a romantic relationship 
  with Mancer Flatten that included cohabitation.Â  Flatten resided in Wifeâ€™s house, 
  yet his employment as a contractor frequently required him to work out of town 
  and often he would stay in the home only on weekends.Â  The romantic relationship 
  lasted for two years.Â  Thereafter, including the two years leading up to the 
  commencement of this trial, Flatten lived in the house in a platonic capacity, 
  sleeping sometimes on the couch and sometimes in the bedroom with Wife.Â  
Flatten contributed to the economic state of the household.Â  He paid Wife a 
  monthly rent of $250.00.Â  He occasionally bought groceries and sometimes paid 
  for dinner when the two dined together.Â  He also finished building a screened-in 
  porch that he began before he lived with Wife and provided materials and worked 
  on constructing a swimming pool deck at the home.Â  In 2001, Flatten bought land 
  and planned to buy a trailer to live in on the property.Â  Flatten moved out 
  of Wifeâ€™s home in July 2002; however, his driverâ€™s license lists his address 
  as Wifeâ€™s residence and he continues to receive mail at the location.
Husband brought an action seeking to modify the 1996 divorce order requesting 
  termination of alimony and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Wife asserted a general denial 
  defense and counterclaimed for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court concluded 
  applicable law did not afford Husband modification of the prior divorce order 
  and denied both partiesâ€™ attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  This appeal follows.
Standard of Review
Questions concerning alimony 
  rest within the sound discretion of the family court judge whose conclusion 
  will not be disturbed absent a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  Bryson v. 
  Bryson, 347 S.C. 221, 224, 553 S.E.2d 493, 495 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAn abuse 
  of discretion occurs when the decision is controlled by some error of law or 
  is based on findings of fact that are without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id. 
  at 224, 553 S.E.2d at 495.Â  
LAW/ANALYSISÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
  I.                 
Termination of Alimony 
   
Husband argues the trial court 
  erred in finding Wifeâ€™s relationship with Flatten was not â€œtantamount to marriage,â€ 
  which would entitle him to termination of alimony responsibility.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina common law in 
  effect at the time of the filing of this action governs this case. 
  [2] Â  Changed conditions may warrant modification or termination of alimony.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1985).Â  A court may terminate alimony when a supported 
  ex-spouse is involved in a relationship tantamount to marriage.Â  Bryson, 
  347 S.C. at 226, 553 S.E.2d at 496.Â  Husband contends that Wife had a relationship 
  with Flatten tantamount to marriage, evidenced by the initial sexual relationship, 
  the fact that Flatten resided at the house for four years, and his assistance 
  with various household improvements.Â  
When our courts have found changed 
  circumstances based on a relationship tantamount to marriage, the supported 
  ex-spouse has been involved in a relationship in which the parties have economically 
  relied upon one another.Â  Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 517, 586 S.E.2d 
  136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003);Â  See Bryson, 347 S.C at 225, 553 S.E.2d 
  at 496 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding that relationship was tantamount to marriage 
  where supported ex-spouse had lived together for twelve years, had moved to 
  Florida together, and continued to engage in sexual relations throughout their 
  involvement).Â  No evidence exists from the record indicating that such reliance 
  existed in this case.Â  Flattenâ€™s economic contributions to the household were 
  minimal and there is no evidence that Wife used her alimony to support Flatten 
  in any way.Â  Flatten paid Wife rent for the privilege of residing on the premises, 
  and even through the duration of the sexual relationship, Flatten retained the 
  status of tenant.Â  Moreover, the evidence suggests that Flatten spent a majority 
  of nights out of town tending to his business duties.
Husband argues on appeal that 
  the lower court erred in its analysis and that this error affords him a reduction 
  or termination of alimony.Â  Husbandâ€™s exclusive argument on appeal is that the 
  relationship was tantamount to marriage.Â  When a court determines such a relationship 
  exists, the only result can be termination rather than reduction of alimony.Â  
  In Bryson, this court overruled the family courtâ€™s decision reducing 
  alimony rather than terminating it where the court found a relationship tantamount 
  to marriage.Â  Bryson, 347 S.C. 221, 553 S.E.2d 493.Â  Husbandâ€™s complaint 
  and the testimony reveal that Husband specifically requested termination of 
  alimony at trial, and the only mention of modification lies in the court order, 
  which concluded the law did not require it to modify or terminate Husbandâ€™s 
  obligation.Â  
Accordingly, the trial court 
  correctly found the relationship between Wife and Flatten was not tantamount 
  to marriage, and therefore correctly denied Husband termination of alimony. 
  Â 
  II.              
Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
   
Husband argues the family court erred in denying 
  his request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
The family courtâ€™s decision whether to award attorney 
  fees is a discretionary matter and will not be overturned absent an abuse of 
  discretion. Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 
  903 (1988).Â  We find no abuse of that discretion in the family courtâ€™s refusal 
  to grant attorney fees to Husband. 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  In 2002, the South Carolina General 
    Assembly amended Section 20-3-150 of the South Carolina Code, changing the 
    conditions under which the court may modify or terminate alimony, including 
    cohabitation.Â  The 2002 amendments became effective in June 18, 2002 after 
    the filing of this action, thus the family court correctly disregarded the 
    2002 amendments in its analysis.

title: Murray v. Murray
text:
PER CURIAM: In this termination of alimony action brought by Appellant 
Larry Hathcock against Respondent Betty Hathcock, Appe


THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Wanda S. Murray, Respondent,
v.
James H. Murray, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â M.D. Myers, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-539
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Lohman D. Reiter, II, of Sumter, for Appellant.
G. Murrell Smith, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic action brought 
  by James Murray (Husband) against ex-wife Wanda Murray (Wife), Husband challenges 
  the family courtâ€™s refusal to terminate military retirement benefit payments 
  to Wife pursuant to a 1990 divorce degree.Â  Husband also challenges the award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
Facts Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
James and Wanda Murray divorced in 1990 after fourteen 
  years of marriage.Â  Both parties served in the military and the divorce decree 
  awarded each 30 percent of the otherâ€™s military retirement benefits based on 
  the partiesâ€™ rank and length of service at the time of the 1990 decree.Â  Applying 
  the 30 percent figure, the court concluded that Husband should pay Wife $318.33 
  per month, plus all cost of living raises. The court also determined the funds 
  paid to Wife were to be deducted from Husbands gross, non-disability retirement 
  benefits.Â  Husband retired from the United States Air Force in 1999 and the 
  Veteranâ€™s Administration found Husband to be 60 percent disabled.Â  At the time 
  of this action, Husband received monthly payments of $1,682.00 for military 
  retirement and $864.00 in disability payments. 
  [2] Â  
After Husband retired, Wife requested payment in accordance 
  with the 1990 divorce decree and Husband directed her to seek payment from the 
  Defense Finance and Accounting Services (DFAS).Â  DFAS declined to recognize 
  the divorce decree because it did not include a specific formula required by 
  DFAS to calculate the pay due to Wife.Â  Wife filed a complaint for payment and, 
  after a hearing, the family court found for the Wife.Â  Husband filed a motion 
  to reconsider, which the court denied.Â  This appeal follows.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Standard of Review
In appeals from the 
  family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with 
  its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 
  322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, 
  does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson 
  v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSISÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

  I.                 
Military Retirement Benefits 
   
Husband argues the family court 
  erred in finding Wife is still entitled to receive a portion of the Husbandâ€™s 
  military retirement benefits.Â  We disagree.Â  
Courts do not have the authority 
  to treat disability benefits as property divisible upon divorce.Â  Mansell 
  v. Mansell, 490 U.S. 581 (1989).Â  Husband contends that because his retirement 
  benefits were reduced when he waived his retirement pay to receive disability 
  benefits, Wife should bear the burden of the loss, or alternatively, that the 
  loss should be borne equally.Â  However, there is no evidence that at the time 
  of the divorce the court factored in whether Husband was entitled to receive 
  any disability benefits in lieu of retirement pay.Â  The court made its calculation 
  based solely on the amount Husband was then entitled to draw, which represented 
  what the Husband owed to Wife as a portion of the marital property.Â Â  
Military retirement benefits 
  accrued during the marriage are subject to equitable division.Â  Tiffault 
  v. Tiffault, 303 S.C. 391, 401 S.E.2d 157 (1991).Â  Any retirement pay accrued 
  after the divorce, however, would constitute non-marital property.Â  Therefore, 
  the divorce decree determined the fixed sum that Husband owed Wife for the time 
  the two spent as husband and wife.Â  The percentage was to be taken from the 
  amount of retirement Husband had accrued to that point, leaving Wife with a 
  precise figure, explicitly excluding any disability pay from the total sum.Â  

The divorce decree clearly stated 
  that Wife was entitled to $1,061.00, plus cost of living increases, and further 
  indicated that if the militaryâ€™s retirement plan administrator failed to pay 
  Wife, the Husband should pay from his personal assets.Â  Husband voluntarily 
  waived his right to a portion of his earned retirement benefits to receive disability 
  pay and his action should not injure Wife, who had a right to the retirement 
  pay accrued during the marriage.Â  See Price v. Price, 325 S.C. 
  379, 480 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding husband may not subvert support 
  obligations to his former wife by waiving military retirement pay in favor of 
  disability benefits).Â  Thus, the trial court properly interpreted the divorce 
  decree awarding Wife a specific sum to be paid from Husbandâ€™s non-disability 
  retirement benefits.Â Â  
  II.              
Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
   
Husband argues the family court erred in awarding 
  Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees will not be overturned 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 99, 561 
  S.E.2d 610, 617 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When determining the amount of fees to award, 
  the court must consider several factors including the beneficial results obtained 
  and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 
  304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  In this case, the family court 
  detailed the rationale for its award in its final order, addressing the applicable 
  Glasscock factors.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not abuse its discretion 
  in its award of attorneyâ€™s fees. 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Veterans receiving retirement pay may also apply for disability benefits 
    for a disability obtained from military service.Â  However, â€œ[i]n order to 
    prevent double dipping, a military retiree may receive disability benefits 
    only to the extent that he waives a corresponding amount of his military retirement 
    pay.â€Â  Mansell v. Mansell, 490 U.S. 581, 583 (1989).Â  Military retirees 
    often prefer to waive retirement pay in favor of disability benefits because 
    disability benefits are exempt from taxation.Â  Id. at 583.

title: S.C. Department of Social Services v. Martin
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
S.C. Department of Social Services, County of
Siskiyou, and Debra J. 
        Little, Plaintiffs, 
Of Whom, S.C. Department of Social Services is,
Appellant,
v.
Michael D. Martin, Respondent.
        
      
    
  

Appeal From Greenwood County
Â Billy A. Tunstall, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.
2004-UP-540  
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 25, 2004 


REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Holly C. Walker, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Billy J. Garrett, Jr., C. Rauch Wise, both of Greenwood, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In April 2003 the family court 
  issued a civil contempt order against Michael Martin for failure to pay child 
  support under a November 18, 1986 California support order.Â  Martin filed a 
  motion for emergency temporary relief, claiming that an order issued in South 
  Carolina on May 8, 1990 modified the California order.Â  Upon reconsideration, 
  the judge vacated his 2003 order after determining the 1990 order terminated 
  Martinâ€™s obligations under the California order. We reverse and remand.  
  [1] Â  
FACTS 
Debra Little and Michael 
  Martinâ€™s marriage, which began in 1978, produced two children, Trenton and Lisa.Â  
  After a period of separation, the couple divorced in 1986 in Siskiyou County, 
  California.Â  The court granted custody of Lisa to Little and custody of Trenton 
  to Martin.Â  On November 18, 1986, the Siskiyou County Family Support Division 
  ordered Martin to pay $303 per month in child support for Lisa.
On February 27, 1989, the 
  Siskiyou County District Attorney sent a request to the South Carolina Department 
  of Social Services (SCDSS) to enforce the November 18, 1986 order pursuant to 
  the Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act 
  [2]  (URESA).Â  Siskiyou County and Little also sought $11,831.00 
  for medical coverage and arrearage of past due support payments.Â  SCDSS served 
  Martin with the URESA request, which he answered on April 5, 1990.Â  
Prior to a hearing on April 
  25, 1990, the county and Little entered into an agreement with Martin to reduce 
  Martinâ€™s child support payments. The agreement was then incorporated into an 
  order issued on May 8, 1990.Â  Per the order, Martin was to pay $30.00 per week 
  in child support and $10.00 per week toward the arrearage, which was to be determined 
  within 30 days of the date of the order.Â  The parties did not appeal the order 
  nor did the court determine the arrearage. 
At some point after May 
  8, 1990, the Greenwood County Clerk of Court issued two rules to show cause 
  for failure to pay child support.Â  As a result, on April 23, 2003, nearly thirteen 
  years later, Martin appeared pro se to defend SCDSSâ€™s allegations 
  that he was in willful contempt of Californiaâ€™s 1986 child support order.Â  During 
  the hearing, the SCDSS attorney failed to bring the May 8, 1990 South Carolina 
  order to the courtâ€™s attention.Â  As a result, the judge issued an order enforcing 
  the November 18, 1986 California order.Â  
Martin filed a motion for 
  emergency temporary relief and a hearing was held on June 25, 2003.Â  On October 
  17, 2003, the judge issued an order vacating his previous order and enforcing 
  the May 8, 1990 order, stating that the court would not have issued the April 
  23, 2003 order had it known about the May 8, 1990 order. [3] Â  The order also stated that the May 8, 1990 
  order was the â€œfinal order in this matter determining [Martinâ€™s] child support 
  obligations, and [the May 8, 1990] final order ended [Martinâ€™s] prospective 
  California child support obligations.â€Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from a family court order, the appellate 
  court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with their own view of the 
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  Roberson v. Roberson, 359 S.C. 384, 388, 597 S.E.2d 840, 842 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
  The appellate court should not, however, disregard the findings of the trial 
  judge who observed the witness and was better able to assess their credibility. 
  Â Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 523, 599 S.E.2d 114, 119 (2004).Â  Cases 
  involving child support are ordinarily left to the discretion of the family 
  court and will only be disturbed on appeal upon a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  
  Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 
  2003).Â  Abuse of discretion arises when the court is controlled by an error 
  of law or the order lacks evidentiary support.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
SCDSS argues that the trial 
  court erred in finding the May 8, 1990 South Carolina support order was final 
  and terminated Martinâ€™s prospective California child support obligations.Â  We 
  agree.Â Â  
The parties agree that the 
  applicable law governing this case is URESA, formerly found in sections 20-7-960 
  to 1170 of South Carolina Code (1985). [4] Â  Section 20-7-933 of the South 
  Carolina Code (Supp. 2003) grants the family court authority to enforce orders 
  regarding child support, including cases in which the family court has jurisdiction 
  based on URESA.Â  Section 20-7-933 also provides that the family court has â€œthe 
  right to modify any such decree, judgment, or order for child support as the 
  court considers necessary upon a showing of changed circumstances.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-933 (Supp. 2003).Â  Therefore, the South Carolina family court had 
  authority to enforce and modify the 1986 California support order when SCDSS 
  sought to enforce the California order on behalf of Siskiyou County and Little.Â  

Section 20-7-1110, however, 
  provides that â€œ[a] support order made by a court of this State . . . does not 
  nullify and is not nullified by a support order made by a court of this State 
  pursuant to any other law or by a support order made by a court of any other 
  state . . . unless otherwise specifically provided by the court.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-1110 (1985).Â  â€œSection 20-7-1110 clearly provides that a support 
  order made by a court of this State is not nullified by a support order made 
  by a court of another state unless specifically provided by the court.â€Â  South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Social Services v. Hamlett, 330 S.C. 321, 325, 498 S.E.2d 
  888, 890 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Thus, in Hamlett, we held that a South Carolina 
  child support order continued as an â€œindependently enforceable order regardless 
  of its registration and modification in a foreign state unless specifically 
  nullified by the court pursuant to section 20-7-1110.â€Â  Id. at 326, 498 
  S.E.2d at 890-91.
More recently, in SCDSS/Child 
  Support Enforcement v. Carswell, 359 S.C. 424, 597 S.E.2d 859 (Ct. App. 
  2004), SCDSS sought registration and enforcement of a Washington child support 
  order in South Carolina under URESA. [5] Â  In Carswell, as in this 
  case, the parties had entered into an agreement to reduce the amount the obligor 
  was required to pay, which was then incorporated into one of three South Carolina 
  family court orders.Â  Id. at 427, 597 S.E.2d at 860. Upon examination 
  of the original order and the subsequent South Carolina orders, we held that 
  because the subsequent South Carolina orders merely recognized the Washington 
  order, the orders did not â€œrise to the level of a nullification of the Washington 
  order.â€Â  Id. at 430, 597 S.E.2d at 861.Â  Therefore, the original Washington 
  order remained valid and independently enforceable in South Carolina.Â  Id. 
 

In this case, the May 8, 
  1990 order does not provide any indication that it was intended to nullify the 
  California order.Â  The 1990 order does not specifically mention the 1986 order, 
  nor does it specify it was intended to nullify the 1986 order.Â  Therefore, the 
  May 8, 1990 order did not nullify the 1986 California order and the California 
  order remains independently enforceable in South Carolina.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.


 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  Formerly found in S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-960 to 
    1170 (1985); Act No. 356, 1984 S.C. Acts 1640.Â  Â Â Â 

 
   
    [3]  The court took judicial notice in its October 17, 2003 order that 
    Martinâ€™s daughter, Lisa, turned 18 years old on February 17, 1997 and she 
    was the only child Martin was ordered to support prospectively from May 8, 
    1990.Â  Therefore, Martinâ€™s prospective South Carolina child support ended 
    on February 17, 1997.

 
   [4]  On July 1, 1994, the South Carolina 
    Legislature enacted the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA), which 
    replaced URESA.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-960 to 1220 (Supp. 2003); Act No. 
    494, 1994 S.C. Acts 5103.Â  This court has interpreted UIFSA to require application 
    of URESA to support actions arising before July 1, 1994, the effective date 
    of UIFSA.Â  Deltoro v. McMullen, 322 S.C. 328, 471 S.E.2d 742 (Ct. App. 
    1996).Â  The initial support obligation in this action arose in 1986, which 
    was prior to UIFSAâ€™s July 1, 1994 effective date.Â  Therefore, URESA, not UIFSA, 
    is the controlling law in this action.

 
   
    [5]  We note that the trial judge did not have the benefit of the Carswell 
    opinion when he issued the October 17, 2003 order because it had not yet been 
    decided.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCDEEDING EXCEPT AS 
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
v.
Jonathan Bass, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-541
Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  26, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Appellant.
Christopher A. Wellborn, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  




PER CURIAM:  Jonathan Bass was arrested 
  for driving under the influence.Â  At a pre-trial hearing, the trial judge suppressed 
  the results of a breath analysis test administered to Bass following his arrest.Â  
  The State appeals this evidentiary exclusion, arguing the trial judge erred 
  in finding the testâ€™s suppression was statutorily mandated.Â  We reverse and 
  remand.
FACTS
The facts of this case are undisputed.Â  
  In August 2001, Jonathan Bass was arrested for driving under the influence.Â  
  Once at the police station, the arresting officer advised Bass of his implied 
  consent rights and offered him a breath test to gauge his breath alcohol concentration.Â  
  During the statutorily mandated videotaped pre-test waiting period, Bass requested 
  to speak to his attorney.Â  Since there was no telephone in the breath analysis 
  room, the arresting officer escorted Bass out of the room and off camera to 
  make the phone call.Â  Bass and the officer returned to the testing room approximately 
  eleven minutes later.Â  The officer testified he remained in close proximity 
  to Bass the entire time they were off camera and at no time did Bass place a 
  foreign substance or object into his mouth.Â  At the conclusion of the twenty-minute 
  period (including the time both were absent from the room and off camera), the 
  breath analysis test was conducted on video by the arresting officer.Â Â  Bass 
  registered a .23 breath alcohol concentration.Â Â  
At a pre-trial hearing, Bass moved to 
  suppress the results of the breath analysis test.Â  Finding that the arresting 
  officer did not follow the statutory requirements applicable to administering 
  the test, specifically that the test subjectâ€™s conduct during the twenty-minute 
  waiting period be videotaped, the trial judge found the test results inadmissible.Â  
  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The trial judge has considerable discretion 
  in ruling on the admissibility of evidence.Â  State v. Sheldon, 344 S.C. 
  340, 342, 543 S.E.2d 585, 585-86 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  On appeal, the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling will not be disturbed absent a prejudicial abuse of discretion amounting 
  to an error of law.Â  Id.; see alsoÂ  State v. Smicklevich, 
  268 S.C. 411, 415, 234 S.E.2d 230, 232 (1977).
LAW / ANALYSIS
The State contends South Carolina's 
  implied consent statute does not mandate automatic exclusion of a breath test's 
  results when the pre-test waiting period is not videotaped in its entirety.Â  
  We agree.
By operating a motor vehicle in this state, 
  one automatically consents to searches of his breath, blood, and urine for the 
  presence of alcohol or drugs if arrested for an offense arising from the alleged 
  influence of such while driving.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a) (Supp. 2003).Â  
  This â€œimplied consentâ€ to be searched is circumscribed by several restrictions 
  and safeguards incorporated into the framework of the implied consent statute.Â  
  For instance, one may still refuse to take the tests at the sufferance of a 
  penalty (suspension of his driving privileges for at least ninety days), and 
  must be advised of this right of refusal before any test is given.Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a)(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  One may also request an additional independent 
  test performed by a person of his own choosing and has a right to â€œaffirmative 
  assistanceâ€ from the police in obtaining such a test.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  The authorities must also offer a person suspected of driving 
  under the influence the least intrusive of the three tests, a breath analysis 
  test, before further tests are ordered (unless a breath test is medically unfeasible 
  or there is reasonable grounds to suspect drug use other than alcohol).Â  Id.Â  

In addition to these statutory rights, 
  the implied consent statute requires that a twenty-minute pre-test waiting period 
  be videotaped â€œpursuant to Section 56-5-2953(A)(2)(d)â€ when the arresting officer 
  is administering a breath test.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a) (Supp. 2003).Â  
  Section 56-5-2953(A)(2) reads: 

[t]he videotaping at the breath site: . . . (d) must . . . 
  include the personâ€™s conduct during the required twenty-minute pre-test waiting 
  period, unless the officer submits a sworn affidavit certifying that it was 
  physically impossible to videotape this waiting period.Â  However, if the 
  arresting officer administers the breath test, the personâ€™s conduct during the 
  twenty-minute pre-test waiting period must be videotaped.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2953(A)(2) (Supp. 2003) (emphasis 
  added).Â  Because the arresting officer performed the breath test on Bass, the 
  videotaping of the pre-test waiting period was clearly required by the implied 
  consent statute in the case at bar.Â  By failing to videotape the entire twenty 
  minutes, the officer violated a mandate of the implied consent statute.Â Â Â  
Having concluded that the officerâ€™s administration 
  of the breath test violated section 56-5-2950, we next consider whether this 
  violation automatically renders the test results inadmissible.Â  We conclude 
  that it does not.
The failure of law enforcement to strictly 
  adhere to certain testing guidelines found in the implied consent statute often 
  results in the suppression of the test results at trial.Â  See e.g. 
  State v. Mullins, 331 S.C. 501, 503, 489 S.E.2d 923, 924 (1997); State 
  v. Pipkin, 294 S.C. 336, 338, 364 S.E.2d 464, 465 (1988); State v. Kimbrell, 
  326 S.C. 344, 349, 481 S.E.2d 456, 459 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  However, a violation 
  of the implied consent statute does not make suppression of the test results 
  a foregone conclusion.Â  See State v. Hunley, 349 S.C. 1, 6, 562 
  S.E.2d 472, 474 (2002) (finding the trial court erred in automatically suppressing 
  a breath testâ€™s results when no prejudice to the defendant was shown as a result 
  of the implied consent statuteâ€™s violation).Â  It is well established that â€œexclusion 
  of evidence should be limited to violations of constitutional rights and not 
  to statutory violations, at least where the appellant cannot demonstrate prejudice 
  at trial resulting from the failure to follow statutory procedure.â€Â  State 
  v. Chandler, 267 S.C. 138, 143, 226 S.E.2d 553, 555 (1976).Â  
In the case before us, the trial court 
  found that the failure to videotape the entire twenty-minute waiting period 
  automatically mandated the suppression of the breath test.Â  The trial court 
  reached this conclusion without any findings on whether Bass was prejudiced 
  by the statutory violation.Â  When a trial court suppresses evidence based on 
  a statutory violation without making any findings on whether the violation prejudiced 
  the moving party, it has made an error of law. The proper action for this court, 
  therefore, is to reverse the suppression order and remand to the trial court 
  for the purpose of making such findings.Â  Sheldon, 344 S.C. at 343-44, 
  543 S.E.2d at 586.
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â
