title: Geathers v. 3V, Inc.
text:
PREHEARING REPORT


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
      Martha Geathers, Claimant.
      v.
      3V, Inc., Employer and EBI Companies, Carrier/Defendants, 
        And, Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, Carrier/Defendant Of Whom Liberty 
        Mutual Insurance Company is the, Appellant,
      and, Martha Geathers, 3V, Inc., and EBI Companies 
        are the, Respondents.
      
    
  



  
    
      
Appeal From Georgetown County
Benjamin H. Culbertson, Special Circuit Court Judge
      
    
  


Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-542
Heard October 13, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  26, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Pope D. Johnson, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Frederick M. Zeigler, of Columbia, Andrew D. Smith and Kirsten 
  Leslie Barr, both of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation 
  action, we consider whether substantial evidence exists to support a finding 
  that where claimant Martha Geathers sustained compensable injuries in two separate 
  accidents while working for the same employer, liability for the period following 
  the second injury must be partially borne by the insurer who provided coverage 
  when the first accident occurred.Â  Here, a single commissioner and appellate 
  panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Commission) concluded 
  such evidence exists, relying on their findings that Geathers had not reached 
  maximum medical improvement (MMI) for injuries sustained in the first accident, 
  her treating physician had not released her from treatment of injuries sustained 
  in the first accident, and that the injuries she sustained in the two accidents 
  were â€œintertwined, indistinguishable, and inseparable.â€Â  On appeal, the circuit 
  court made contradictory findings based on its own view of conflicting evidence 
  in the record.Â  Ultimately, the circuit court found that the insurer providing 
  coverage when the second accident occurred, Liberty Mutual Insurance Company 
  (â€œLiberty Mutualâ€), was exclusively liable for compensation for the period following 
  the second injury.Â  Deferring to the factual findings of the Commission as mandated 
  by the applicable standard of review, we reverse.
FACTS  
Geathers sustained compensable back and leg injuries 
  in two accidents while employed by 3V, Inc. (â€œ3Vâ€).Â  The first accident occurred 
  on July 20, 1999 when EBI, Inc., (â€œEBIâ€) provided workersâ€™ compensation coverage 
  to 3V.Â  The second accident occurred on May 11, 2000, when Liberty Mutual provided 
  3Vâ€™s coverage.Â  
Following the first accident, Geathers was out 
  of work from July 21, 1999 to August 21, 1999.Â  She returned to work at 3V and 
  was placed on â€œlight dutyâ€ until October 28, 1999, after which she resumed the 
  duties she performed before the July 1999 accident.Â  In the interim, Geathers 
  sought treatment from Dr. Jeffery C. Wilkins, a physiatrist, [1]  for her back and leg injuries.Â  Dr. Wilkins ordered that Geathers 
  undergo therapy and prescribed pain medicine for her use.Â  He also ordered that 
  she not work for three weeks, and then return to light duty at work.Â  Geathers 
  discontinued office visits with Dr. Wilkins in January 2000, after about nine 
  visits.Â  However, he continued to prescribe pain medicine.Â  Although Dr. Wilkins 
  also recommended additional therapy, Geathers failed to comply. 
Geathers continued working and taking Dr. Wilkinsâ€™s 
  prescribed pain medication until the May 2000 accident.Â  She never returned 
  to work after the second accident.Â  When the second accident occurred, she again 
  sought treatment from Dr. Wilkins, who continued to prescribe pain medicine 
  and therapy.
Shortly after the second accident, Geathers filed 
  a claim seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits for injuries she sustained in 
  the July 1999 accident.Â  3V and EBI, the insurer providing 3Vâ€™s coverage at 
  the time of the 1999 accident, admitted that Geathers sustained a back injury 
  in the 1999 accident, but denied that she needed medical care for the injury 
  because she had reached MMI. 
Geathers filed a second claim against 3V on August 
  14, 2000.Â  This claim sought compensation for injuries she sustained in the 
  second accident, which occurred in May 2000 when Liberty Mutual provided 3Vâ€™s 
  workersâ€™ compensation insurance coverage.Â  3V and Liberty Mutual denied this 
  second claim, taking the position that her injuries resulted from the first 
  accident.Â  
In March 2001, a single 
  commissioner conducted a hearing on Geathersâ€™s claims.Â  At the hearing, EBI 
  took the position that Geathersâ€™s injuries from the 1999 accident were no longer 
  compensable because she had reached MMI, she had been released from Dr. Wilkinsâ€™s 
  care in January 2000, and her injuries were not the same as those sustained 
  in the first accident.Â  Conversely, Liberty Mutual argued that Geathers never 
  reached MMI for injuries related to the first accident, and that at a minimum 
  EBI should share liability for compensating Geathers.Â  Conflicting testimony 
  from Dr. Wilkins arguably supports both positions.Â  
First, Dr. Wilkinsâ€™s medical 
  records provide no clear indication that he ever made a finding that Geathers 
  reached MMI or released Geathers from his care following the 1999 accident.Â  
  Instead, the records suggested that he continued to recommend therapy and prescribe 
  pain medicine to Geathers beyond the January 2000 point at which Geathers stopped 
  visiting him for treatment.Â  
Next, in deposition testimony 
  Dr. Wilkins agreed that when he examined Geathers following the second accident, 
  she had the â€œexact same physical exam signs, had the same objective and subjective 
  complaints as she had the entire timeâ€ and that â€œ[t]his was the same problemâ€ 
  she had following the 1999 accident.Â  He further agreed â€œthe symptoms and the 
  problems that she was having [did] relate back to July 1999.â€Â  Dr. Wilkins added 
  that the first accident caused â€œwhatever condition she might be in todayâ€ following 
  the 2000 accident.Â  He also testified:

[T]he problem that she had from the first and from the second 
  and today is all the same problem.Â  The, the ideology and cause of her pain 
  is the same.Â  The, the â€“ I would consider that the second injury, per say [sic], 
  is, was actually just an aggravation of her initial injury.Â  Thatâ€™s the â€“ if 
  you look at her, if you look at her pain diagrams and way [sic] she describes 
  it, itâ€™s identical both by my examination as well as by [Geathersâ€™s] report 
  on her pain diagrams as far as distribution.

Dr. Wilkins further agreed that Geathersâ€™s â€œcurrent 
  conditionâ€ flowed from the first accident, and that â€œif she hadnâ€™t had the original 
  injury â€¦ itâ€™d be reasonable that she probably would not have had the second 
  injury â€¦ which is actually aggravation.â€Â  Dr. Wilkinsâ€™s deposition testimony 
  stands in stark contrast to his testimony at the hearing.Â  For example, at the 
  hearing Dr. Wilkinsâ€™s opinions largely favored the position of EBI in terms 
  of MMI and the relationship between the two accidents.
Geathers testified that she continued to receive 
  prescription pain medicine from Dr. Wilkins even after she voluntarily stopped 
  seeking treatment from him in January 2000.Â  Especially significant is 
  Geathersâ€™s testimony concerning the events on the day of the second accident, 
  particularly the continuing nature of the pain she experienced prior 
  to the second injury.Â  According to Geathers, on the day of the second 
  accident but before the second accident occurred, she experienced â€œa lotâ€ of 
  sharp pain in her leg and lower back, which were the â€œsame symptomsâ€ and â€œsame 
  painâ€ she had experienced since the first work-related accident in July 1999.Â  
  Thus, Geathers was â€œstill in painâ€ and â€œstill having problemsâ€ from the first 
  accident at the time of the second accident.Â  She subsequently confirmed that 
  the â€œsevereâ€ back pain experienced at the time of the second accident was identical 
  to the pain she experienced as a result of the first accident.Â  This testimony, 
  deemed credible by the Commission, is consistent with those portions of Dr. 
  Wilkinsâ€™s testimony that the Commission adopted.
Following the hearing, the 
  single commissioner issued an order finding that the 2000 accident resulted 
  in an injury that:

was a re-injury to the 
  same body parts for which [MMI] had not been established; that the [May 2000] 
  accident was intervening, but not totally independent of the [July 1999] accidental 
  injury and the [May 2000] accidental injury aggravated, exacerbated, and worsened 
  [Geathersâ€™s] condition; and the injuries from the two accidental injuries are 
  intertwined, indistinguishable, and inseparable beginning May 11, 2000 and[,] 
  and remain so as of the date of this hearing.

Based on these findings, 
  the single commissioner ordered that EBI and Liberty Mutual â€œeach equally payâ€ 
  Geathers compensation and â€œall medical and related costs incurred by [Geathers] 
  as a result of her injuries by accident as provided and allowed under the South 
  Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act; and during the remainder of disability continuing 
  from [Geathersâ€™s] injuries by accident [EBI and Liberty Mutual] shall continue 
  to furnish free of charge all such medical and related costs incurred by [Geathers] 
  â€¦.â€Â  EBI appealed the order of the single commissioner to an appellate panel 
  of the Commission, which affirmed.
EBI appealed to the circuit 
  court, which conducted a hearing in January 2002.Â  In March 2003, the circuit 
  court issued an order reversing the Commissionâ€™s order holding EBI liable for 
  Geathersâ€™s compensation following the 2000 accident, finding that there was 
  â€œsimply no evidence in the record to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that [Dr.] 
  Wilkins had not released [Geathers] in January 2000 at maximum medical improvement.â€Â  
  It based this finding â€œupon [] Dr. Wilkinsâ€™s sworn testimony at the hearing, 
  the medical records in evidence, and [Geathersâ€™s] own admission â€¦.â€Â  The circuit 
  court also rejected the Commissionâ€™s finding that the two accidental injuries 
  were â€œintertwined, indistinguishable, and inseparable beginningâ€ on the date 
  of the 2000 accident.Â  In so doing, the circuit court stated:

Based on upon the evidence 
  in the record, the [2000] accident is clearly distinguishable from the [1999] 
  accident because [Geathersâ€™s] need for medical and compensation benefits after 
  [the 2000 accident] was necessitated solely by the [2000] accident and that 
  accident caused physical injuries separate and distinct from any injuries related 
  to the [1999] accident.Â  The Commission cites no evidence in support of its 
  finding that the [1999] accident was distinguishable from the [2000] accident.Â  
  Because this finding is otherwise not supported by substantial evidence in the 
  record, it must be reversed.

Consequently, the circuit 
  court held Liberty Mutual solely responsible for the Geathersâ€™ benefits following 
  the 2000 accident.
Liberty Mutual made a motion seeking the circuit court 
  to reconsider its order, which the circuit court denied.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Liberty Mutual argues there is 
  substantial evidence to support the findings of the Commission.Â  Liberty Mutual 
  further argues that the circuit court reached contrary conclusions by impermissibly 
  weighing the evidence and making its own findings of fact.Â  As a consequence, 
  Liberty Mutual argues the circuit court erred in finding it exclusively liable 
  for Geathersâ€™s compensation benefits for the period following the 2000 injury.Â  
  We agree and reverse.
In workersâ€™ compensation cases, a court sitting 
  in an appellate capacity will not overturn a decision of the Commission unless 
  the decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or controlled by an error 
  of law.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 
  (1981).Â  Substantial evidence is not merely a â€œscintilla of evidence nor the 
  evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering 
  the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion 
  that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify 
  its action.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe substantial evidence rule does not allow judicial 
  fact-finding, or the substitution of judicial judgment for agency judgment.â€Â  
  Toddâ€™s Ice Cream, Inc. v. South Carolina Employment Commâ€™n, 281 S.C. 
  254, 258, 315 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Rather, the Commission is the 
  ultimate fact-finder, and neither the circuit court sitting in an appellate 
  capacity nor this court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission 
  as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  Linnen v. Beaufort 
  County Sheriffâ€™s Depâ€™t, 305 S.C. 341, 345, 408 S.E.2d 248, 250 (Ct. App. 
  1991).Â  
Here, the record contains ample evidence from Geathers and Dr. Wilkins to support 
  the version of facts adopted by the Commission.Â  With respect to Geathersâ€™s 
  testimony, we note that she testified that she continued to suffer symptoms 
  of â€œsevereâ€ and â€œsharpâ€ back pain resulting from her 1999 accidental injuries 
  after she stopped seeking treatment, apart from prescription pain medicine, 
  from Dr. Wilkins in January 2000.Â  Significantly, she testified that she was 
  suffering these painful symptoms on the date of the 2000 accident, just prior 
  to the accident. Â 
Regarding Dr. Wilkinsâ€™s testimony, 
  his notes of Geathersâ€™s treatment do not indicate a finding of MMI or that he 
  released her from his treatment in January 2000.Â  The record further supports 
  the finding that Dr. Wilkins continued to prescribe pain medicine to Geathers, 
  at her request, even after she stopped visiting his office for treatments.Â  
  Moreover, his deposition testimony provides substantial evidence for the findings 
  of the Commission concerning the nexus between the 1999 and 2000 accidental 
  work-related injuries. 
We find the testimony of Geathers 
  and Dr. Wilkins provides substantial evidence to support the version of facts 
  adopted by the Commission.Â  See Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 
  343 S.C. 487, 492-93, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001) (â€œWhere there is a conflict 
  in the evidence, either by different witnesses or in the testimony of the same 
  witness, the findings of fact of the Commission are conclusive.â€).Â Â  Accordingly, 
  we find that the circuit court erred in adopting its own view of the facts in 
  reaching its conclusions regarding whether Geathers reached MMI, whether Geathers 
  had been released from care by Dr. Wilkins in January 2000, and whether the 
  injuries she sustained in the two accidents were indistinguishable so as to 
  require both insurance carriers to share liability for providing compensation 
  to Geathers.
EBI nevertheless contends that Liberty 
  Mutual should have been held solely liable for compensation for the period following 
  the May 2000 accidental injury.Â  In support of its contention, EBI cites Gordon 
  v. E.I. DuPont de Nemours, 228 S.C. 67, 76, 88 S.E.2d 844, 848 (1955) for 
  the propositions that â€œwhere a latent or quiescent weakened, but not disabling, 
  condition resulting from disease is by accidental injury in the course and scope 
  of employment aggravated or accelerated or activated, with resulting disability, 
  such disability is compensableâ€ and if such â€œdisability is proximately caused 
  by the subsequent accidental injury, compensability is referable to that, and 
  not the earlier, one.â€Â  EBI argues that Gordon mandates a finding in 
  its favor as a matter of law.Â  We find this argument unavailing in light of 
  the factual-driven nature of the Gordon decision.Â  See id., 
  228 S.C. at 70, 88 S.E.2d at 845 (â€œThere is but one fundamental issue involved, 
  and that a factual one, namely: was appellantâ€™s compensable disability caused 
  by the accident of March 9, 1951, or by the accident of July 23, 1951.â€).Â  Here, 
  the Commission determined that Geathersâ€™s 1999 and 2000 injuries were not separate 
  and distinct injuries but instead were â€œintertwined, indistinguishable, and 
  inseparable.â€Â  In making this finding, we are constrained by the applicable 
  substantial evidence standard of review.Â  Similarly, the Gordon court 
  emphasized that its role was to affirm the Commissionâ€™s findings where supported 
  by substantial evidence.Â  Id.Â  (â€œThat issue having been decided by the 
  Commission as before stated, our review is limited to determination of whether 
  there was any competent testimony tending to support the Commissionâ€™s finding.â€).Â  
  We reject EBIâ€™s efforts on appeal to recast the issue as one of law in an attempt 
  to avoid application of the substantial evidence test.
CONCLUSION
We reverse the circuit court order and reinstate the order of the Commission.Â  
  Accordingly, we do not reach the remaining grounds for reversal.Â  See 
  Futch v. McAllister Towing, 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) 
  (ruling that an appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution 
  of prior issue is dispositive of remaining issues). 
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  A physiatrist is a â€œphysician who specializes in physical 
    medicine.â€Â  Merriam-Websterâ€™s Collegiate Dictionary 877 (10th ed. 1993).Â  
    Physical medicine is â€œa branch of medicine concerned with the diagnosis and 
    treatment of disease and disability by physical meansâ€ such as radiation, 
    heat, and electricity.Â  Id.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ashley Engineering & Consulting, Inc.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
TKS Construction, Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Patrick R. Watts, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-543
Heard October 13, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  26, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Frank M. Cisa, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
Andrew David Grimes, of North Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: TKS Construction hired Ashley 
  Engineering to help develop a piece of property that it was seeking to purchase.Â  
  Ashley Engineering filed a mechanicâ€™s lien against the property when TKS failed 
  to pay Ashley Engineering for its services.Â  TKS challenged the mechanicâ€™s lien 
  and sought to escape the full impact of the lien by submitting a cash bond in 
  compliance with the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.Â  The master-in-equity enforced 
  the mechanicâ€™s lien and refused to substitute the cash bond for the property.Â  
  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
TKS is wholly owned and operated by Theo K. Soritoglou, 
  who is the corporationâ€™s registered agent for service of process.Â  TKSâ€™s registered 
  office for service of process, as of April 23, 2002, was 100 Crowfield Boulevard, 
  Goose Creek, South Carolina. 
TKS sought to buy a piece 
  of property from Westvaco Development Corporation; however, prior to purchasing 
  the land, Westvaco had to approve TKSâ€™s development plans.Â  Therefore, TKS hired 
  Ashley Engineering to determine the most cost effective way to develop the property.Â  
  The work involved engineering a development design, obtaining permits, getting 
  approval for the project, and conducting boundary, topographical, and construction 
  surveys. 
TKS was initially interested 
  in buying an area defined as Lot 2.Â  Ashley Engineeringâ€™s work, however, revealed 
  that a section of Lot 2 did not need engineering work to obtain a building permit.Â  
  This section would yield four lots ready for immediate construction because 
  an area that was in the process of being developed surrounded it.Â  As a result, 
  this subsection of Lot 2 was sold to TKS as Lot 2A.Â  TKS did not purchase the 
  rest of Lot 2 from Westvaco.
TKS never paid Ashley Engineering 
  for the work they performed on Lot 2.Â  As a result, Ashley Engineering filed 
  a notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien in the amount of $7,533.57 on Lot 
  2A.Â  Ashley Engineering subsequently initiated a suit against TKS by filing 
  a summons and complaint, as well as a lis pendens.Â  The complaint 
  requested damages totaling $7,663.20 and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  TKS failed to answer 
  the complaint and an order of default was entered.Â  
At a damages hearing, TKS 
  challenged the sufficiency of Ashley Engineeringâ€™s service of process through 
  a motion to set aside default, but the trial court found service was proper.Â  
  Additionally, damages were set at $7,800.00 for labor, $675.00 for accrued interest, 
  and $4,494.00 for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  By consent of the parties, the amount of 
  damages was later amended to $7,573.57. 
Prior to the amendment of 
  the damages, TKS entered a bond in the amount of $10,098.08 and requested that 
  the court amend its order to substitute the cash bond entirely for the real 
  property pursuant to section 29-5-110 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003).Â  
  Ashley Engineering objected to the substitution because it would leave a portion 
  of its $12,969.00 judgment unsecured by either the bond or the real property.Â  
  The trial court agreed and determined it would be inequitable to allow the bond 
  to be substituted entirely for the real property.Â  TKS appeals this decision.
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.     
Service of Process  
TKS argues the trial court 
  erred by not setting aside the default judgment because the summons and complaint 
  regarding the mechanicâ€™s lien was not appropriately served.Â  We disagree. 
When the sufficiency of 
  the service of process is challenged, the findings of the trial court are binding 
  on the appellate court unless they are wholly unsupported by the evidence or 
  manifestly influenced or controlled by an error of law.Â  Brown v. Carolina 
  Emergency Physicians, P.A., 348 S.C. 569, 583, 560 S.E.2d 624, 631 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).
Ashley Engineering served 
  TKS on April 23, 2002 by delivering the summons and complaint to TKSâ€™s registered 
  office for service of process, which at that time was 100 Crowfield Boulevard, 
  Goose Creek, South Carolina.Â  Agent Owned Realty, however, occupied this address.Â  
  In the past, Agent Owned Realty had employed Soritoglou, TKSâ€™s president, sole-shareholder, 
  and registered agent of service; however, he had since left the agency.Â  Soritoglou 
  operated TKS out of Agent Owned Realtyâ€™s office until January 2002.Â  As late 
  as April 12, 2002, TKS sent a facsimile transmission to Ashley Engineering listing 
  100 Crowfield Boulevard as its address on its letterhead.Â  Furthermore, it was 
  not uncommon for Soritoglou to receive mail at Agent Owned Realty, even after 
  he quit working there.Â  In fact, the office had a procedure for handling ex-agentsâ€™ 
  mail whereby the mail was placed in an envelope for the agent to pick up, and 
  if after some time the agent had not come to get the envelope, it was mailed 
  to the agent.Â  Soritoglou admitted he still received mail at the Crowfield address 
  and occasionally retrieved his mail from there.Â  
When the process server 
  arrived at 100 Crowfield Boulevard, Kelly Poston, Agent Owned Realtyâ€™s secretary, 
  told her that Soritoglou no longer worked at the office.Â  Poston then offered 
  to call Soritoglou for the process server.Â  Soritoglou admits that during the 
  telephone conversation he told the process server that she could leave the legal 
  papers at Agent Owned Realty.Â  After the telephone call, the process server 
  told Poston she had been instructed by Soritoglou to leave the legal papers 
  with her and Poston accepted them.Â  Soritoglou denies receiving the papers.
Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP, allows 
  for service of a corporation â€œby delivering a copy of the summons and complaint 
  to an officer, a managing or general agent, or to any other agent authorized 
  by appointment or by law to receive service of process . . . .â€Â  Ashley Engineering 
  served the summons and complaint at the registered address for service of process 
  after being told by Soritoglou, the registered agent for service of process, 
  that the legal papers could be left at that location. 
â€œAccording to . . . state rules . . . , service 
  of process may be made upon an individual by delivering a copy of the summons 
  and of the complaint to an agent authorized by appointment to receive service 
  of process.Â  This provision was intended to cover the situation where an individual 
  actually appoints an agent for the purpose of receiving service.â€Â  Moore 
  v. Simpson, 322 S.C. 518, 523-24, 473 S.E.2d 64, 67 (Ct. App. 1996) 
  (citation omitted).Â  Through his actions and words, Soritoglou authorized Poston 
  to be an agent for service of process.Â  Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP, allows for this 
  authorization of an agent for service of process.Â  Therefore, the trial court 
  did not commit error by refusing to set aside the default judgment. 
  II.   Mechanicâ€™s Lien
TKS argues the trial court erred in concluding 
  that Ashley Engineering was entitled to a mechanicâ€™s lien because Ashley Engineering 
  had not performed any work relative to Lot 2A within 90 days of filing the mechanicâ€™s 
  lien as required by section 29-5-90 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003).Â  
  We disagree.Â  
â€œThe decision of whether to grant relief from an 
  entry of default is solely within the sound discretion of the trial court.â€Â  
  Top Value Homes, Inc. v. Harden, 319 S.C. 302, 306, 
  460 S.E.2d 427, 429 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œAn order based on an exercise of that 
  discretion, however, will be set aside if it is controlled by some error of 
  law or lacks evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.
Robert Locklair, the owner of Ashley Engineering, 
  testified that October 29, 2001 was the last date that Ashley Engineering did 
  any work for TKS.Â  Locklair testified that on that date Ashley Engineering obtained 
  approval from the Town of Summerville for their plat of the property that TKS 
  was contracting to purchase from Westvaco.Â  Ashley Engineering then filed its 
  mechanicâ€™s lien on November 8, 2001.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not err 
  in its decision because there was evidence that Ashley Engineering had completed 
  its work for TKS within 90 days of filing its mechanicâ€™s lien. 
  III.           Cash Bond
TKS argues the trial court 
  erred by refusing to release the subject property from the mechanicâ€™s lien because 
  they submitted a cash bond pursuant to section 29-5-110 of the South Carolina 
  Code (Supp. 2003).Â  We agree.Â  
The trial courtâ€™s decision 
  regarding a mechanicâ€™s lien will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse 
  of discretion.Â  Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc. v. Palmieri, 345 S.C. 
  550, 553, 548 S.E.2d 900, 901-02 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An abuse of discretion 
  occurs when the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is based upon an error of law.Â  Id.
Ashley Engineering submitted 
  a statement of account for $7,533.57 in work performed and interest on the unpaid 
  balance.Â  Later, at the damages hearing, the trial court set damages at $7,800.00 
  for labor, $675.00 for accrued interest, and $4,494.00 for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
  The amount of damages was later amended, by consent of the parties, to $7,573.57.
After the court had set 
  damages and attorneyâ€™s fees, TKS submitted a bond for $10,098.08, one and one-third 
  times the amount the court awarded as damages.Â  Subsequently, TKS asked the 
  trial court to amend its order to substitute the cash bond for the subject real 
  property.Â  Ashley Engineering objected, arguing the substitution would leave 
  $2,870.92 of its judgment unsecured.Â  The court agreed and refused to substitute 
  the cash bond because it would leave a substantial portion of Ashley Engineeringâ€™s 
  judgment uncovered by either bond or property.Â  The court determined that it 
  would be â€œunjust and inequitableâ€ to find that a lienorâ€™s property is secured 
  by only a general lien on the property, after the lienor has complied strictly 
  with all the requirements of the statute and enforced its lien all the way through 
  suit to judgment.Â  
Section 29-5-110 of the 
  South Carolina Code states that an owner may, at any time, secure the discharge 
  of the property from a mechanicâ€™s lien by filing an amount equal to one and 
  one-third times the amount claimed in the statement of account.Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 29-5-110 (Supp. 2003).Â  The use of the word â€œmayâ€ vests discretion in the 
  owner of the property to either submit a cash bond or suffer the lien.Â  TKS 
  availed itself of this statute by submitting an amount complying with the formula 
  in section 29-5-110.Â  
â€œWhen the terms of a statute 
  are clear, the court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.â€Â  
  Hinton v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services, 
  357 S.C. 327, 334, 592 S.E.2d 335, 339 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Section 29-5-110 does 
  not grant the courts discretion in discharging the property from the lien.Â  
  While it may be inequitable to apply the statute in such a way that the lienorâ€™s 
  full judgment is no longer secured and where attorneyâ€™s fees are effectively 
  capped at an amount no greater than the one-third of the total value of labor 
  listed in the statement of account, it is the application required by the statuteâ€™s 
  clear language.
Because a plain reading 
  of section 29-5-110 allows discharge of the lien in return for a cash bond set 
  at one and one-third the amount claimed in the statement of account, and TKS 
  submitted such bond, the trial court erred by refusing to substitute the cash 
  bond for the subject property.
  IV.           Damages
TKS argues the court erred 
  in awarding damages because Ashley Engineering was unable to specify what improvements 
  or work was performed on Lot 2A.Â  We disagree.Â  
In a foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien, the judgeâ€™s findings will not be disturbed unless they are without evidentiary 
  support.Â  Zepsa Constr., Inc. v. Randazzo, 356 S.C. 39, 43, 586 S.E.2d 
  599, 601 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The trial court found Ashley Engineering had 
  â€œconducted site and topographical surveysâ€ and â€œdeveloped designs for roads, 
  drainage, water sewer and grading for the propertyâ€ as to the entirety of Lot 
  2, from which Lot 2A was later carved.Â  Also, Ashley Engineeringâ€™s work revealed 
  that Lot 2A could be subdivided and built upon without additional infrastructure 
  such as roads, drainage, water, and sewer.Â  Furthermore, Ashley Engineering 
  determined where to separate Lot 2A from Lot 2 and where to divide the portion 
  into lots for building. 
Ashley Engineering contracted 
  with TKS to provide engineering services related to all of Lot 2, from which 
  Lot 2A was eventually divided.Â  TKS tries to escape a portion of the mechanicâ€™s 
  lien by demanding that Ashley Engineering specify what percentage of the work 
  was performed on Lot 2A as opposed to Lot 2.Â  The work Ashley Engineering performed 
  on the entire area, however, led to the conclusion that Lot 2A could be separated 
  from Lot 2. 
Testimony from Locklair 
  established the interconnectedness of the work done on Lot 2 and Lot 2A.Â  Locklair 
  testified the work was of such a degree that it was impossible to apportion 
  amounts of work between the lots.Â  This supports the trial courtâ€™s conclusion 
  that a mechanicâ€™s lien in the full amount could attach to Lot 2A, thus there 
  is abundant support in the record to support the judgeâ€™s factual findings.
Additionally, because we 
  affirm the trial courtâ€™s findings and attorneyâ€™s fees are authorized under the 
  mechanicâ€™s lien statute, the trial court did not err by awarding Ashley Engineering 
  attorneyâ€™s fees.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED 
  IN PART, AND REMANDED. 
 STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

of a valid mechanicâ€™s lien against First Calvary Bap

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Curley Wilson Green,       
Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
First Calvary Baptist Church of Rock Hill,       
Defendant and Third party Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
D.K. Construction Company of North Carolina, Inc.,       
Third Party Defendant,
Of whom First Calvary Baptist Church of Rock Hill is the,       
Appellant,
And D.K. Construction Company of North Carolina, Inc., is the,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John Buford Grier, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No.Â 
2004-UP-544
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  26, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William E. Whitney, Jr., of Union, for Appellant.
Wesley Dickinson Peel, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  DK Construction Company (DK) 
  of North Carolina sought foreclosure of a valid mechanicâ€™s lien against First 
  Calvary Baptist Church (First Calvary).Â  First Calvary raised defenses related 
  to setoff and indefiniteness.Â  The master-in-equity rejected the defenses and 
  foreclosed the mechanicâ€™s lien in favor of DK Construction.Â  First Calvary argues 
  the trial court erred in foreclosing the mechanicâ€™s lien. Â We affirm. 
    FACTS/PROCEDURAL
HISTORY  
  This action arises out of the 
    construction of the First Calvary Baptist Church in Rock Hill, South Carolina.Â  
    The parties settled all claims with the first party Plaintiff Curley Wilson 
    Green prior to trial.Â  
  First Calvary contracted with R. Jones 
    Construction Company, Inc. a/k/a Quad-State Group (Jones) to design and build 
    a new church building for the parish.Â  Jones encountered difficulties in completing 
    the construction project due to financial problems.Â  The project was already 
    behind the original schedule by the time Jones, as general contractor, contracted 
    with subcontractor DK Construction to provide all labor and materials necessary 
    to finish the project under Jonesâ€™ supervision.Â  All the parties were aware 
    of the project delays at the time that DK began work on the project.Â  No evidence 
    indicated that First Calvary intended to assess delay damages against the 
    contractors at the time DK entered the project.Â  
  DK contracted to complete the work for Jones 
    for the remaining contract balance, including the retainages held by First 
    Calvary.Â  Moreover, by agreement of DK, Jones, and First Calvary, DK would 
    be paid for additional work outside of the subcontract by change orders approved 
    by the project architect.Â  At the time DK subcontracted with Jones the only 
    work completed on the project was the foundation, slab, and plumbing work. 
  
  DK satisfactorily performed its obligation under 
    the contract with Jones and the project architect approved DKâ€™s work on the 
    project.Â  DK presented its final bill to First Calvary through Jones in the 
    amount of $52,436.00.Â  The amount of the final bill consisted of $12,886.00 
    in change orders and $39,550.00 in work related to the original contract.Â  
    Moreover, the project architect approved DKâ€™s final request for payment in 
    the amount of $52,436.00.Â  Neither Jones nor DK received the final payment 
    due from First Calvary.Â  First Calvary concedes that it owes DK the $12,886.00 
    from the final change order.Â  First Calvary also holds $39,550.00 related 
    to the original contract.Â  
  First Calvary asserted at trial the defenses 
    of setoff and delay to DKâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  The court found that based upon 
    the testimony, DK agreed to perform work for Jones for the remaining contract 
    balance including any retainages held by First Calvary and that the retainages 
    were owed to DK under that contract.Â  The trial court also concluded as a 
    matter of law that DK filed and perfected a mechanicâ€™s lien pursuant to section 
    29-5-20 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003) and is entitled to foreclose 
    on the lien in the amount of $52,436.00 plus interest, costs, and attorneyâ€™s 
    fees.Â  The court rejected the defenses of setoff and delay.Â  First Calvary 
    appeals only the amount foreclosed under the mechanicâ€™s lien [1] . Â We affirm.Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
  An action to foreclose a mechanicâ€™s 
    lien is an action at law in South Carolina.Â  Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc. 
    v. Palmieri, 345 S.C. 550, 553, 548 S.E.2d 900, 901 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
    In an action at law, tried without a jury, the judgeâ€™s findings will not be 
    disturbed by the appellate court unless they are without evidentiary support.Â  
    King v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 317 S.C. 385, 388, 453 S.E.2d 885, 
    888 (1995).Â  The judgeâ€™s findings are equivalent to those of a jury in an 
    action at law.Â  Id. at 389, 453 S.E.2d at 888.Â  
  LAW/ANALYSIS
  The issue before this court is whether 
    the trial court erred in foreclosing DKâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  The South Carolina 
    Mechanicâ€™s Lien Statute provides that â€œ[e]very laborer, mechanic, subcontractor, 
    or person furnishing material for the improvement of real estate when the 
    improvement has been authorized by the owner has a lien thereon, subject . 
    . . to the value of the labor or material so furnished . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code 
    Ann. Â§ 29-5-20 (Supp. 2003).Â  Section 29-5-20 protects the mechanic or supplier 
    who deals with a general contractor or some person other than the owner or 
    his agent.Â  T.W. Morton Builders, Inc. v. von Buedingen, 316 S.C. 388, 
    400, 450 S.E.2d 87, 94 (Ct. App. 1994) (A manifest purpose of Section 29-5-20 
    is â€œthe protection of one not a party to a contract with the owner, who furnishes 
    labor or material in the improvement of the ownerâ€™s property, by giving him 
    a lien for such labor or material.â€).Â  
  First Calvaryâ€™s main argument is that 
    the trial court erred in foreclosing the mechanicâ€™s lien since the lien was 
    not related to work performed or materials provided by DK and, therefore, 
    outside the definition provided in Section 29-5-20.Â  We find this argument 
    to be without merit.Â  There is ample evidence in the record to support the 
    courtâ€™s decision that the amount of the lien related directly to DKâ€™s work 
    performed and materials furnished for the benefit of First Calvary.Â  
  Jones brought DK into the project to furnish 
    all labor and materials necessary for the completion of the church.Â  DK performed 
    its obligation under the contract with Jones and the project architect approved 
    DKâ€™s work on the project.Â  First Calvary admits holding the contract balance 
    due to Jones, which, in turn, is owed to DK pursuant to DKâ€™s subcontract.Â  
    We find that the master-in-equity correctly foreclosed the lien in the amount 
    of $52,436.00. [2]   
  AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â  
   STILWELL, BEATTY, AND SHORT, JJ., 
    concur.

 
   
    [1]  First Calvary does not appeal any issues relating to their defenses 
    of setoff or the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, interest, and costs.

 
   
    [2]  In the Appellantâ€™s Brief, First Calvary also contends that the trial 
    court erred in awarding damages on the basis of quantum meruit.Â  
    Since we held that the trial court properly foreclosed the mechanicâ€™s lien 
    of DK for the full amount sought, we need not address this issue.Â  Moreover, 
    the trial court did not award damages based on quantum meruit; 
    the sole basis of recovery for DK was limited to foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s 
    lien.Â  Therefore, the issue is manifestly without merit.Â  Rule 220(b)(2), 
    SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
City of Greenwood,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Phillip W. Whiteside,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-545
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  27, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles M. Watson, Jr., of Greenwood, for Appellant.Â  
Solicitor William Townes Jones, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Philip W. Whiteside appeals 
  the circuit courtâ€™s order upholding his conviction for violating a city noise 
  ordinance.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Whiteside served as president of his social 
  fraternity and lived in a house along with four of his fraternity brothers in 
  the City of Greenwood, South Carolina.Â  On the evening of February 12, 2003, 
  the brothers hosted a fraternity-sponsored house party and played music for 
  their guests on a stereo.Â  The stereo belonged to one of the four brothers who 
  shared the house with Whiteside, who was present at the party.Â  Police officers 
  testified they could hear music and loud voices coming from the house approximately 
  one and a half lots away.Â  
After determining the music was too loud, two police 
  officers went to the house and asked some party guests to speak with the person 
  in charge.Â  They summoned Whiteside, who came onto the porch and spoke with 
  the officers.Â  When asked by the officers, Whiteside affirmed he was in charge 
  of the house.Â  He was then issued a citation for violation of the city noise 
  ordinance.Â  
The municipal court denied Whitesideâ€™s motion for 
  directed verdict and found him guilty of violating section 18-62 of the city 
  noise ordinance after determining there was â€œdirect and circumstantial evidence 
  that indicated that [Whiteside] was in charge of the property in which the music 
  was being emitted.â€Â  The court â€œadvised [Whiteside] that not only was the charge 
  proper against him, but could also be brought against the other three persons 
  who reside at this location and were present on this evening when this charge 
  was made.â€Â  
Whiteside appealed to the circuit court, arguing the 
  judge erred in declining to grant a directed verdict because there was no evidence 
  he either maintained or operated the stereo and therefore the ordinance was 
  inapplicable to him as a matter of law.Â  The circuit court disagreed and upheld 
  the conviction, finding Whiteside â€œwas sufficiently in charge of the premises 
  at issue to be deemed criminally responsible for the violation of City Ordinance 
  18-62, even though there was no specific evidence admitted that [Whiteside] 
  personally operated the radio, or that the radio was his personal property.â€Â  
  The court determined that as fraternity president, Whiteside was in â€œa position 
  of special responsibility over the premisesâ€ and was â€œresponsible for the consequence 
  of unreasonable noise arising from the music being played.â€Â  
DISCUSSION
Whiteside contends the circuit court erred by affirming the 
  denial of his directed verdict motion arguing there was no evidence he owned 
  or operated the stereo.Â  He claims the circuit court improperly held him responsible, 
  as fraternity president, for the acts of his unidentified fraternity brother 
  and housemate who also attended the party and owned and operated the stereo.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
â€œIn criminal appeals from magistrate or municipal 
  court, the circuit court does not conduct a de novo review, but instead 
  reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate exception.Â  In reviewing 
  criminal cases, this court may review errors of law only.â€ Â State v. Henderson, 
  347 S.C. 455, 457, 556 S.E.2d 691, 692 (Ct. App. 2001) (internal citations omitted).Â  
  On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, an appellate court shall view 
  the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Walker, 
  349 S.C. 49, 53, 562 S.E.2d 313, 315 (2002).Â  This court will affirm the denial 
  of a directed verdict motion if there is any direct evidence or substantial 
  circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused.Â  
  State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653, 572 S.E.2d 267, 273 (2002).Â  
Section 18-62(a), Code of Ordinances for the City 
  of Greenwood, provides in relevant part,

It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to maintain 
  and operate . . . from any building, any public place or on any premises whatsoever 
  within the city, any radio or device of any kind which is designed to amplify, 
  or does in fact, amplify sound and/or music whereby the sound created therefrom 
  creates unreasonably loud excessive or disturbing noises[.]Â  

All parties acknowledge Whiteside neither 
  owned the stereo nor personally played the loud music heard by the officers.Â  
  However, as the person who accepted responsibility over the house, Whiteside 
  co-hosted a party where the stereo located in the house living room was used 
  to play music for the entertainment of his guests.Â  When the officers arrived 
  to investigate the source of the loud noise and asked to speak with the person 
  in charge, guests summoned Whiteside to meet them.Â  Finally, in his conversation 
  with the officers, Whiteside acknowledged he was in charge of the house.Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the 
  State, we conclude there was substantial circumstantial evidence that Whiteside 
  was responsible for the maintenance and operation of the stereo during the party.Â  
  As a result, his motion for directed verdict was properly denied.Â  State 
  v. Williams, 321 S.C. 327, 332-33, 468 S.E.2d 626, 629 (1996) (â€œIn ruling 
  on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial judge is concerned with the existence 
  of evidence, not with its weight.Â  When [an appellate court] reviews the denial 
  of a motion for a directed verdict, it views the evidence in the light most 
  favorable to the non-moving party, and if there is any direct or substantial 
  circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, 
  refusal by the trial judge to direct a verdict is not error.â€) (internal citations 
  omitted).Â  
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Willie D. Reaves,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Franklin C. Reaves,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marion County
Mary E. Buchan, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-546
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  27, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Franklin C. Reaves, Appellant, Pro Se.
Willie D. Reaves, Respondent, Pro Se.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Franklin C. Reaves appeals 
  from a bench warrant the family court issued upon his alleged failure to appear 
  as directed by a Rule to Show Cause and his failure to pay alimony.Â  The bench 
  warrant ordered that Reaves must pay his account current and court costs on 
  or before his release.Â  We affirm [1]  pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR, 
  and the following authorities:Â  Watson v. Watson, 319 S.C. 92, 93, 460 
  S.E.2d 394, 395 (1995) (â€œSubject matter jurisdiction refers to the courtâ€™s power 
  to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in 
  question belong.â€); Coon v. Coon, 356 S.C. 342, 588 S.E.2d 624, 628 (Ct. 
  App. 2003) (stating that as a general rule where there is no lack of subject 
  matter jurisdiction, the courtâ€™s judgment will be binding, even if affected 
  by irregularity which would have defeated the proceeding if objection had been 
  timely and properly made); Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 629 576 S.E.2d 
  156, 165 (2003) (â€œObjections to personal jurisdiction, unlike subject matter 
  jurisdiction, are waived unless raised.â€); Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 
  S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot 
  be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled 
  upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); In re McCracken, 
  346 S.C. 87, 92, 551 S.E.2d 235, 238 (2001) (stating a constitutional claim 
  must be raised and ruled upon to be preserved for appellate review).
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and KITTREDGE, 
  JJ., concur.Â  

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James Randall Smith,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Karen P. Smith,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
H. E. Bonnoitt, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-547
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  27, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Margaret D. Fabri, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Robert Wade Maring, of Georgetown, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  Karen P. Smith (the mother) 
  appeals the order of the family court finding her in contempt for withholding 
  the partiesâ€™ children from a scheduled visitation with James R. Smith (the father).Â  
  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
The parties were divorced on October 31, 2002.Â  
  Pursuant to the terms of the decree, the mother was granted custody of the partiesâ€™ 
  two daughters with liberal visitation to the father.Â  The girls exercised visitation 
  with their father without incident until July of 2003.Â  
After the girls returned from visitation with the 
  father from June 20, 2003 to July 4, 2003, the mother discovered the older daughter 
  had a bald spot at the top of her head caused by her pulling her own hair out.Â  
  The mother called the father that night, July 7, 2003, and they discussed the 
  situation.Â  The younger girl had told the father about the older daughterâ€™s 
  actions during their visitation with him.Â  According to the mother, the father 
  told her that he â€œwasnâ€™t too concerned about itâ€ because he himself had developed 
  obsessive-type habits when he was a child.Â  The father, however, testified that 
  he planned on asking Patricia Carter, the girlâ€™s therapist about the condition 
  when they met for a scheduled family counseling session on Thursday, July 10, 
  2003.Â  On that Thursday, the mother instead took the girls to an appointment 
  with Michael Kollar, Ed.D., a licensed clinical psychologist that the girls 
  had been seeing for individual counseling, who made the diagnosis of trichotillomania. [2] Â  Without first calling the father, the mother cancelled the 
  family counseling session that was scheduled for that evening.Â  Later that evening, 
  the father called the motherâ€™s house and spoke to the older daughter.Â  The mother 
  testified that after the call, the older daughter began crying and pulling out 
  her hair for much of the night, saying she didnâ€™t want to go to visitation with 
  her father.Â  
The following day the mother left a note in the 
  fatherâ€™s mailbox stating that she was refusing to produce the children for the 
  visitation that was to start that day, July 11, 2003, and to end on July 25, 
  2003.Â  The father attempted to pick up the children that evening with the assistance 
  of a sheriffâ€™s deputy.Â  Although the older daughter was home, the younger daughter 
  was at a friendâ€™s house.Â  The father left without either girl.Â  As the mother 
  knew, the father had planned to take the children on a vacation to the Bahamas 
  during this visitation period.Â  The trip was to commence on July 15.Â  As a result 
  of not being able to start his visitation with the girls, the father had to 
  buy replacement airline tickets and also had to pay another veterinarian who 
  had contracted with him to cover for him at work during the vacation days missed.Â  

The father filed an Emergency Rule to Show Cause 
  on July 14, 2003.Â  The motherâ€™s attorney accepted service on her behalf by fax 
  on the same date.Â  Although the mother was never personally served, she appeared 
  at the hearing and agreed to go forward on the Rule.Â  
At the hearing, the mother introduced evidence 
  in the form of an affidavit prepared by Dr. Kollar advising that the older daughter 
  had begun suffering from trichotillomania.Â  In the affidavit, Dr. Kollar recommended 
  that the older daughter be evaluated by a pediatrician and also advised that 
  the mother should not â€œphysically forc[e]â€ the daughters to visit the father 
  if they did not want to go.Â  
After hearing all the evidence, the trial judge found 
  that the mother had improperly denied visitation to the father and was in willful 
  contempt.Â  The judge stated that the mother had â€œeither manipulated [the] children 
  or allow[ed] them to manipulate her.â€Â  The court ordered the mother to be incarcerated 
  for a period of 60 days and to pay a fine of $1500.00.Â  However, the court allowed 
  the mother to purge these sanctions in the following manner: (1) by delivering 
  the children to the father for visitation on the following day; (2) by paying 
  $2,039.00 to the father for the cost of the replacement airline tickets; (3) 
  by paying $1050.00 to the father for the substitute veterinarian to cover his 
  practice during the time he would have been on the vacation; and (4) by paying 
  a $750 fine to the Georgetown County Clerk of Court.Â  Additionally, the mother 
  was ordered to pay attorney fees and costs in the amount of $2126.70.
This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A finding of contempt rests within the family courtâ€™s 
  sound discretion.Â  Haselden v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 63, 552 S.E.2d 
  329, 337 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  This court will reverse the family courtâ€™s determination 
  regarding contempt only if it is without evidentiary support or is an abuse 
  of discretion.Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Finding of Willful Contempt
The mother first argues that the family 
  court erred in finding her in willful contempt for withholding visitation.Â  
  We disagree.
A party may be found in contempt of court for willfully 
  violating, neglecting, or refusing to obey or perform a lawful court order.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2003).Â  An act is willful if it is â€œdone voluntarily 
  and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, 
  or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; 
  that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€ Spartanburg 
  County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 
  874 (1988).Â  â€œBefore a court may find a person in contempt, the record must 
  clearly and specifically reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€Â  Henderson v. 
  Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 197, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1994).Â  To show contempt 
  for violation of a court order, the moving party must prove the existence of 
  a court order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with 
  the order.Â  Eaddy v. Oliver, 345 S.C. 39, 42, 545 S.E.2d 830, 832 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).Â  Once a prima facie showing has been made, â€œthe burden shifts to 
  the respondent to establish his defense and inability to comply.â€Â  Id.Â  

The mother does not dispute the existence of the 
  court order or her noncompliance with the order.Â  Instead, she argues that the 
  family court failed to give proper weight to the evidence establishing her defense.Â  

The mother relies on Nash v. Byrd, 298 S.C. 
  530, 381 S.E.2d 913 (Ct. App. 1989), for the proposition that unilateral withholding 
  of visitation in violation of a court order does not constitute contempt of 
  court where a child is suffering from the ill effects of the conduct of the 
  opposing parent.Â  In Nash, this court found that the father had â€œengaged 
  in a course of conduct calculated to harass the mother and gain information 
  to support a change of custody.â€Â  Id. at 532, 381 S.E.2d at 914.Â  The 
  father and his family stalked the mother, made derogatory remarks toward or 
  about her in front of the child, and encouraged the child to make false allegations 
  of abuse and neglect against the mother.Â  The child developed gastrointestinal 
  problems as a result of anxiety caused by the fatherâ€™s actions.Â  He eventually 
  refused to go with his father for scheduled visitation.Â  Prior to the cessation 
  in visitation, the wife had brought two actions for modification of visitation 
  and restraining orders due to the father and his familyâ€™s conduct.Â  The family 
  court denied the fatherâ€™s action to have the mother held in contempt for refusing 
  visitation.Â  In affirming the family court, this court found the family court 
  did not abuse its discretion in concluding that the problems were caused by 
  the father and that the mother had taken all reasonable steps to resolve the 
  problems.Â  Id. at 534, 381 S.E.2d at 916.
We find Nash clearly distinguishable from 
  the present case.Â  Here, the mother waited until the day the father was to start 
  an extended visitation, which she knew included a vacation to the Bahamas, before 
  dropping the letter off to the father informing him that he would not have his 
  visitation with his daughters.Â  Furthermore, unlike in Nash, there is 
  no evidence of wrongful conduct by the father causing ill effects on the older 
  daughter.Â  According to Dr. Kollar, the older daughter was experiencing distress 
  thinking about going to her fatherâ€™s for visitation.Â  He stated that she related 
  feeling powerless because she has little to say in what she and her sister do 
  during visitation.Â  She also told him that she was distressed because her father 
  does not allow her to go to the barn where the girls take riding lessons and 
  she was afraid he would not allow her to participate in upcoming horse shows.Â  
  Dr. Kollar did not advise that the father not be allowed to visit with his daughters.Â  
  Rather, Dr. Kollar stated that the mother should not have to physically force 
  the daughters to go to their father.Â  He explained that it was up to the father 
  to work out these issues with the children in family therapy.Â  
We note the motherâ€™s interference with the fatherâ€™s 
  visitation was not unexpected.Â  In the divorce decree, the family court stated 
  that it shared the fatherâ€™s concern that the mother had attempted to alienate 
  the childrenâ€™s affections from him in order to receive custody.Â  The court found:

The Wife is a very bright and well-organized woman who can 
  be very indiscreet when she sets her mind on achieving a desired result.Â  She 
  will do almost anything to get what she wants.Â  There is also an indication 
  that the Wife has tried to interfere with the Husbandâ€™s visitation with his 
  daughters.Â  This Court is concerned that if the Wife is awarded custody, the 
  Husbandâ€™s relationship with his daughters and their relationship with him will 
  suffer, especially if the Husband were to remarry.Â  

Despite these expressed reservations, the family 
  court awarded the mother custody, but granted the father more than standard 
  visitation to aid him in fostering a closer relationship with his daughters.Â  

We hold the family court did not abuse its discretion 
  in determining the mother had willfully withheld visitation from the father.Â  
  As the family court found, the mother had failed to introduce evidence to support 
  the allegation that the older child suffered harm as a result of visitation 
  with the father, and further found that she had offered no credible evidence 
  as to why she had denied visitation of the youngest child.Â  Moreover, as the 
  family court noted, the mother did not call the situation to the attention of 
  the court before taking action.Â  Instead, she acted unilaterally and in knowing 
  violation of the court order.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court did not 
  err in holding the mother in willful contempt.Â  
II. Procedural Due Process Violation
The mother argues that she was denied procedural 
  due process in that she was never personally served with the Rule to Show Cause, 
  and that the hearing was held less than 24 hours after she received notice of 
  the hearing.Â  As the mother admits in her reply brief, she did not contest the 
  personal jurisdiction of the family court and did not make a formal motion for 
  a continuance.Â  While the mother did request and obtain a ruling as to whether 
  the affidavit of Dr. Kollar would be admitted into evidence in part on the grounds 
  that Dr. Kollar himself was unavailable on such short notice, the mother did 
  not object to the fairness of the hearing itself on due process grounds.Â  Accordingly, 
  we find the motherâ€™s argument is not preserved.Â  See Bakala v. Bakala, 
  352 S.C. 612, 625, 576 S.E.2d 156, 163 (2003) (â€œA due process claim raised for 
  the first time on appeal is not preserved.â€).
III. Excessive Fees, Costs, and Fines
The motherâ€™s final argument is that the fees, costs, 
  and fines imposed by the family court were excessive.Â  
The mother challenges the family courtâ€™s imposition 
  of a fine payable to the court contending the imposition of a criminal sanction 
  was inappropriate and excessive in a civil contempt proceeding.Â  There is no 
  indication in the record that the mother raised this issue to the family court 
  at the hearing or in a post-trial motion.Â  Accordingly, it is not preserved.Â  
  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt 
  is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but 
  must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for 
  appellate review.â€); Pelican Bldg. Ctrs. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 60, 
  427 S.E.2d 673, 675 (1993) (stating that although the appellant learned for 
  the first time upon receiving the order on a post-trial motion that the respondent 
  would be granted certain additional relief, the appellant must move under Rule 
  59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment to â€œpreserve the record for appealâ€).
The mother next contends the family courtâ€™s award of 
  costs and attorneyâ€™s fees to the father was not supported by the record. This 
  issue is not properly before this court because the wife failed to present this 
  issue in her statement of the issues on appeal.Â  See Rule 208(b)(1)(B), 
  SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered which is not set forth in the 
  statement of the issues on appeal.â€).Â Â Â  
Furthermore, the mother failed to raise several of 
  the points contained in this section of her brief to the family court.Â  The 
  mother complains on appeal that the father was not entitled to reimbursement 
  for the veterinary help he had hired because it was an expense he would have 
  incurred even if visitation had begun as scheduled.Â  The mother never argued 
  to the family court that the father was not entitled to this expense.Â  Accordingly, 
  it is not preserved.Â  See Wilder Corp., 330 S.C. at 76, 497 S.E.2d 
  at 733.
Similarly, the mother never argued to the family court 
  that the father was not entitled to all of his attorneyâ€™s fees, nor did she 
  object to the admission of the fatherâ€™s affidavit of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Thus, 
  this issue is not preserved.Â  See Id. at 76, 497 S.E.2d at 733.Â  
  Moreover, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees to 
  the father.Â  A contemnor may be required to reimburse a complainant for the 
  costs he or she incurred in enforcing the courtâ€™s prior order, including reasonable 
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Poston v. Poston, 331 S.C. 106, 114, 502 S.E.2d 86, 
  90 (1998).Â  â€œIt is well settled that an award of attorney fees is within the 
  sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse 
  of that discretion.â€Â  Smith v. Smith, 308 S.C. 492, 496, 419 S.E.2d 232, 
  234-35 (Ct. App. 1992).Â Â Â  
Finally, the mother argues the family court erred in 
  awarding the father $2,039.00 for having to change his airline tickets to the 
  Bahamas.Â  She asserts there is no indication that the tickets were non-refundable.Â  
  The father explained that he was not able to change the tickets because he did 
  not know when he was going to get the children and be able to leave for the 
  Bahamas.Â  The father presented into evidence the airline tickets and his testimony 
  of the expenses he had incurred due to the change of departure date.Â  
â€œCompensatory contempt is a money award for the 
  plaintiff when the defendant has injured the plaintiff by violating a previous 
  court order.â€Â  Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 386, 287 S.E.2d 915, 919 
  (1982).Â  The goal of compensatory contempt awards is to restore the plaintiff 
  as nearly as possible to his or her original position.Â  Id.Â  We hold 
  the family court judge did not err in finding that these expenses were reasonable 
  and necessary to restore the father to his original position.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the above reasons, we hold the order of 
  the family court is
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â  


 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  According to Dr. Kollar, trichotillomania is a 
    self-destructive behavior involving the recurrent pulling of oneâ€™s hair as 
    a means of relief from anxiety.Â

PER CURIAM:Â  Mark Francis Stewart appeals 
  the family courtâ€™s denial of his Rule 60(b)(3), SCRCP, motion for relief from

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Tyson Mack,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-549
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  27, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia, and Solicitor 
  Cecil Kelley Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tyson Mack appeals his second-degree 
  burglary conviction, arguing the trial court erred in refusing to grant him 
  a directed verdict.Â  We affirm. [1] 
BACKGROUND
Officers Evans and Kearney of the Sumter 
  Police Department were dispatched to a sportswear store at 4:20 a.m.Â  When they 
  arrived at the store, they learned it had been broken into and clothing had 
  been removed.Â  They immediately began a search of the area and quickly located 
  Mack in a nearby vacant lot.Â  He was carrying a large trash bag, sweating, and 
  breathing heavily.Â  The officers stopped and as Evans approached, Mack dropped 
  the bag, which contained a large amount of clothes on hangers with the tags 
  still on them.Â  The officers then arrested Mack.Â  The police later showed the 
  clothes to the storeâ€™s owner, who identified them as his merchandise.Â  
DISCUSSION
Mack concedes the State presented evidence 
  he was guilty of receiving or possessing stolen goods and does not dispute the 
  sportswear store was burglarized.Â  However, he contends he was entitled to a 
  directed verdict on the burglary charge because the State failed to establish 
  he was the person who broke into the store.Â  We find the court properly denied 
  Mackâ€™s motion.
In ruling on a directed verdict motion, 
  the trial court is concerned with the existence of evidence, rather than with 
  its weight.Â  State v. Mitchell, 341 S.C. 406, 409, 535 S.E.2d 126, 127 
  (2000).Â  â€œA defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails 
  to produce any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence of the offense 
  charged.â€Â  State v. Rothschild, 351 S.C. 238, 243, 569 S.E.2d 346, 348 
  (2002).Â  Where the evidence is circumstantial, the court must submit the case 
  to the jury if there is substantial evidence that reasonably tends to prove 
  the defendantâ€™s guilt or from which guilt can be logically deduced.Â  State 
  v. Williams, 321 S.C. 327, 332, 468 S.E.2d 626, 629 (1996).Â  On appeal from 
  the denial of a directed verdict, this court reviews the evidence in the light 
  most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  State v. Asbury, 328 S.C. 187, 
  194, 493 S.E.2d 349, 353 (1997).Â  
In State v. Shields, 217 S.C. 496, 61 S.E.2d 
  56 (1950), our supreme court affirmed the denial of a directed verdict on a 
  burglary charge where the defendant was found in possession of recently stolen 
  goods taken during an undisputed burglary.Â  
Here, as in Shields, Mack was found in possession 
  of recently stolen goods taken during an undisputed burglary.Â  The incident 
  occurred in the very early hours of the morning, and the officers responding 
  to the complaint arrived at the scene quickly.Â  They spotted Mack approximately 
  a block away from the burglarized business and the record contains no evidence 
  any other individual was in the vicinity at that time.Â  When the officers approached 
  Mack, he dropped the large bag he was carrying, which contained the stolen clothes, 
  still on hangers and bearing the storeâ€™s tags.Â  Viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the State, this constitutes substantial evidence from which Mackâ€™s guilt 
  could be deduced.Â  Thus the trial court properly submitted the charge to the 
  jury.
AFFIRMED.
Stilwell, Beatty, and Short, JJ., concur. 

 
   
    [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE
