  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
John David Lee and Kathleen Newman Lee,       
Respondents/Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Robert Allen Bunch,       
Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-550
Heard September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed October 27, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Donnell G. Jennings and R. Hawthorne Barrett, both of Columbia, 
  for Appellant-Respondent.
Stephen B. Samuels and Joseph R. Dasta, both of Lexington, 
  for Respondents-Appellants.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This action arises from a traffic 
  accident involving John David Lee (Lee) and Robert Allen Bunch.Â  Lee, his wife 
  Kathleen Newman Lee (Mrs. Lee), and Bunch appeal, challenging various rulings 
  of the trial court.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial.
FACTS
The traffic accident between Lee and Bunch 
  occurred on September 19, 1997, at approximately 10:30 p.m. While riding his 
  motorcycle on Old Dunbar Road, Lee collided with a Cadillac El Dorado driven 
  by Bunch.Â  Leeâ€™s motorcycle hit the driverâ€™s side of the Cadillac, which was 
  situated perpendicularly across the road.Â  Bunch was uninjured by the accident 
  and exited the vehicle through the passenger-side door.Â  Lee, however, was seriously 
  injured.
At trial, the parties presented contradictory accounts 
  of how the accident happened. Bunch testified that on the evening of the accident, 
  his then-fiancÃ©e, Joanne Hankinson, called him at his sisterâ€™s house and asked 
  him to bring her dinner and a tube of lip-stick to the bar where she worked, 
  Johnny Bâ€™s.Â  Bunch borrowed his sisterâ€™s Cadillac, purchased the lipstick at 
  a grocery store near the bar, and proceeded down Old Dunbar Road to the bar.Â  
  He stated he was attempting to make a wide left turn into the parking lot of 
  Johnny Bâ€™s when Leeâ€™s motorcycle collided with the car.Â  In his deposition, 
  Bunch testified that it was still daylight when the accident occurred.Â  At trial, 
  he vacillated on the time from when he borrowed the Cadillac until the accident 
  occurred.Â  
Lee testified that he had left a family birthday 
  celebration at Murrayâ€™s, a bar and grill, shortly before the accident occurred.Â  
  He stated that he remembered seeing a moving blur shortly before everything 
  went black but he did not remember the impact at all.Â  Gregory Jones and Chong 
  Abernathy, who witnessed the accident, testified about what they observed that 
  night.Â  Abernathy testified that when she and Jones left the bar Abernathy owned 
  between 7:00 and 7:30 that evening to go to dinner, Bunchâ€™s Cadillac was parked 
  on the shoulder of the road in front of a mailbox.Â  When they returned from 
  dinner several hours later, the Cadillac was still parked there.Â Â  Abernathy 
  and Jones testified the Cadillac slowly pulled into the road.Â  Abernathy stated 
  it appeared that the driver of the Cadillac was attempting a U-turn when the 
  accident happened.Â  
An ambulance arrived at approximately 
  10:45 p.m.Â  Though slightly disoriented, Mr. Lee was conscious and related pain 
  he felt as the emergency medical technicians (E.M.T.â€™s) splinted his arms and 
  legs.Â  While the E.M.T.â€™s were tending to Mr. Leeâ€™s injuries, Trooper Paul Allen 
  Nelson of the South Carolina Highway Patrol arrived on the scene and began investigating 
  the accident by observing the condition of the vehicles, their relative positions 
  on the road, and the debris caused by the impact.Â  Trooper Nelson later met 
  with Lee after he had been taken by ambulance to the emergency room.Â  During 
  their conversation at the hospital, Trooper Nelson smelled alcohol on Lee and 
  asked whether he had been drinking prior to the accident.Â  Lee responded in 
  the affirmative.Â  Trooper Nelson arranged for a sample of Leeâ€™s blood to be 
  taken by hospital personnel and tested by SLED for alcohol content.Â  The test 
  indicated Lee had a blood alcohol level of 0.036%.Â  
Lee had numerous broken bones, a head 
  injury, and severe injury to his groin area.Â  He spent ten days in the hospital 
  and several months recuperating while he and his family lived with his parents.Â  
  Because of his injuries, he was not able to return to his job performing home 
  remodeling and interior repair work with his father.Â  Instead, he became a licensed 
  cosmetologist and works in his motherâ€™s salon.Â  
On March 28, 2000, Lee and his wife, Kathleen 
  Newman Lee, brought suit against Bunch 
  [1]  in the Orangeburg County Court of Common Pleas, alleging Bunch negligently 
  pulled out from a parking space into the roadway, thereby causing the accident 
  and Leeâ€™s resulting injuries.Â  Mrs. Lee sought to recover for loss of consortium.Â  
  While Bunch denied all allegations of negligence in his answer, the pleading 
  contained no assertion of comparative negligence as an affirmative defense.Â  

Prior to trial, the Lees moved to exclude 
  any evidence of Leeâ€™s consumption of alcohol before the accident.Â  The trial 
  court denied the motion, ruling testimony of alcohol consumption would be probative 
  as to the determination of liability.Â  At trial, after Lee testified, Bunch 
  moved to amend his answer to include the affirmative defense of comparative 
  negligence.Â  In support of the motion, Bunchâ€™s trial counsel noted that Lee 
  testified that he had consumed alcohol and testimony of other witnesses corroborated 
  the fact.Â  The trial court granted the motion.Â  
After deliberating, the jury returned a verdict 
  of comparative negligence, assigning 70% of the fault to Lee and 30% to Bunch.Â  
  Having found Lee more than 50% at fault, the jury awarded no damages to Lee.Â  
  The jury also returned a defense verdict on Mrs. Leeâ€™s claim for loss of consortium.Â  
  Counsel for the Lees argued the verdicts were inconsistent in that Mrs. Lee 
  was entitled to recover damages on account of the juryâ€™s finding that Bunch 
  was partially negligent on Leeâ€™s claim.Â  The judge agreed and ordered the jury 
  to resume deliberations with instructions to award some amount of damages to 
  Mrs. Lee.Â  After deliberating again, the jury returned with a verdict for Mrs. 
  Lee in the amount of $9,000.00.Â  
In a post-trial motions hearing, Lee moved for 
  judgment notwithstanding the verdict or for a new trial.Â  Mrs. Lee moved for 
  a new trial nisi additur or a new trial absolute.Â  Bunch moved for reinstatement 
  of the original defense verdict against Mrs. Lee.Â  By order filed September 
  24, 2002, the trial court denied each of the post-trial motions.Â  Bunch and 
  the Lees appealed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
 The Lees argue the trial court erred in 
  denying their motion to exclude evidence of Mr. Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption before 
  the accident.Â  We agree.
A trial courtâ€™s ruling on admission of evidence 
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent abuse of discretion amounting to error 
  of law.Â  Hoeffner v. The Citadel, 311 S.C. 361, 365, 429 S.E.2d 190, 
  192 (1993).Â  â€œEvidence is relevant and admissible if it tends to establish or 
  make more or less probable some matter in issue.â€Â  Id. at 365, 429 S.E.2d 
  at 192.Â  â€œHowever, otherwise relevant evidence may be excluded where its probative 
  value is â€˜substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion 
  of the issues, or misleading the jury . . . .â€™â€Â  Kennedy v. Griffin, 
  358 S.C. 122, 127, 595 S.E.2d 248, 250 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Rule 403, SCRE).Â Â  
  â€œUnfair prejudice means an undue tendency to suggest a decision on an improper 
  basis.â€Â  Id. (quoting State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 666, 552 S.E.2d 
  745, 760 (2001).Â  
In Kennedy, this court held the trial court 
  had abused its discretion in allowing the admission into evidence of toxicology 
  results showing the presence of marijuana in the plaintiff motoristâ€™s system, 
  finding the unfair prejudice outweighed the probative value of the evidence.Â  
  The court found the plaintiffâ€™s mere delay in applying his brakes did not necessarily 
  suggest that he was driving under an impairment.Â  Thus the court concluded, 
  â€œUnder these circumstances, evidence of the mere presence of marijuana, without 
  further indication of impairment, could mislead the jury.Â  The admission of 
  this evidence was more prejudicial than probative because there was no correlation 
  between the marijuana and the accident.â€Â  Kennedy, 358 S.C. at 128, 595 
  S.E.2d at 251.
The Lees argue that probative value of 
  the evidence of alcohol consumption was outweighed by its prejudicial effect 
  because under the driving under the influence statute, Lee, with blood alcohol 
  level of 0.036%, would be conclusively presumed to not be under the influence 
  of alcohol. [2] Â Even the higher 
  alcohol levels Bunchâ€™s expert witnesses calculated Lee may have had when the 
  accident occurred [3]  would not 
  have created an inference that Lee was under the influence of alcohol under 
  the statute in effect at the time of the accident. 
  [4] Â  
There is no evidence that Lee showed any signs of impairment.Â  
  Leeâ€™s mother testified that when her son told her goodbye at Murrayâ€™s, he appeared 
  fine and did not appear intoxicated.Â  There is also no evidence in the record 
  that Lee was driving erratically before the accident.Â  Leeâ€™s sister testified 
  that when Lee was driving away from the restaurant, there was nothing unusual 
  in his driving.Â  Although there was some testimony the accident occurred slightly 
  left of the centerline, there is no evidence that Lee was driving across the 
  line before the accident.Â  
Bunchâ€™s expert witnesses both testified to the 
  general effects of the consumption of the amount of alcohol would have on a 
  person of Leeâ€™s size.Â  Dr. Eagerton testified that the amount of alcohol he 
  calculated Lee had consumed would have impaired a personâ€™s judgment and ability 
  to multi-task, making his ability to drive impaired.Â  Dr. Merlin testified that 
  a person who had consumed that much alcohol would have diminished functioning, 
  such as poor judgment, inability to do some fine motor skills, and the significantly 
  diminished ability to multi-task.Â  However, neither of Bunchâ€™s experts testified 
  to a connection between Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption and the cause of the accident.Â  
  They did not testify that absent the alcohol consumption, Lee would have been 
  able to avoid the accident, which happened in â€œmaybe a couple of seconds, more 
  or less, a split secondâ€ according to Chong Abernathy, who witnessed the accident.Â  
  As she explained, â€œI donâ€™t think the motorcycle had [any] time to avoid any 
  of the the â€“no matter which angle, he was going to hit the Cadillac.â€Â  
Other than the expertsâ€™ generalizations, there is simply 
  no evidence that Lee was impaired.Â  Moreover, there is no evidence at all that 
  absent the consumption of alcohol, it was â€œless probableâ€ that the accident 
  would have occurred.Â  
While the probative value of the alcohol consumption 
  is at best slight, the prejudicial effect of the admission of the evidence is 
  significant.Â  Bunchâ€™s attorney made Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption the theme of his 
  opening statement, emphasizing repeatedly that this was a case about drinking 
  and driving.Â  We find the prejudicial effect of the admission of the evidence 
  regarding Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption greatly outweighed its probative value.Â  
  Thus, we hold the trial court abused its discretion in allowing the admission 
  of the evidence concerning Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption.Â  
As we hold the trial court erred in admitting the 
  evidence of Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption, we need not address the partiesâ€™ remaining 
  issues.Â  Accordingly, the juryâ€™s verdict is reversed and the case remanded for 
  a new trial on the Leesâ€™ claims.Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â  
  



 
   
    [1]  The Lees also named Mr. Bunchâ€™s sister, Catherine Bunch Graham, who 
    owned the Cadillac, as a defendant.Â  She was dismissed from the suit prior 
    to trial and is not a party to this appeal.

 
   
    [2]  South Carolina Code Annotated Section 56-5-2950(b)(1) (Supp. 2003), 
    provides:Â  If the alcohol concentration was at that time five one-hundredths 
    of one percent or less, it is conclusively presumed that the person was not 
    under the influence of alcohol.Â Â Â Â Â  

 
   
    [3] David Eagerton, the chief toxicologist for the South Carolina Law 
    Enforcement Division (SLED) testified that he calculated Lee had an approximate 
    alcohol level of 0.066% at the time of the accident because the sample was 
    taken at least two hours after the accident, assuming Lee was in the elimination 
    stage then.Â  Similarly, Dr. Stephen Merlin, the director of the chemical dependency 
    unit at Palmetto Richland Springs Hospital, testified that according to his 
    calculations, Leeâ€™s blood alcohol level ranged from 0.066% to 0.096% between 
    the time of the accident and the time the sample was taken.Â  

 
   
    [4]  The statute in effect at the time of the accident provided:Â  
  
  If the [alcohol] concentration 
    was at that time in excess of five one-hundredths of one percent, that fact 
    does not give rise to any inference that the person was or was not under the 
    influence of alcohol, but that fact may be considered with other evidence 
    in determining guilt or innocence of the person.Â  
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 
    (Supp. 2002).Â  This section was amended in 2003 to provide that an alcohol 
    level of eight one-hundredths or more gives rise to an inference of intoxication.Â  
    Act No. 61, 2003 Acts 688.Â Â

title: Saverance v. Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service
text:
Ricky Saverance owned and operated his own carpet installation business 
and did work as a subcontractor for Williamâ€™s Carpet S


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
      Ricky Saverance, Claimant, Respondent,
v.
Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service, Employer, and The Hartford, Carrier,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-551
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed October 28, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
George D. Gallagher, of Columbia, for Appellants.
J. Marvin Mullis, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service and The 
  Hartford (collectively Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s 
  affirmance of the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s 
  order setting the compensation rate for claimant Ricky Saverance and ask this 
  court to set-off any award by the amount in excess of the correct compensation 
  rate they have already paid.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Ricky Saverance owned and operated his own carpet installation 
  business, working as a subcontractor for Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service from 1996 
  until 1998.Â  In 1998, Saverance was injured as he attempted to stretch carpet.Â  
  He missed the knee kicker and knocked out a doorjamb with the top of his knee.Â  
  Saverance has been out of work and had two knee surgeries since the accident.Â  
  The knee injury has also resulted in an altered gait and, subsequently, a back 
  injury.Â  
Though a subcontractor, Saverance is covered by Williamsâ€™ Carpet Serviceâ€™s 
  workersâ€™ compensation insurance.Â  On October 27, 1998, Saveranceâ€™s workersâ€™ 
  compensation claim was accepted and temporary total benefits at the maximum 
  weekly compensation rate for 1998, $465.18, were initiated.Â  This compensation 
  rate was based on the assumption that Saverance was an employee, and, therefore, 
  entitled to an average weekly wage and corresponding compensation rate based 
  on his gross income.Â  
After Saverance reached maximum medical improvement, Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service 
  filed a form 21 request to terminate weekly benefits and enter a permanent disability 
  award.Â  Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service also requested reduction of Saveranceâ€™s compensation 
  rate on the basis that he was not actually an employee, but a subcontractor, 
  and, therefore, the compensation rate should have been based on his net as opposed 
  to gross income.Â  Finally, Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service requested a set-off based 
  on any difference between the actual past payments and any reduced compensation 
  rate.Â  
A hearing was held before the workersâ€™ compensation commissioner on April 26, 
  2001, to determine the extent of Saveranceâ€™s permanent disability and to calculate 
  the average weekly wage and applicable compensation rate.Â  The commissioner 
  set the average weekly wage and compensation rate as $388.40 and $258.94 respectively.Â  
  However, the commissioner declined to grant a set-off based on the difference 
  between the actual compensation rate and what was paid beginning in October 
  1998.Â  Instead, the commissioner did allow a set-off from the time Williamsâ€™ 
  Carpet Service filed the form 21.Â  Furthermore, the commissioner found Saverance 
  had a 35% loss of use of his right leg and 10% loss of use of his back.Â  
The commissionerâ€™s findings were appealed by both parties to the workersâ€™ compensation 
  commission appellate panel.Â  There, the commission affirmed and reversed in 
  part.Â  The commission determined that due to the injury and his total loss of 
  earning capacity, Saverance is permanently and totally disabled.Â  The commission 
  also reinstated the maximum compensation rate for 1998 of $465.18, noting payments 
  were made at that rate for over two years and â€œ[e]ven though the correct AWW 
  [average weekly wage] and CR [compensation rate] remain open until such time 
  as there is an order of the commission, this panel finds that the rate at which 
  benefits were paid is an equitable rate.â€Â  
Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service appealed to the circuit court the issues of permanent 
  and total disability as well as the commissionâ€™s determination regarding the 
  average weekly wage.Â  The circuit court affirmed the commissionâ€™s findings.Â  
  Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service appeals part of this decision.

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard 
  of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  
  Lark v. Bi-Lo, 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  This court 
  can reverse or modify the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s 
  substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by 
  an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, 
  and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 
  341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor 
  evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, 
  as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the [Appellate Panel] 
  reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  The possibility 
  of drawing two inconsistent conclusions does not prevent the Appellate Panelâ€™s 
  conclusions from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l 
  Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999).
The Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder in 
  workersâ€™ compensation cases and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings 
  of fact.Â  Ross v. American Red Cross, 298 S.C. 490, 492, 381 S.E.2d 728, 
  730 (1989).Â  â€œThe final determination of witness credibility and the weight 
  to be accorded evidence is reserved to the [Appellate Panel].Â  It is not the 
  task of this Court to weigh the evidence as found by the [Appellate Panel].â€Â  
  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442 (citations omitted).

LAW/ANALYSIS
Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order on the basis that 
  the compensation rate is in error and it would be unjust to allow Saverance 
  to retain any difference created by a lowering of the compensation rate.Â  We 
  disagree and affirm the compensation rate as set by the workersâ€™ compensation 
  commission.Â  

1.Â  The commissionâ€™s compensation rate was not error.

Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service argues the commissionâ€™s compensation 
  rate is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial 
  evidence of the whole record.Â  In contrast, we find a record with contradictory 
  evidence regarding Saveranceâ€™s average weekly wage; however, when viewed in 
  its totality, this evidence suggests an average weekly wage that supports the 
  maximum compensation rate.Â  Because there is substantial evidence supporting 
  the full commissionâ€™s decision, we affirm.
The goal of workersâ€™ compensation is to set an approximate 
  earnings capacity had claimant not been injured.Â  Sellers v. Pinedale Residential 
  Ctr., 350 S.C. 183, 191, 564 S.E.2d 694, 698 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  A subcontractorâ€™s 
  compensation rate should be based on net rather than gross earnings.Â  Stephen 
  v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 347, 478 S.E.2d 74, 81 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  

The difficulty caused by this case is that Williamsâ€™ Carpet 
  Services has challenged the compensation rate, and it is difficult to clearly 
  show what Saverance as a subcontractor â€œearned.â€Â  The average compensation rate 
  approved by the full commission was $465.18.Â  The rule for calculating the compensation 
  rate on form 20 requires multiplying the average weekly wage by the factor of 
  .6667 to reach the compensation rate.Â  Therefore, the average weekly wage would 
  have been a minimum of $697.74 for the average compensation rate to be $465.18.Â  

Saveranceâ€™s average weekly wage can be calculated in several 
  ways according to his tax returns.Â  The net income on Saveranceâ€™s tax return 
  was $3,650.Â  The average weekly rate after expenses would be $86.90, $3,650 
  divided by 42 weeks.Â  However, counsel for Williamsâ€™ Carpet admitted this argument 
  for a minimum compensation rate was made â€œtongue [in] cheekâ€.Â  The gross income 
  on the income tax return was $39,371, which would be $937.40 per week when divided 
  by 42 weeks.Â  However, the $937.40 gross pay does not take into account expenses 
  Saverance incurred.Â  It is not simply a case of looking at the total amount 
  paid to Saverance by Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service, because out of this money Saverance 
  had to pay helpers and purchase supplies.Â  
On top of contradictory results based on his tax returns, 
  Saverance testified 10% of his gross payments had been taken by Williamsâ€™ Carpet 
  Service to pay workersâ€™ compensation insurance premiums and he had paid approximately 
  $4,400 during the 42 weeks prior to his injury.Â  This would suggest that Saverance 
  earned $1,047.60 gross pay per week. [2] Â  Additionally, a vocational rehabilitation 
  expert for Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service presented evidence that the average hourly 
  wage for a carpet installer in South Carolina was $9.71.Â  This hourly wage would 
  support an average weekly wage of $388 and was entered into evidence pursuant 
  to section 42-1-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003).Â  The hourly wage 
  of a carpet installer would not, however, be that of a subcontractor with installers 
  working for him.
Mr. Williams of Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service also testified that 
  Saverance was among his top subcontractors, he could make more than ten dollars 
  an hour, and could gross more than four hundred dollars a week.Â  Later, before 
  the circuit court, defense counsel conceded that Saverance â€œwas grossing a substantial 
  amount of money per week, you know, 900, $800, a thousand dollars, $700 a week, 
  which would, you know, entitle him to the maximum compensation rate.â€Â  
The record is 
  replete with conflicting and contradictory evidence regarding the average weekly 
  wage.Â  However, there is evidence that Saveranceâ€™s gross weekly wage exceeded 
  $1,000.Â  Additionally, the record is devoid of any serious valuation of Saveranceâ€™s 
  work-related expenses.Â  By awarding Saverance the maximum weekly wage, the commission 
  must have determined his expenses did not exceed $300.Â  Decisions of fact are 
  beyond the purview of the appellate court as long as there is substantial evidence 
  supporting the commissionâ€™s decision.Â  We find the compensation rate was properly 
  and appropriately set.Â  As there is no difference in payments made, Williamsâ€™ 
  Carpet Service second argument is rendered moot.
Additionally, 
  Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service argues the circuit court erred in finding the average 
  weekly wage to be $465.18.Â  However, it is clear from a review of the record 
  and the entirety of the order that this was a scrivener error and in fact the 
  court supported the commissionâ€™s determination that the compensation rate 
  was $465.18.Â  See State v. George, 331 S.C. 342, 347, 503 S.E.2d 
  168, 171 (1998) (â€œWe note that the circuit courtâ€™s order incorrectly refers 
  to Dr. Albiniakâ€™s testimony concerning African Americans making up more than 
  13% of the â€˜voting and driving population.â€™ This statement--that the percentage 
  was based on voting and driving population--is directly contradicted 
  by the record, so we assume this was a scrivenerâ€™s error.â€).

2.Â  Unjust Enrichment

Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service argues if the compensation rate 
  was in error, the doctrine of unjust enrichment requires Williamsâ€™ Carpet Service 
  be given credit for payments made pursuant to the higher, erroneous compensation 
  rate.Â  Because of our decision that the higher compensation rate was supported 
  by substantial evidence, it is not necessary to reach this argument.Â  See 
  Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 
  613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining 
  issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the decision of the circuit 
  court is
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We 
    decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  
    $4,400 divided by 42 weeks equals $104.76.Â  $104.76 is ten percent of $1,047.60.
